business.start.para: The SPEAKER (Hon. David Hawker) took the chair at 2.00 pm, and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I inform the House that the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads will be absent from question time today and tomorrow. He is travelling to Norfolk Island for ministerial meetings. The Minister for Transport and Regional Services will answer questions on his behalf.

—My question is to the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. Minister, isn’t it a fact that on 21 June 2004 the government correctly approved and issued travel identity documents for a Mr and Mrs Kola? Minister, isn’t it also a fact that, after failing to deport Mr and Mrs Kola to Serbia using these documents, the minister’s department knowingly requested the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to issue new identity documents bearing names for Mr and Mrs Kola that the department knew were false identities? Minister, isn’t the deliberate production of false identities in order to gain admission to a country what people smugglers do—not an action of the Australian government?

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The honourable member has made a serious allegation about the integrity of the minister for immigration. I ask that he withdraw the imputation or else deal with it on substantive motion. He cannot deal with it in a question.
—I thank the member for Mackellar. I ask the member for Watson to begin his question again so I can be clear on the point.

—My question is to the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. Minister, isn’t it a fact that on 21 June 2004 the government correctly approved and issued travel identity documents for a Mr and Mrs Kola? Minister, isn’t it also a fact that, after failing to deport Mr and Mrs Kola to Serbia using these documents, the minister’s department knowingly requested the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to issue new identity documents bearing names for Mr and Mrs Kola that the department knew were false identities? Minister, isn’t the deliberate production of false identities in order to gain admission to a country what people smugglers do—not the role of the Australian government?

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr JOHN COBB

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I do not have knowledge of the particular issue you are talking about, but obviously I will get back to you as soon as I have it. But, Mr Speaker, I can assure you that this government does not engage in illegal practices. I can assure you that Minister Vanstone, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, does not encourage any such practices nor have anything to do with them. I will refer back to the House as soon as I have the information required.
—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer inform the House of the International Monetary Fund’s latest assessment of the Australian economy?

—I thank the honourable member for Mackellar for her question. I can report to the House that the International Monetary Fund has released its annual assessment of the Australian economy, known as the ‘Article IV assessment’. This is what the IMF does for all 184 members. I am sure that both sides of the House will be glad to know that the IMF has reported that the sustained strength of Australia’s economic performance can be attributed to an exemplary setting of economic policy and institutions. The IMF notes that since the early 1990s, when Australia bottomed in living standards as a consequence of the Labor recession, per capita incomes have increased to almost 10 per cent above the OECD average. So, even though the OECD standard of living was increasing, Australia’s was increasing faster and, far from being in that bottom half of the world league ladder of economic performance, since the early 1990s Australia has climbed the ladder and all Australians have improved their per capita incomes compared to developed economies overseas. The IMF notes that employment and productivity gains have been strong. The IMF records that there has been a six per cent decrease in the unemployment rate since the early 1990s. Unemployment is now at a 30-year low and six per cent better than it was under the then Minister for Employment, Education and Training, who was presiding over an 11 per cent unemployment rate in the early 1990s.
—Who was that?

—Modesty forbids me from naming who the minister for employment was when unemployment hit 11 per cent. The IMF notes that there has been strong productivity growth. It indicates that there is ‘increased flexibility at the micro-economic level’, and notes ‘prudent and flexible management of monetary and fiscal policy within transparent medium-term policy frameworks’.

answer.para: All in all, the IMF report today is a glowing assessment of the Australian economy. If one were to compare it with the IMF assessment of the UK, United States, European or Japanese economies, you would see that no longer does Australia trail in economic performance—now, Australia is among the lead nations of the OECD. We did not get there by accident or fluke. We got there by hard work. A proper monetary policy, a balanced budget, reducing net debt, reform of industrial relations, abolishing wholesale sales tax, cutting capital gains tax and reducing income taxes—these were the things that made the Australian economy stronger, and if we continue with economic reform it will continue stronger into the near future.

talk.start.para: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Speaker of the Parliament of Sri Lanka, the Honourable Lokubandara. On behalf of the House, I extend to him a very warm welcome.

speech.para: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. Does the minister agree that the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs should play a critical role in Australia’s national security? Minister, is it not imperative, if the immigration department is to play this role, that it provide accurate, not deliberately false, documents to other key agencies critical to ensuring Australia’s national security? Minister, is the department of immigration now so incompetent that it commits identity fraud in order to do its job? How can Australia’s national security be protected with that level of incompetence on the front line?

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. That question offends standing order 100(d)(ii), (iii) and (iv). It contains arguments, inferences, imputations and, one could say, even insults. As a consequence, it should be ruled out of order.

—Order! I listened carefully to the question. It did make reference to the department. I do not know that it specifically referred to the minister in the way that the member for Sturt has implied, so I will rule the question in order and call the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr JOHN COBB

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for his question. All I can say is that for the honourable member to be suggesting that this government would have anything at all to do with illegal representation from one department to another shows just how desperate the opposition has become. It shows how absolutely irrelevant the opposition know they have become to the greater Australian public. It shows how irrelevant they were in 2001, when they could not find it in themselves to have a decent immigration policy. It shows how they have never, ever been able to stand firmly on one side of the line when it comes to protecting Australia’s security. I think the member for Watson needs to take a very hard look at himself as to whether he has any respect for his own side.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker.
—The minister has completed his answer.

—My question is addressed to the Acting Prime Minister and Minister for Trade. Would the Acting Prime Minister and Minister for Trade update the House on Australia’s relationship with China? Does China’s economic development present an opportunity for Australia?

—I thank the member for Pearce for her question. I recognise her ongoing interest in our international relationships, particularly with regard to the effort that many of her Western Australian counterparts have put into the relationship with China, particularly in the minerals and resources sector.

answer.para: China is the fastest growing major economy in the world today. The Chinese economy is growing, on average, at about nine per cent per year. It has achieved that on an average basis over the last 25 years, which is quite a phenomenal achievement. This growth has lifted more than 300 million people out of poverty. A prosperous, outward-looking and engaged China is a vital component of both international and regional economic prosperity when you look at what is taking place within the East Asian region now in growth, linkages among those economies and the impact on that by the growth of China.

Australia have been well placed to benefit from China’s rapid industrial expansion because of our strengths. I have flagged some of the all-important exports that go out of Western Australia that have helped to fuel, if you like, the industrialisation of China. Australia’s exports to China grew by 30 per cent in 2004-05, to stand at about $13 billion. During the last decade, our exports to China have increased fourfold, such has been the growth of our relationship with China.

I know that many members of the House are interested in the export of manufactured goods. It is interesting to note that, in the last little while, our exports of elaborately transformed manufactures to China have grown four times faster than to the rest of the world. So we are expanding our manufactured exports to China faster than we are to most other markets in the world. Services exports have grown nearly three times as fast to China than to the rest of the world. It is interesting to look at some of the key statistics as far as China’s growth is concerned. In 1996, China had seven million mobile phones in use; in 2003, they had 269 million mobile phones in use. In 2003, there were 36 million computers in China, and that rate is doubling every 28 months, such is the expansion and development of the Chinese economy.

The relationship that Australia, over many decades, has established and nourished with China is delivering and will in the future deliver significant prosperity to our country. Australia’s FTA negotiations with China allow us to make the most of this unique opportunity as far as our exporters and our broader relationship with China are concerned. Our overall economic relationship within the East Asian region is growing rapidly and being drawn along by the growth of China.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Treasurer. I refer him again to the fact that, on 12 August this year, the Singapore price for petrol was $95 per barrel but more recently it rose to $120 per barrel while the crude oil price a month ago and today has hovered more consistently at around $89 per barrel. Does the Treasurer now accept that Australians are the victims of petrol price gouging? Why is he not prepared to direct the ACCC to investigate refiner margins, as he can do, of course, under the Trade Practices Act? Is it because the Treasurer does not understand the issue or does he simply not care?
—The Treasurer does not need to respond to the last part of that question.

—As I said earlier today, consumers in Australia are obviously suffering under exorbitant petrol prices. That is not good for them, it is not good for Australian businesses, it is not good for the economy, it is not good for the consumer price index and it is not good for other retailers because, as people spend more on petrol, they tend to spend less in other areas of the economy.

answer.para: If the petrol price were just a matter for an ACCC investigation, nobody would be happier than this government to have the matter solved. But I point out to the honourable member for Hunter that the petrol price does seem to be high in the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Japan. So, if the cause of high petrol prices was domestic conditions, one would wonder why they are high in the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Japan. The reality is that the price of petrol is high because world oil prices are high and refining capacity, particularly in the wake of Hurricane Katrina, has been reduced. You do not have to take my word for it, because you could have read this in the Age on 20 July 2005, where an op-ed piece—

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order, regarding relevance. The question was specifically about action and all we are hearing are comparisons without identifying—
—The Treasurer is in order.
—The op-ed piece in the Age was entitled ‘No quick fix to the problem of pricey petrol’. The article concluded with the following quote:

quote.para: ... there are no magic solutions to high petrol prices. It might seem clever to pretend there are, but the Australian people are smarter than that.

answer.para: Who wrote that? It was Craig Emerson, the member for Rankin. How could he have had the member for Hunter in mind when he said:

quote.para: It might seem clever to pretend there are, but the Australian people are smarter than that.

answer.para: I will tell you one thing: the Australian people are a lot smarter than the member for Hunter.

talk.start.para: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Hon. Neil Brown, a former minister in this place. On behalf of the House I extend to him a very warm welcome.

speech.para: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Treasurer. Is the Treasurer aware of recent comments on the need for ongoing economic reform in Australia? Are there any other views?

—I thank the honourable member for Blair for his question. As I previously outlined to the House, the International Monetary Fund has just done an annual report on the Australian economy, as it does in relation to all 184 members of the IMF, the premier world financial body. It has endorsed Australia’s fiscal policy, its monetary policy, its structural reform programs and its competition policy, but it makes the point—and the government would also make this point—that you can never rest when it comes to economic reform. The moment you rest in relation to economic reform is the moment you begin to slip behind.

answer.para: The IMF talks about things we have to do in Australia. It welcomes our recent reforms of pharmaceutical benefits. It welcomes the establishment of the Future Fund. But, most importantly, it says that Australia can get a productivity benefit from reforming its industrial relations system. After looking at the government’s proposal on industrial relations and work to welfare reform, the IMF concluded:

quote.para: The mission urged the implementation of this package of reforms to widen employment opportunities and raise productivity by enhancing flexibility and work arrangements.

answer.para: You do not have to take it from the government, you do not have to take it from the Prime Minister, you do not have to take it from the Treasurer and you do not have to take it from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations because the IMF has recommended to Australia that we engage in industrial relations reform—met with great hilarity by the Labor Party.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Denison says, ‘What would the IMF know?’ Well, what would it know compared to the member for Denison?
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order, I have been invited to respond. In Indonesia, the monetary crisis was caused—
—The Member for Denison will resume his seat! That is not a point of order.

—I thank the member for Denison for sharing with us all he knows on the subject of industrial relations! Who says there is nothing to be gained from industrial relations reform? The member for Lilley says you cannot engage in any further industrial reform in this country.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The Treasurer asked the member for Denison for a point on the IMF. The Treasurer has not answered the member for Denison’s point.
—The member for Lyons will resume his seat. The member for Lyons is well aware that the Treasurer is in order.
—The member for Lilley says you cannot get any productivity out of industrial relations. He knows more than the IMF. The Leader of the Opposition said this:

quote.para: The industrial relations lemon has been squeezed dry …

answer.para: There is a lemon here, but it is not industrial relations reform; it is the views of the Leader of the Opposition. Why would it be that the Labor Party opposes industrial relations reform? It has nothing to do with the economic productivity of the country; it has everything to do with the people who direct the Australian Labor Party—the trade union secretaries who give it its orders.
I think members on both sides of this House are looking forward to the publication of a book this weekend. Melbourne University Publishing is publishing The Latham Diaries.

talk.start.para: —Something you’d never manage! When’s your book coming out?
—Maybe you could read it to your children.
—The member for Ballarat on a point of order.
—The collective writings of Peter Costello!
—The member for Melbourne will allow the member for Ballarat to take her point of order.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order on relevance. The Treasurer was not asked about any books, nor was he asked about The Latham Diaries.
—The member for Ballarat will resume her seat. I am listening closely to the Treasurer.
—Apparently in this diary, according to Melbourne University Publishing, the former Leader of the Opposition had this—
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order on relevance. I know he has to prove a point during the absence of the Prime Minister, but he ought to do it within the framework—
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
Mr Beazley interjecting—
—The Leader of the Opposition! The Treasurer is answering the question and, as members would recall, the end of the question did ask for other views.

—Other views, Mr Speaker? I thought the House would be interested to know the view of the man that the Labor Party tried to make Prime Minister less than one year ago. He has written his views in The Latham Diaries, where he said:

quote.para: I’m not opposed to unionism per se—

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I know the Treasurer has an agenda, but there is such a thing as standing orders—
—Does the Leader of the Opposition have a point of order?
—Mr Speaker, it is on relevance. This has absolutely no relevance to the question he was asked.
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. I am sure the Treasurer will come back to the question.
—Mr Speaker, the former Leader of the Opposition says:

quote.para: I’m not opposed to unionism per se, just the idea of six union secretaries sitting around a Chinese restaurant table planning the future for everyone else.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order, and once again it is on relevance. Will the Treasurer’s book be called ‘My almost brilliant career’?
—I am sure the Treasurer is coming back to the question.

—If it is a choice between the views of the member for Lilley or the Leader of the Opposition and the views of the OECD or the IMF, or the Liberal-National coalition government, we will stand up for economic reform any time because it leads to higher living standards for the Australian people.
—My question is to the Acting Prime Minister, as opposed to the ‘acting Acting Prime Minister’.
—The leader will come to his question.

—Is the Acting Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party aware of the existence of a 104-page Telstra document prepared by Chief Operations Officer Greg Winn, which details plans to cut jobs and services from Telstra as part of CEO, Sol Trujillo’s, strategic review of Telstra? Acting Prime Minister, is this strategic review scheduled to be released next month?
—I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. I am not aware of the details of any such report. I understand that there are reports to be put out by Telstra next month.
—Are you aware of its existence?

—I am not aware of this report. But can I make a point with regard to services and services to regional Australia, because that is what the question goes to. In the whole process of this debate about Telstra and the level of services to regional Australia, we have put in place legislation that underpins the universal service obligation. We have put in place legislation that underpins the customer service guarantee. We have announced what we are going to do as far as the network reliability framework is concerned and what we are going to require Telstra to do as part of that licensing requirement. We are going to make part of the licensing requirement their local presence plan in regional Australia.

answer.para: We have made abundantly clear in this whole debate what we intend to do as far as the delivery of services to regional Australia is concerned, and that is what this government have done since we came into office in 1996, which is something that the Labor Party—you should note this—never ever did when they were in government for 13 years. Apart from turning off the analog mobile phone system, they never mentioned any interest in investment in telecommunications infrastructure in regional Australia. In the last nine years, we have invested over $1 billion in regional telecommunications across Australia.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order on relevance. The question was specifically about the existence of a 104-page document; whether he had read it—
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. As the Acting Prime Minister has finished his answer, I call the member for Wakefield.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Would the Attorney-General advise the House of practical measures, including transport security, taken by the government to counter the threat of terrorism in Australia?

—I thank the honourable member for Wakefield for his question, and I know of his real and continuing interest in these matters. Of course the government’s response to the terrorist threat has been substantial. It is a three-pronged approach involving better laws to deal with terrorists and prevent attacks, equipping our law enforcement and intelligence agencies with the tools they need to fight terrorism, and international cooperation, because we know that the war on terrorism is not a battle which can be fought on any one front.

answer.para: I note that the Leader of the Opposition has recently expressed some interest in these matters and at the weekend gave an insight into the type of innovative thinking that we have come to expect from him and his colleagues on these matters. According to the Leader of the Opposition, we do not need new laws to deter terrorists; we need more spies. I am pleased to inform the House that under this government ASIO currently has around 960 staff, compared with 580 four years ago. This figure is expected to increase to 1,100 by the end of this financial year. I might say that no request from ASIO in the budget process has been rejected by this government.

This significant commitment accounts for only one part of the $5.6 billion investment in national security since September 11 four years ago. For the benefit of honourable members opposite, I am pleased to advise that there have been more than 100 practical security initiatives. They include establishing counter-terrorism first response capability at all international and major domestic airports, increasing the rate of container examination by Customs and establishing Customs officers to board more vessels at first port of arrival in Australia, expanding our National Counterterrorism Committee exercise program, establishing the AFP mobile strike teams and joint counter-terrorism teams, initiating a national identity security framework, increasing the funding for AUSTRAC to provide vital intelligence to counter money laundering and terrorist financing, establishing and maintaining the national security hotline, engaging with the private sector to improve protection of critical infrastructure and supplying chemical, biological and radiological counterterrorism equipment to the states and territories.

These initiatives are a record of achievement and a measure of this government’s commitment to protecting Australians from terrorism. They do not diminish the importance of equipping our agencies with the legislative tools they need to successfully thwart terrorist activities, and I look forward to the Leader of the Opposition supporting the serious, practical measures announced by the Prime Minister and me last week. In the meantime, the government will get on with the job of protecting our community from the terrorist threat.

talk.start.para: —It is a shame you have got a report that says your aviation security is a complete mess—
—The Leader of the Opposition will come to his question.

—My question is to the Acting Prime Minister. Isn’t it the case that, just as Telstra provided the government with its 11 August advice, Telstra has also provided the government with or briefed it on the 104-page document? Isn’t it the case that this details up to 14,000 job losses from Telstra, including in rural and regional Australia? Isn’t it the case that the government is keeping this information secret until after the legislation for the full privatisation of Telstra goes through the Senate? Isn’t this why the government is rushing the Telstra fire sale through the parliament?
—No.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Would the minister inform the House of any discriminatory provisions and restrictions on employment which exist in the state industrial relations systems? How do these impact on the Commonwealth workplace relations system, and are there any alternative views?

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Hasluck for his question. Indeed there are examples of archaic and discriminatory provisions in awards in the state systems in Australia. Let me take a couple of examples. The bag, sack and textile award in Western Australia contains the provision that no more than one in three male workers in a workplace can be juniors, but no more than one in two female workers can be juniors. And take the laundry workers award, also in Western Australia: there may be two female juniors for each adult employee but only one male junior for each adult employee. These are just a couple of examples of the mind-numbing minutiae contained in state awards that seek to regulate every minute of every day of workers in Australia. The only party in Australia which is defending this mind-numbing archaic detail is the Australian Labor Party.

answer.para: The Australian Labor Party has as a policy to call for the implementation of a comprehensive system of awards in Australia. It is no wonder, as the Treasurer pointed out, that in its report the IMF has called upon and supported further reform of workplace relations in Australia. In its report, the IMF said, in part:

quote.para: Further reforms of industrial relations are needed to expand labor demand and facilitate productivity gains.

answer.para: It went on to point out that large employers face up to six industrial relations systems at federal and state levels—something which this side of politics is trying to overcome by the implementation of one national system for industrial relations. This is something which, again, is opposed by the Australian Labor Party and the union movement.
Indeed, the IMF concluded:

quote.para: The mission urged the implementation of this package of reforms to widen employment opportunities and raise productivity by enhancing flexibility in work arrangements.

answer.para: So it is quite clear that when an objective assessment is made of workplace relations in Australia and the challenges facing the Australian economy over the next five, 10 or 15 years, by the IMF, there is this conclusion that we need to undertake further incremental, careful, balanced reforms of the workplace relations system—something which this government proposes to do. Why does the ALP stand opposed to these changes? Why has the ALP opposed every attempt to change and improve workplace relations under this government going back to the 1996 reforms? As the Treasurer pointed out in his quote from a former Leader of the Opposition, it is because you have union leaders sitting around a table in a Chinese restaurant each night deciding what the policy for the ALP and the rest of this country should be.

talk.start.para: Mr Crean interjecting—
—I hear the member for Hotham interjecting. We have in the Australian Labor Party, in the member for Hotham and next to him the member for—I cannot remember his seat—
—Batman!
—Batman, and the member for Throsby, three former presidents of the ACTU, three of the six, no doubt, that sat around the Chinese restaurant table—
—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. They did not lead privileged lives like the minister. They lead lives like ordinary Australians.
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. That is not a point of order.

—If the Leader of the Opposition believes growing up in a family where my parents got out of bed at three or four o’clock every morning and worked until eight or nine o’clock at night is privileged, then he does not know what he is talking about! The reality is that, rather than being made up of the privileged members and union bosses of Australia that occupy the benches on the other side, this side of politics represents the ordinary people of Australia.

—My question is to the Acting Prime Minister and follows on from the earlier questions by the Leader of the Opposition. Is it the case that the 104-page document contains potentially market-sensitive information? Does the Acting Prime Minister support Labor’s approach to the Stock Exchange for the document to be released generally rather than provided selectively? Will the Acting Prime Minister ensure the public release of the information before the vote to fully privatise Telstra takes place in the Senate?
—I cannot pass comment on the document because I have not seen it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the minister inform the House of new measures taken by the government to reduce petrol sniffing in remote Indigenous communities?

—I do thank the member for Solomon for his question and I also thank him for the concern he has to try to combat this dreadful scourge which afflicts many remote Indigenous communities. Petrol sniffing in remote communities has claimed some 100 lives since the early 1980s, but thanks to the policies of the Howard government unsniffable petrol is now available in some 43 remote communities around the country. In the budget, the government allocated an additional $9 million to extend unsniffable petrol to another 23 communities, and yesterday the government committed a further $6 million to extend unsniffable petrol to at least seven communities and six roadhouses in a 128,000 square kilometre swathe of the central desert, centred on Ayers Rock. This is an area twice the size of the state of Tasmania.

answer.para: Also yesterday, the Commonwealth, South Australian, Western Australian and Northern Territory governments agreed on a comprehensive anti-petrol-sniffing strategy, including consistent legislation clearly banning petrol sniffing, effective policing to ensure that the law is actually enforced and responsible communities that are capable of giving their young people a decent future. Again, I commend the example of Yuendumu, which has almost eliminated petrol sniffing through practising zero tolerance and quite literally marching petrol sniffers out to the Mount Theo outstation for rehabilitation and treatment. As Noel Pearson said on the Sunday program a couple of weeks ago, when it comes to substance abuse, we need to ‘rebuild intolerance’. That is what he said. Yet again, Noel Pearson is providing great leadership, not just to the Indigenous people of Australia but to the wider Australian community.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Acting Prime Minister. Is the Acting Prime Minister prepared to ensure the tabling in the House of a document prepared by Telstra’s chief operations officer, Greg Winn, detailing plans to cut jobs and services from Telstra before the Telstra bills are voted on in the Senate?

—I would have thought that the Leader of the Opposition would have been aware that for any information such as this that Telstra has it is a matter for the Telstra board to decide when it should release it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Would the minister update the House on the government’s efforts to improve transport infrastructure? Are there any alternative policies?

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr TRUSS

talk.start.para: —I know that the honourable member for Page, like many members on this side of the House, is very anxious to see considerable upgrading of Australia’s road system and wants to see, in particular, the AusLink commitment for $12.7 billion put into action as quickly as possible. This is an important national program that will help deliver critically important land transport upgrades around the country, including significant expenditure on the Pacific Highway—which I know is of great interest to the member for Page and all other members on the New South Wales North Coast.

answer.para: Again, I have to tell the House that still only two states have signed up to the AusLink agreement. Victoria and South Australia are the only states that have unlocked the key to this significant additional funding—

talk.start.para: Mr Wilkie interjecting—
—The member for Swan!

—to enable important road and rail construction projects to commence. It is important to note the significance of New South Wales and other states blocking the financial opportunities that are available under AusLink. For instance, under AusLink, New South Wales will receive $2,488 million, including $1,946 million for construction. That is 77 per cent more in construction funding than the state has received over the previous five years. It is a 77 per cent increase, and New South Wales has not yet signed the agreement. What about Western Australia, which I referred to a couple of days ago? There is $620 million under AusLink for Western Australia, including $460 million for construction. That is an 89 per cent increase over what they have received in the past. This is an 89 per cent increase, and Western Australia are dillydallying! They cannot get around to signing the agreement. I would remind the states that, if they have not signed up by 1 October 2005, all of the unsigned agreements will include the new construction code guidelines.
Mr Wilkie interjecting—
—The member for Swan is warned!
—Perhaps they are waiting for the new industrial relations reform to take effect so that they can get the maximum benefit in their state.

answer.para: I was asked whether there are any alternative policies or commentary on these issues. On ABC Sydney Drive just the other day, the New South Wales Minister for Roads said, ‘If I get the money, I will spend it.’ There is a clear message to the Minister for Roads in New South Wales: he can have the money; all he has to do is sign the AusLink agreement. But it seems as though Labor are not all that committed to road funding.

I noticed that Labor’s shadow spokesman for transport and regional services waded into the issue yesterday with a statement in which he repeated Labor’s election commitment to strip money out of the Roads to Recovery program—a program absolutely essential for the construction of urban streets and rural roads around the country—and to spend that money on other projects such as public transport, bus and ferry stations, walkways, railway crossings and real-time passenger information. That is their priority—the money goes off roads and onto all these other kinds of infrastructure expenditure. I fail to see how you can deal with the increasing freight task in Australia by building more cycle lanes, walkways or ferry stations. That is not the answer. It is time that Labor got on board with this very significant AusLink project and used their initiative so that all Labor state governments would sign up, get on with the work and build the roads so that we can stop some of the fatalities that are tearing so many communities apart at the present time.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Treasurer in his capacity representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Does the Treasurer agree with his colleague the member for Cook that the Telstra privatisation bill is ‘an economic bill about privatising a very large government owned organisation and has no impact on families’? Will the Treasurer be seeking the Prime Minister’s commitment to deliver on his promise to deliver these family impact statements? Treasurer, is the provision of decent telecommunications services crucial to family life in the country and in the suburbs?

—Can I say that access to communications services is important for families. Of course it is important for families. That is one of the reasons why we want to promote competition in the sector to get lower prices. It is one of the reasons why we have the HiBIS to extend broadband access. It is one of the reasons why we have a $2 billion regional Communications Fund. We do believe it is important for families.

answer.para: I take up this point that something that is important to families can only be delivered by a nationalised company. I think that is the premise behind the question. If Telstra is in private ownership, somehow that affects in an adverse way the delivery of services to families. Can I make this point: there are many things that are delivered in this economy by the private sector that are important to families. Let me give you an example: food. In this country, food is entirely produced by private producers, distributed by private transporters and sold by private retailers, and it is very important to families. But that is not a reason to nationalise the food industry.

talk.start.para: Mr Tanner interjecting—
—The member for Melbourne is warned!
—Let me take another example which will be dear to the heart of the member for Melbourne.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order which goes to relevance. The question was about a family impact statement. Why hadn’t it been done on Telstra, and was there an intention to deliver one?
—The Treasurer is in order.

—I was going to go back through the Labor Party’s history of supporting the privatisation of banking. Is banking important to families? I would have thought so. Did the Labor Party believe that, therefore, we had to have a government owned Commonwealth Bank? I do not think so. In fact, one of the proudest boasts of the member for Brand was that he was around when the Commonwealth Bank was privatised. Can I just say—

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The question was specifically about family impact statements and whether the Treasurer was going to keep the Prime Minister’s commitment to Family First on this matter.
—The member for Ballarat is correct. The question was about impact on families, and I believe the Treasurer is in order.

—Let me conclude by saying that we believe that a competitive sector, delivering lower prices, with an infrastructure fund to roll out broadband, is in the interests of Australian families. Can I say that the regional telecommunications fund is going to be of great assistance to regional families to future proof new services. In fact, it ought to be renamed ‘The Labor Party future-proofing fund’, because what it will do is ensure that those people get great services long before the Labor Party ever gets back into office and proceeds, as we have always known that it would, with its own plans to privatise Telstra.
—My question is addressed to the very capable and cooperative Minister for Ageing. Would the minister advise the House how the government is supporting older people in rural and regional communities?

—I thank the member for Hume for his question. I certainly acknowledge his commitment to supporting the needs of older people living in the electorate of Hume. Due to the strong economic management of this government, we have been able to invest record levels of funding in aged care, including in rural and regional Australia. We are aware of the particular challenges that older people face in accessing aged care in rural and regional Australia, and members will be pleased to know that over one-third of all operational aged care places—residential and community care—are located in rural and regional areas.

answer.para: This year, in the 2005 annual aged care allocation round, we have allocated over 40 per cent of available places for rural and regional areas. There is in place a viability supplement, recognising the increasing costs that the delivery of care in rural and regional Australia might bring. As of 1 January this year we have increased that viability supplement by a further $14½ million over the next four years, on top of the $13 million a year that currently comprises that viability supplement.

The government also provide capital grants for homes in rural and regional Australia for communities who have difficulty accessing capital. Again, this year some $40 million will be available for homes in rural and regional Australia for capital requirements. Recently, we completed a grants application process to enhance respite services and information services across Australia. As a result of this grants process, some $374 million will be available for enhanced and increased respite services and improved information services. Of the 414 projects that received grants, over 50 per cent were located in rural and regional Australia—some 244 projects, up on the 193 rural and regional projects before the commencement of the grants application process. On average, there has been an increase of 20 per cent per project across Australia. We now have in place 54 combined Carelink and Commonwealth respite service centres across Australia. These provide information on aged care services and respite services. Thirty-nine of those 54 co-located services are in rural and regional Australia and, as a result of our grants process, two new services will be available in remote communities in the Northern Territory.

The government has also allocated a further $9.3 million in the last budget for further respite services, through the 93 multipurpose services that exist in Australia to service remote and rural communities. The government is committed to supporting older Australians living in rural and regional areas. Meanwhile, the Labor Party has no interest in the needs of people in rural and regional Australia, no interest in aged care and still no aged care policy.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. I refer the minister to the report released today by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling—NATSEM—an organisation which the Prime Minister has described as respected, independent and objective. Is the minister aware that this respected institute has found that people with a disability will lose up to $122 a week under the Howard government’s extreme changes to welfare? Doesn’t this come on top of a previous report by NATSEM that showed that sole parent families will be up to $91 a week worse off under the changes? Minister, will you guarantee that people with disabilities and sole parents who are already looking for a job will not be financially worse off?

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: —In reply to the member for Sydney, can I say that this government has a simple proposition upon which it is elaborating its Welfare to Work measures. That proposition is this: people who can work should work. That is, if people are capable of working part time, who are capable of working 15 hours or more a week, there is an expectation that they should work. In parallel with that—

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —They ask a question, yet they do not seem to want to hear the answer. In parallel with that, those people who are not capable of working for 15 hours a week—that is, people who, because of a disability, are not capable of working 15 hours or more a week—will remain on the disability support pension. In the future, people in that situation will be on the disability support pension.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I draw attention to relevance. This government has reduced employment for the handicapped. Each year, this government—
—The member for Denison will resume his seat. The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations is in order.

—I understand—I am indeed informed—that only 10 per cent of people currently on the disability support pension actually engage in some form of paid work. If you make a comparison between what a person with no paid work receives under the disability support pension—namely, a total of $290.05 a week—and what that person will receive on the Newstart allowance when they are undertaking 15 hours of paid work, you find that the effective money in their pocket at the end of the week is $382.25.
Mr Adams interjecting—

—The member for Lyons interjects and says that is pretty mean. That is $382.25 compared to the $290.05 that they get at present. Let me say this: the government does not resile from the proposition that if people in this country are capable of undertaking part-time work then there is an expectation that they should do so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer. Would the minister advise the House how the superannuation co-contribution scheme is boosting the retirement savings of low- and middle-income Australians? Are there any threats to this scheme?

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr BROUGH

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Greenway for her question. As I have informed the House, the federal government, under its co-contribution, has now given $309 million to low- and middle-income earners in Australia who, in the first year of the super co-contribution, received a dollar for every dollar they put in. But what does that mean to those low- and middle-income earners over time, because what we are about here is changing people’s attitudes to their own retirement? A worker who is 25 years of age and who in the first year took up the option of putting $1,000 away and receiving $1,000 through the Howard government’s co-contribution—getting an immediate boost of $2,000 into their superannuation account—over a 40-year working life, with the seven per cent interest rate, will have $28,000, in round figures, by making the decision even just once. In the electorate of the member for Greenway, as she will be pleased to know, in the first year of operation, over 3,100 of those low- and middle-income earners in the Parramatta region and around that area actually took the chance of getting a dollar for a dollar from the Howard government.

answer.para: She also asks: are there any threats? The threat comes in the form of the Labor Party’s policy at the last election. So that the member for Lilley cannot pretend that he has been somehow verballed, let me read and quote from page 4 of their policy:

quote.para: Labor will abolish the Howard government’s super co-contribution scheme from 11 October 2004.

answer.para: Many people in this House will remember the former leader, Mark Latham, in a photo opportunity at the Golden Circle factory in Brisbane with the member for Lilley. Photo opportunities are cheap, but many of those workers would have no doubt taken up the super co-contribution. In fact, nearly one in every 10 voters in the Lilley electorate actually took up the Howard government’s co-contribution; some 7,500 members of the member’s electorate took up the Howard government’s co-contribution. I wonder whether the member for Lilley mentioned that to the workers at the Golden Circle factory. The member for Lilley had a policy—

talk.start.para: —No!
—Yes!
—No, he did not!

—Treasurer, he had a policy! The policy was: do not let these workers at the Golden Circle factory get $1,000 as a dollar for a dollar. The Labor Party said, ‘If you’re on a $25,000 income, we’re going to cut your contribution tax by two per cent over four years.’ What does that mean for a Golden Circle worker? It means for a Golden Circle worker $45 over four years—that is it. Mind you, if you are the boss of Golden Circle and you are earning $100,000, you will get $180 from Labor. This co-contribution is about rewarding effort. It is about rewarding people for putting money into their retirement. It is about building better retirement incomes for Australians—and it is opposed by the Labor Party.

answer.para: The member for Paterson has 3,500 electors who took up the co-contribution. The member for Tangney has 4,400. But what is the member for Ballarat going to be saying at the next election? Is she going to be holding up the Labor Party document to the 4,400 workers out there who took up the co-contribution, saying, ‘You can’t have it’? Remember the member for Rankin? He has a lot to say these days. Well, 6,500 of his voters actually took up the Howard government’s co-contribution. And now it is even better: put a dollar in, get $1.50—make a difference to your own retirement and get the support incentives of the Howard government.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. I refer again to today’s report by the respected NATSEM institute. In particular, I refer the minister to the report’s findings that the Howard government will take back as much as 75c of every dollar that people with a disability earn. Why does the minister find it acceptable for people with a disability to work for an effective return of $2.27 an hour? Why do the Howard government’s proposed welfare changes make it less worth while to move from welfare to work than it is now? Why doesn’t the government at least listen to its own backbench when the member for Pearce says:

quote.para: I am concerned that people are going to lose income support when they move back into the work force. They are on such a small amount of income now.

talk.start.para: —I call the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would be aware, the minister is not required to comment on backbench colleagues. The question is otherwise in order.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: —Can I repeat for the benefit of the member for Jagajaga that under these new arrangements a person who is on Newstart and working the minimum of 15 hours a week would effectively have in their pocket at the end of the week some $382.25. That compares to a person on the disability support pension without work who has $290.05 a week. If the member for Jagajaga could simply subtract one from the other, she would find out that there is a difference—an advantage—of some $90 between those two figures.

answer.para: As for the suggestion that somehow this person is effectively earning only $2.27 an hour, the reality is that a person who works 15 hours and receives Newstart allowance in addition to what they are earning effectively puts in their pocket, at the end of the week, somewhere in the order of $24 or $25 an hour. The principle which underlies this is very simple. We in the government believe that if a person is capable of working 15 hours or more a week they should do so. I believe that the overwhelming majority of Australians also believe that. We have a generous safety net in place for people who are incapable of working 15 hours a week. That safety net remains. People will still be on the disability support pension if they cannot work for 15 hours a week, but there is some expectation that somebody who is capable of working 15, 20 or 25 hours a week will contribute to their own wellbeing.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr Speaker, you would be aware that your predecessor initiated a recommendation for changes to second reading speeches which was endorsed by the Procedure Committee but which has not yet been responded to by the government. Would you indicate to all members now or at a later date whether or not you support the changes sought to the standing orders by your predecessor?
—I thank the Chief Opposition Whip. I will have a close look at that recommendation and report back accordingly.

—Yesterday I was asked a question about the standard of dress acceptable in the House. As was the case with many of my predecessors, I do not intend to be inflexible or prescriptive on this matter. In 1999 the former Speaker, the Hon. Neil Andrew, pointed to the significance and role of this unique institution and the expectation on the part of electors that we, as members, maintain high standards in carrying out our responsibilities and in our conduct in this place. The accepted practice is that members have chosen to dress in a formal manner in keeping with business and professional standards. This includes trousers, jacket, collar and tie for men and a similar standard of formality for women.

speech.para: I would also like to make the point that these standards apply equally to officers and staff occupying the advisers boxes, members of the press gallery and guests in the distinguished visitors gallery. As already mentioned, I do not propose to apply these standards rigidly. However, while I accept that members hurrying to attend a division or quorum will sometimes arrive without a jacket or tie, it is not in keeping with the dignity of the House for members to arrive in casual or sports wear. I look forward to the cooperation of all members in fulfilling their obligation to maintain the dignity of the House through their standard of dress and their conduct during proceedings.

motionnospeech.name: Mr ABBOTT
motionnospeech.inline: —Documents are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the documents will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.

talk.start.para: —I have received letters from the honourable member for Hunter and the honourable member for New England proposing that definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by standing order 46(d), I have selected the matter which, in my opinion, is the most urgent and important—that is, that proposed by the honourable member for Hunter, namely:

quote.para: The failure of the Government to recognise and address the adverse impact of high fuel prices on Australian motorists.

subdebate.1.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —I note for the Hansard record that the Treasurer has slipped out of the chamber, which prompts me to make the point that he thinks this debate is beneath him. He thinks he has more important things to be doing, despite the fact that Australian families are facing crippling fuel costs and are hurting. The electorate find the Treasurer’s smugness disconcerting, his arrogance offensive and his ignorance on petrol prices scary. He demonstrated that ignorance in this House yesterday when, in response to my question, he did not even go to the question of refinery pricing and the huge gap opening up between world oil prices and refinery prices. I note that he corrected that today on some advice overnight, but his answer yesterday demonstrated clearly his failure to understand and properly grasp this issue and the impact it is having on Australian families. The Treasurer has failed two tests today. The first test was to give a serious, sensible and constructive answer to the question I posed to him during question time. The second test was to stay in here for this most important debate on the impact that petrol prices are having on Australian families. Of course, he failed both tests.

speech.para: I am disappointed that the Treasurer has left us. I am disappointed not for us but for him, because we have some very good advice for the Treasurer this afternoon. The Treasurer says that he feels that he already leads the country in a sense—he already leads the country in an economic sense. This is an economic issue. This was a good opportunity for the Treasurer to show some leadership. We are prepared to give him some advice on leadership. We are happy to tell him that he should jettison the Prime Minister’s contention that the government can do nothing about petrol prices. He should forget about that. Instead, he should acknowledge the pain being imposed on Australian families. He should acknowledge that families are now facing fuel bills of up to $200 a week and, in addition, that they are facing higher prices on the goods they buy due to the transport and additional costs imposed on all sorts of goods and services as a result of rising fuel prices.

I note that just today, coming out of the IMF report that the Treasurer was quoting during question time, the IMF has predicted that Australia’s inflation rate is now likely to go to three per cent as a result of these high oil prices. That has ramifications and implications for interest rates and for mortgage interest rates in this country. I also note that today JP Morgan has estimated that for the average household the 20 per cent rise in petrol prices over the past six weeks is roughly equivalent to a quarter of one per cent increase in interest rates. So the government, already putting pressure on Australian families by not introducing fair and equitable tax cuts and putting extra pressure on them through a range of higher costs including private health insurance, is now not prepared to move on this very important issue.

I said I had some advice for the Treasurer. In fact, I have a five-point plan for the Treasurer today. He says he can do nothing, but I have a five-point plan which he could embrace immediately and put into effect in most circumstances in a very short time. The first point, and one of the most important, is that he should apologise for his broken promise that the GST would not cause petrol prices to rise. We all remember that period around 1999-2000 when the Treasurer said, ‘Don’t worry, the GST will not cause petrol prices to rise because we are going to reduce the excise by 7c.’ He established what was called a strike rate. He said that, if you take 7c off 70c—the arithmetic is pretty easy—and put 10 per cent back on, you end up back at the same price. But, if you take a price of $1.30—I am giving him a bit of latitude here—which is below the current price, and take off 7c and put 10 per cent back on, you end up with $1.35. So the promise that the GST would not cause petrol prices to rise has been well and truly broken and the Treasurer should come in here today and apologise.

The second thing he can do, as we have been calling upon him to do for weeks, is to ask the ACCC to conduct an inquiry into fuel prices and, in particular, refinery margins. The Daily Telegraph screamed the headline ‘The big petrol rip-off’. That was sufficient for the Chairman of the ACCC to say that there was something funny going on with refinery margins. But it was not sufficient for the Treasurer, who obviously does not understand this graph that shows a huge gap opening up between oil prices and petrol prices. This shows that this is not just about oil prices; this is about oil companies gouging profits inappropriately. The government have their hands in the trousers of the Australian community. The combined effect of that is devastating on Australian families.

The Treasurer said yesterday that the ACCC could hold an inquiry any time it liked. Of course it can but, for whatever reason, the Chairman of the ACCC has not seen fit to do so. I call upon the Treasurer to direct him to do so. As I indicated during question time, the Treasurer has the absolute right to do that. Both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister like to hang their hats on the fact that we have had 100 or so inquiries into petrol already—in fact, I exaggerated, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be surprised to hear. The Prime Minister claimed that there have been 44 major inquires into petrol, but the government was very clever in choosing the base year. You may have noted that the Prime Minister likes to go back to 1983, some 22 years ago. Here is the more important point. How many inquiries do you think we have had since 1996, in the almost 10 years that the Howard government has been in office? The Prime Minister claims that there have been 44 inquiries since 1983, but how many do you think there have been in the last nine years? There has been one major inquiry in 10 years. I will concede that there were two other minor inquiries by the ACCC—one on declaration and one on inconsistency between domestic and international prices—but they were very narrowly confined inquiries. The major inquiry I am talking about, the Trebeck inquiry, was into fuel taxation only. It did not in any sense canvass the issues we are dealing with here today of abuse of market power and price gouging. That is the second thing the Treasurer can do today: insist that the ACCC undertake an inquiry into what is happening in refining margins in particular and petrol and fuel prices generally.

Third, the Treasurer can do something about section 46 of the Trade Practices Act. It is well known that section 46 of the Trade Practices Act has been rendered inefficient and ineffective because of a number of Federal Court and High Court cases. For example, in the Safeway case the concept of take advantage was brought into question. In the Rural Press case the concept of abusing market power in another market was brought into question. In the Boral case the very concept of market power was brought into question. The ACCC has effectively given up taking cases under section 46 of the Trade Practices Act because it knows it has now been rendered ineffective. We had a Senate inquiry into this issue and a report was tabled in March 2004 making some sensible recommendations for reform of the Trade Practices Act, but we have heard nothing from this government.

The fourth thing the Treasurer can do today is to have another look at the regulatory structure which controls the petroleum industry. This is a structure that is now 25 years old. In 1980 Malcolm Fraser decided it was time to put a brake on the power of the major oil companies. To do so he introduced two acts: the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act. But back then there were nine major oil companies and some 20,000 service stations around this country. Today there are just four major oil companies and some 7,000 service stations. More to the point, this is a regulatory structure that has been effectively circumvented by the major oil companies by a range of invented instruments, the least of them not being the concept of the multisite franchise. But, even worse, this is a regulatory regime that does not cover the new entrants to the market, Coles and Woolworths, and as a result does not cover 50 per cent by volume of the market. What sort of a regulatory regime does not cover 50 per cent of the market or two of the biggest players? The government has had nine years to sort this out. It has been talking about an oil code. The opposition is happy to talk about the repeal of the franchise and sites acts if it can come up with a decent oil code and get some agreement between the major players in the market, but the government is simply not capable of doing it. If it were capable of doing it, in combination with improvements to section 46, petrol prices for motorists would fall.

We are talking about a fuel industry in which we rely too heavily on imports. We are now approaching 60 per cent oil import dependency and we are now importing 25 per cent of our refined product—in other words, petrol. We are increasingly being exposed to the whims of OPEC and difficulties in the Middle East and elsewhere, and the government has no plan whatsoever.

That takes me to my fifth point: the government has no plan to diversify our fuel mix in this country. We are becoming increasingly dependent on imports, yet at the same time we have enormous opportunities here in Australia to advance the biofuels market, including ethanol, which has three positive effects: it is good environmentally, it creates jobs in regional Australia and—potentially more important—it maintains the competitiveness of the independent sector because there is no tax on ethanol. So, if the independents can put some ethanol in their mix because it is cheaper, they can compete with the power of those major oil companies.

More particularly, we have 150 trillion cubic feet of natural gas in this country that today, using current technology, could be used and transformed into liquid diesel fuels—fuel that will go straight into existing diesel engines without any modification whatsoever. While ever the price of oil is greater than $US20 per barrel, this is commercially viable. But do we see any plan from this government? No, we do not. The government is happy to sit back and let the oil companies have their hand. It is happy for Australia to become the LNG hub of the world while Qatar in the Middle East becomes the value added gas to liquids hub of the world. This is to Australia’s great disadvantage. We are taking the gas out of the ground, we are selling it off at bargain basement prices and, when the time comes that we will require it, the major oil companies will say: ‘Sorry, all the easier and cheaper to win stuff is already gone; we have exported that. You are going to have to pay through the nose for the harder to get stuff.’ That is what will happen in this country, and it is an absolute disgrace that this government has no plan to transform that gas into diesel liquid fuels, just as it has no real plan for ethanol. It is a friend to ethanol producers but not a friend to ethanol, and it needs a plan. So that is the fifth area of advice I have for the Treasurer.

I made the point that the Daily Telegraph has directly accused the oil majors of profit gouging. The Chairman of the ACCC has said, ‘Something funny is going on but the government refuses to act.’ During question time today the Treasurer in his smugness said, ‘What is the opposition going on about? Don’t you know petrol prices are high all around the world?’ Of course we do, and we know the causes of that, and that is why it is more important that the government act. But Gordon Brown is acting—and guess what? He has got a five-point plan. I quote from the London Times today:

quote.para: Gordon Brown will table an emergency international plan today to bring down oil prices. He will tell the TUC conference in Brighton today that he has a five-point plan.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr BROUGH

talk.start.para: —As every motorist and as every pensioner knows, the price of fuel at the pump today is of grave concern to every Australian—not just the cost when you put the fuel in your motor vehicle but the cost that flows through to everything we purchase. Being such a large country and such a decentralised country, we are so dependent upon transport. In the production cycle, fuel is a major contributor to cost. What is happening around the world today, not just in Australia, is of grave concern to many economies and many governments because it will impact upon the production cycle and the cost of living which, ultimately, flows through to potentially inflation and associated economic activity.

speech.para: There is no quick fix for the problem of major oil prices. What we have seen here today is typical cheapjack political opportunism from the member for Hunter—that is all it is. If the Labor Party were sincere in their belief, if they really believed that they could wave a magic wand and somehow remove the pain from the Australian economy—not just from the motorist but from the entire economy—then they would have done so. Who condemns the Labor Party for their actions? It is not the Prime Minister, it is not the Treasurer—it is one of their own. Craig Emerson, ALP federal member for Rankin in Queensland, wrote in the Age newspaper on 20 July, only a couple of months ago:

quote.para: Australia’s record petrol prices have one cause and one cause only—high world oil prices.

speech.para: He asks this rhetorical question:

quote.para: But isn’t the Government reaping a revenue windfall from soaring oil prices that it could hand back to motorists?

speech.para: That is the common belief. In years gone by, before the coalition government stopped fuel excise being indexed every six months, the federal government continued to take a windfall from excise. But the Howard government froze excise and reduced the price of fuel by over 6c for Australian motorists. So no, the federal government does not pick up one red cent extra when the price of a barrel of crude goes up because our excise is a flat rate. It does not matter if fuel is being sold for 90c a litre or $1.30 a litre: the fact is that the excise collected by the federal government remains the same. The GST goes up, obviously, but where does the GST go? Every last cent of it goes to the state governments. So, when the member for Rankin, Craig Emerson, writing this article asks this rhetorical question about a windfall, he says:

quote.para: It used to, but not any more.

speech.para: Has this man any credibility beyond sitting on the back bench? I went back and had a look at his CV to see whether he had any credibility. He is a doctor of economics. He was an economic analyst with the United Nations from 1978 to 1980, an economic adviser, a former shadow minister for resources—a man of some credibility in this field. He makes a lie of the political cheapjack opportunism of the member for Hunter, who comes in here ranting and raving, trying to put up an argument to make the Labor Party credible on an issue that is painful to the world—not just to Australians. The member for Rankin goes on in the same article:

quote.para: There’s no revenue windfall from petrol excise when world oil prices go up.

speech.para: As he says, the states get a bit of a windfall from GST—about $32 million. But he puts an interesting spin on this, and he is absolutely correct. The member for Hunter said that the rising price of petrol could flow into inflation. We are very much aware of that. What happens when it flows into inflation? The CPI goes up. What is indexed to the CPI? Pensions—disability pensions and age pensions—are indexed to the CPI. Therefore, the cost to government goes up. So there is no windfall to the Howard government—quite the contrary.

The member for Hunter went on to talk about competition. Can I read to members what the ACCC said in a press release dated 12 September, yesterday? There is no point mincing words. The member for Hunter likes to play fast and loose with words. These are the facts:

quote.para: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has confirmed that it is closely monitoring developments in petrol prices, both in Australia and overseas. Recently there have been significant increases, both in the level of petrol prices in Australia and also in the difference between petrol prices and crude oil prices. This phenomenon has occurred not only in Australia but also internationally. It is primarily a result of a shortage in the supply of refined product in the US Gulf following Hurricane Katrina—

speech.para: which may have missed the attention of the honourable member for Hunter—

quote.para: and the Chinese government’s recent decision to take steps to halt the exports of petrol because of an acute shortage of fuel in several of China’s provinces.

speech.para: The ACCC—the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission—does not have any evidence that increases in current domestic petrol prices are related to any anti-competitive conduct. If evidence of such conduct is discovered, the ACCC will immediately investigate.

We talk about competition. A thing called shopper dockets may have escaped the member for Hunter. There is pressure on retailers to drive down the price of petrol. The discounts of 4c and 8c a litre—some mortgage originators, I believe, are even offering discounts of 50c a litre—show the enormous downward pressure, as much as can be achieved, at the petrol pump. That is not anti-competitive; that is competition working at its best, and it is giving some relief to Australian motorists.

Let us compare Australia’s circumstances to international circumstances. The following prices are in US dollars: Australia has petrol at about 71.7c a litre; Austria, $1.15; Belgium, $1.41; the Czech Republic, just over $1; Denmark, $1.39; Germany, $1.38; and Greece, over $1. Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Korea, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and even New Zealand are more expensive than Australia for petrol. Yes, this issue is hurting Australian motorists and, yes, the Labor Party is looking for something to hang its hat on, but trying to make an issue in here of rising petrol prices, which is a phenomenon striking the world because of natural disasters and because of the Chinese economy and its government’s decisions, is nothing more than cheapjack opportunism. And that is what the member for Hunter is renowned for in this place.

Let us go to what Labor did in government. In 1993, when the Labor Party occupied the treasury bench, they brought down a deficit of $17 billion and inflicted upon the Australian public a further increase in the fuel excise. That was over and above the normal six-monthly indexation introduced by a Labor government and stopped by a coalition government. They said this:

quote.para: I now move to the main aspects—

speech.para: this is the budget speech—

quote.para: of the measures, full details of which are provided in supporting documents.

speech.para: And weren’t they ever!

quote.para: Excise on petroleum products will rise by 3c a litre from tonight …

speech.para: That has not happened under a coalition government. What has happened under a coalition government is a reduction in excise, a freezing of excise:

quote.para: and a further 2c a litre a year later.

talk.start.para: Mr Martin Ferguson interjecting—
(Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member for Batman will cease interjecting.

—That is an additional 5c a litre impost of excise on every Australian motorist, right through the production chain, right through the transport chain, because the Labor Party could not manage the economy. Because the economy was going backwards jobs were almost nonexistent, we were at nearly 10 per cent unemployment and interest rates were through the roof, and their answer was to slug the motorist. It was the coalition government that removed excise, that froze excise. If we had not done that, today excise would have been 52c a litre and there would have been more pain to Australian motorists, but that is not the case.

speech.para: There are many things that the coalition government has done to assist in driving down the prices of fuel. For instance, there is terminal gate pricing—the government has developed a draft oil code which details a set of national terminal gate pricing principles; collective bargaining—currently the TPA provides for businesses to seek collective bargaining so that the major companies cannot just have it on their own; strengthening section 46 and banning predatory pricing—providing cease and desist powers to the ACCC. These are the very sorts of things that the Labor Party come in here harking about. The ACCC do not need a direction from the Treasurer. They have the power to act, and in fact they have in the past acted. They have had parts of the petroleum industry in the courts for having colluded. So they do act as much as they possibly can. Let us go to the inquiries. There were 45 inquiries, so the Labor Party talk about—

talk.start.para: —I thought it was 44.

—You are going to quibble over one—44 inquiries? No, in fact it was 45 inquiries so there you go; you have lost track. There have been 45 inquiries. At the same time that the Labor Party was deliberately of its own action collecting more taxes from the Australian public through increases to excises, 5c between 1993 and 1994, and on top of that the indexation every six months, they had inquiries in their own hands. They had an inquiry into petroleum product prices in December 1989. So four years earlier they were out there telling the public, just before an election, no doubt, ‘We’re worried about petrol prices and we’re going to have another inquiry’—No. 37, 38 or 39. That is typical of what Labor governments do. In the same way we have seen the state Labor governments putting up stamp duty on insurances recently. State Labor governments, federal Labor governments—it does not matter where they come from, the colour is always the same: they stand for higher taxes, and the law they have implemented shows that unequivocally.

speech.para: They had another inquiry: the ‘national inquiry into petroleum product prices’ in November 1990. So there was one in 1989, but that was not good enough so 12 months later they had another one. Yet three years later the Labor Party, through their own actions, put a direct impost onto Australians and then wanted to continue to index it. Yet today they are in here again, saying that something should be done about petrol pricing.

The coalition say that the best thing we can do is to provide incentives to people to have jobs, to provide lower taxes for them, to freeze their excises and to drive those things down that have an impost on them so that the whole of the economy can benefit.
