On top of that the coalition also introduced major improvements to the diesel fuel rebate, because this is not just about petrol; this is about the whole cost of petroleum products—on road, off road. So it meant that the cost of delivering products and that the price throughout the production cycle of business were driven down.

But we have not finished there, because we have already announced to the Australian public that there will be over $1.5 billion worth of additional relief, as we go forward, in the form of diesel fuel, so that we can have parity between the different products and so that the cost of business will be reduced. When you reduce the cost to business, it means that the end user, the consumer, benefits, not just at the petrol pump but at the grocery checkout counter, and everywhere else in that cycle.

So, once again, we have come into this place for a matter of public importance. We had the member for Rankin, a person who is credible on this issue, who blows the Labor Party, his own party that he sits on the backbench for—I do not know how he managed to stand today when he was asked in good faith to stand to support this, when he himself has said:

quote.para: So no, there are no magic solutions to high petrol prices. It might seem clever to pretend there are, but the Australian people are smarter than that.

speech.para: They are smarter than that. It is clear, though, that the brains in the tactics committee of the Labor Party are not smarter than that. Trying to use this issue to give themselves some momentum, when they are quite clearly as flat as a tack, going nowhere, leaderless and with no reasonable policy initiatives, they rely on cheapjack political opportunism. Listen to the member for Rankin: he is right. There are no easy issues and answers to this, but you can depend upon one thing: the coalition will continue to deliver to the Australian public in the best possible way. We will do all we can to deliver the strong economy and jobs that Australians deserve. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The member for Longman has just aptly demonstrated the point of this MPI. The government come in here and say, ‘We can do absolutely nothing.’ Hiding behind a hurricane, ‘We’re not responsible at all for petrol pricing; it’s the crude oil. We’re sitting here and there is absolutely nothing we can do,’ they claim. In fact there are things that they can do. The price of fuel is hitting the nation hard. We are seeing prices at a $1.33 in Sydney, with predictions by motorist organisations that it will hit $1.45. The price of fuel is $1.40 in my own district and that of the member for Bendigo just last week.
—Have you spoken to Steve Bracks? He can do what Peter Beattie has done.
(Mr Jenkins)—Order! The parliamentary secretary!

—Fuel prices are what families around Australia are talking about. It is consuming their household budgets at an absolutely alarming rate. Unfortunately, for families that is all the Howard government has done in relation to the spiralling cost of petrol—talk. This is despite the alarming rise in fuel prices in the past few weeks alone. Each time the price rises families are facing tough choices, having to cut back on other expenses and on their daily activities.

speech.para: In the midst of all this, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have been virtually absent from the debate. They have been keeping their heads down, claiming that it is not their responsibility and that the price triggers are well beyond their control. That is not true. Yesterday during question time the Treasurer took this further by laughing off families’ concerns and dismissing a legitimate question about why there is such an enormous variance between the price of crude oil and the price of unleaded petrol and why that variance is getting bigger. The Treasurer cannot have it both ways. If it is all about the price of crude oil, as he argues, then the price of petrol should be much lower than it is today. The Treasurer’s response merely epitomises this government’s do-nothing approach. This government’s form is to act on something only when it becomes a political problem for them, not when it becomes a problem for Australian families.

Action on petrol pricing is long overdue, which demonstrates how out of touch this government is with ordinary Australian families. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics household expenditure survey, every 1c per litre increase in the price of petrol costs the average family 34c per week and the average couple with two dependent children 46c per week. The impact on families, especially those living in regional Australia, is absolutely enormous. Consider that 35.4 per cent of all families are struggling just to make ends meet, according to the ING Direct survey. How are these families managing to cope with petrol prices of $1.40 a litre? The reality is that many of them are not. For an average family with one car, the price increases have added at least $11 to the weekly household budget. That is based on the distance an average person drives in a week, which is around 293 kilometres. The figure is even higher when you consider that many families are running more than one car and that 293 kilometres per week is only the average.

This is bad enough, but if you live in regional Australia it gets even worse. In my own district around 465 people drive from Ballarat to Melbourne every day for work. In the last seven weeks alone, these people have had to fork out an extra $40,000 in fuel. When you add people from Ballarat who travel to Geelong each day—students going to Deakin University and commuters going to work—the figure over the past seven weeks alone is $51,000. The government is so focused on the big end of town that it has taken its eye off the ball as to what is happening to regional economies.

The price of petrol is already having an effect on regional economies like my own. The increased cost of freight is causing difficulty for our manufacturers, who are already under pressure. Regional tourism is suffering due to a decrease in the number of day trippers from Melbourne. Companies are thinking twice about locating in regional areas, because their freight costs are too high. The cost of groceries is going up. You only have to look at the media attention to realise what a massive issue this is for Australian families. At the moment it would be fair to say it is their No. 1 concern. So where is the government on this issue? Where is the self-anointed best friend of ordinary Australian families? What do those families get? They get a do-nothing response from an out-of-touch government.

While the Prime Minister is in New York and the petrol price skyrockets, the government sits on its hands. Where is the leadership? There has been nothing from the PM and nothing from the Treasurer as the responsible minister. They do not have a plan; they do not have a clue. The Treasurer claims that he is already in some way leading this country. How about you stop talking about what a great leader you are and actually get off your backside and do something? His statements to date on this issue show a distinct lack of leadership. How is it leadership to wring your hands like Uriah Heep and say there is nothing you can do about the price of petrol when you know there is? How is it leadership to ignore the plight of ordinary working families as their household budgets become higher each week? The government is out of touch with ordinary working families.

The truth of the matter is that there are things that the Treasurer could do. The Treasurer could apologise for the GST on fuel. He made a promise that the cost of petrol would not go up with the imposition of the GST—a promise that he has not been able to keep. It has gone up. Sorry is only a little word, but it takes a big man to say it. How about the Treasurer shows us what a big man he is. After saying sorry, the Treasurer could apply the competition blowtorch to the industry by strengthening the Trade Practices Act to prevent abuse of market power.

Furthermore, the Treasurer could have the ACCC investigate petrol prices and report every six months on price movements, particularly in regional Australia. The Treasurer could modernise the 25-year-old regulatory regime for the petrol sector to promote competition and protect independent service station operators and franchisees. The Treasurer could work to reduce our reliance on imported fuel by growing a gas based fuel industry. The Treasurer could provide a real future for the biofuels industry by providing a government fleet market for ethanol blends to set an example and help to grow the industry. There is plenty that the Treasurer could do.

However, yesterday, when we called for an ACCC inquiry to detail what can be done to bring petrol prices under control, the government said, ‘Another inquiry is the last thing we need. We don’t want to do anything about this.’ As we just heard again from the member for Longman, the government has stated that we have already had 44 inquiries into petrol pricing. Like most things this government says, that is only half the truth. Since 1996 there have only been three such inquiries and only one of them has been a major inquiry into fuel pricing. The Howard government cannot even be bothered to look at the possibility that something can be done.

Cracking down on the abuse of market power and making the market truly competitive is central to Labor’s approach. This can only be done by giving the ACCC more teeth. The government claims that everything is okay and that the ACCC already has the power. I want to mention a case that the minister referred to, where the ACCC did take petroleum companies to court under section 45 of the Trade Practices Act. The case was based on petroleum companies in my electorate. What emerged in that case—and most people do not know about this—is that for two years Ballarat people knew there was a problem. For two years Ballarat residents and former politicians were calling for the ACCC to do something about it. They were calling the government and asking that something be done.

We knew there was a problem in Ballarat. And what it took was an independent petrol retailer, a whistleblower, to come out and provide some evidence. If the ACCC had been regularly monitoring petrol prices, it would have had evidence to bring this case much earlier and Ballarat residents would not have had to pay the petrol prices we did. It is all right to say the ACCC has the power; this case demonstrated that it did not.

This can only be done if we give the ACCC more teeth, and that is exactly the point that Labor has made in this MPI. We need to encourage more refining capacity by ensuring that the major players do not abuse their market power with anticompetitive behaviour such as predatory pricing. In essence, what Labor is calling for, and what the Howard government is refusing to even consider, is modernising the 25-year-old regulatory regime for the petrol sector to promote competition and protect independent service station operators and franchisees.

talk.start.para: Mr Hunt interjecting—

—Labor’s reforms are practical. At the very least the Australian motoring public deserve to know that they have a government who is batting for them rather than sitting on its hands. They deserve to know that there is someone in there ensuring that the ACCC keeps the pressure on to prevent the price gouging that goes on and to at least put a counterweight in the system against the bad habits the oil companies have developed around weekends. However, John Howard and Peter Costello maintain nothing can be done. The only excuse the Howard government has for not acting on this issue is either complacency or arrogance. Australian motorists deserve better than this government. (Time expired)
(Mr Jenkins)—Before I call the member for Canning, the member for Fraser has a point of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point or order. I did not want to interrupt the member for Ballarat, but during that speech we had continuous interjections from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, the member for Flinders. The parliamentary secretary is neither in his chair not at the table. He is not entitled to interject from where he is. I ask you to draw this to his attention.
—The Premier should also put that on—

—Order! The parliamentary secretary will cease interjecting! I say to the honourable member for Fraser that the chair was in a little bit of difficulty in constraining the parliamentary secretary given the behaviour of the honourable members for Hunter, Batman and others during the speech by the minister. I am sure that all members in the chamber understand the requirements of the standing orders, but in this robust debating chamber some allowances are made.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Your predecessors have ruled that parliamentary secretaries either speak from their place in the chamber or, whilst acting as ministers, speak from the dispatch box. You would pull up any other honourable member who was outside of their place and who was interjecting. The same rules should apply to the parliamentary secretary.
—The Chief Opposition Whip will resume his seat. If he wants to see a strict—
—Application.

—Thank you, the member for Gorton—application of the standing orders, he will see it. But I think that in the context of the good-natured way in which this debate has up until this stage been conducted, I do not see that the chair should act in that way. If there are points to be made, they could be made in better ways.

—I am pleased to speak on this MPI today in relation to petrol pricing. I concur with all speakers at this stage by saying that the price of fuel in Australia is extremely high, at record levels, and it is hurting people, it is hurting families and it is hurting the economy. Having said that, I must point out that, as the member for Longman and the Assistant Treasurer has pointed out, the member for Hunter, having raised this issue, is demonstrating why he is known as an opportunistic and cynical member of parliament. Unlike him and unlike the Labor Party, most Australians know that the current price of fuel is not something that is within the control of the Australian government. As the member for Rankin has pointed out, it is totally out of the hands of any government in the world to regulate and to suppress prices, because it is a world phenomenon driven by a number of factors.

speech.para: Petrol prices are said to be too high in Australia. I point out that Australia is actually one of the lower taxing fuel countries in the world. In fact, on OECD figures, Australia is seen as the fourth lowest fuel taxing country in the world. I repeat that: it is the fourth lowest. The lowest is the United States, the second lowest is Mexico, the third lowest is Canada, then comes Australia and then comes New Zealand. But amongst those countries, in 29th place—at a very high level—is the Netherlands, which taxes fuel at 69.2 per cent, just to put it into context. So as much as fuel prices are high, as much as the opposition wishes to lay this glove on the Australian government, it is not a fact. It is not supported by any economic data or any credible economic commentator. The fact is the Labor Party in this place is scratching around for an issue and, unfortunately, they can find no traction anywhere else. As a result, they cynically find an issue which is hurting the mums and dads of Australia and the businesses of Australia, because they know if you say something long enough and loud enough, people will believe it.

Their argument is not supported by the facts. The fact is Australia has a free market for crude oil and refined petroleum products. This includes the freedom to import and export crude oil and refined products. Consequently, Australian prices for crude oil and refined products are set on world markets. I reconfirm: prices are set on world markets. For example, if petrol or diesel prices in Australia were lower than those prevailing overseas, Australian refineries would export these products. The result would be to drive Australian prices higher, until they equalled international prices. This disallows transport and handling costs. Conversely, if prices in Australia were higher than overseas prices, imported products would drive the prices down in Australia. In other words: ex-refinery prices tend towards equalisation in Australia and the rest of the world.

I do not know if it has actually gelled with people, but the fact is that Australia does produce some crude oil. However, if we were to sell that in a free market—which was deregulated by the Labor Party back in about 1988, I believe—we would then be sucking in higher priced fuel to Australia. If we were selling it into a low-cost market in Australia—in other words, artificially deflating or suppressing the price—then, in an internationally competitive environment, in would come other countries, because they could, selling fuel into Australia. This competition would then drive up the price in Australia. It also has the reverse effect. If there were lower prices overseas and Australia could sell its fuel into those markets, where we could get a better deal, we would. So there is an equalisation component.

There is an excerpt from an ACCC report which describes how petrol prices are determined in Australia. Although the report is dated, the essential facts still remain correct. It states that ‘the main causes of changes in fuel prices in Australia are international prices and the exchange rate between the Australian and US dollars, excise and taxes, and the level of discounting or margin support provided by oil companies’. To that end, today in Sydney the price of fuel is $1.31. I want to compare this price with the Shell Sydney 28-day average price, which is $1.25. In my electorate of Canning, which cuts across 4,500 square kilometres, the price of fuel today in various fuel stations—which I was able to gauge before I came here—was as follows. At a place called Karragullen, coincidentally the price is $1.31.5—about the same as in Sydney—in Mandurah it is $1.30.9; in Kelmscott, near my office, it is $1.31.9; in Halls Head it is $1.30.9; and in Canning Vale it is $1.28.6. Basically, there is a 3.3c variation.

What needs to be pointed out is the fact that the Labor Party’s argument about the government take on taxes is untrue and disingenuous. It is not borne out by the facts when we look at today’s price in Sydney and break it down into the components of who pays what and what it costs, and look at it against the Shell 28-day average price. For example, on today’s price of $1.31 the product cost is 58 per cent, or 76c. On the average price it is 55 per cent, or 69c. When we come to the excise, we know that remains the same—it is 38.1c, and that remains a constant. If the price of fuel goes up, it decreases the percentage slightly. However, the fixed price of GST on both days is nine per cent. On today’s price in Sydney that works out to be 12c. On the 28-day average price it is 11.4c.

It has been pointed out that the government gets a fixed amount of 38c—it is a volumetric measure. The states get the GST windfall. Every cent of this GST, increased by a rise in the price, goes to the states. I have not heard Mr Gallop in Western Australia talking about reducing the price at all. The Labor Party here have a six-point plan and they tell us that Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer in the UK, has a five-point plan—they have got all these different point plans—but at the end of the day none of them actually work in any way. They are just rhetoric. There are no practical measures in them and they just do not work at all.

Let me point out to the honourable member opposite that the people who get dudded in this whole exercise, besides the consumer, are the operators of fuel stations. As the price goes up their margin goes down. For example, on today’s inflated price of Shell petrol per litre in Sydney, they only get four per cent. Yet on the 28-day average price—where the price was $1.25 compared to $1.31, as I said—they get six per cent. So who is getting dudded around here? The consumer and the operators.

It has been pointed out by Graeme Samuel of the ACCC that one of the factors that are driving up the price of fuel is the production cost. He has quoted the fact that the production cost per litre has gone up by 7c, to 17c. So there appears to be some method of profiteering by the fuel companies in this exercise, which Samuel seems to believe is because we hub out of Singapore on these issues. We do not control the Singapore government or the Singapore free market; we are just a victim of them. As a result we need to understand what drives these things. When we have a shortage of fuel we know that sometimes there is an upside to it. We need to be looking at things like biofuels and ethanol. I support both the member for Kalgoorlie and the member for O’Connor. In the US at the moment, hydrogen cars are on the go. I recommend that we move towards a hydrogen economy as well. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—The discussion is now concluded.

debateinfo.title: BUILDING AND CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY IMPROVEMENT (CONSEQUENTIAL AND TRANSITIONAL) BILL 2005

cognateinfo.title: BUILDING AND CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY IMPROVEMENT BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Message from the Administrator reported informing the House of assent to the bills.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I know this is out of order.
(Mr Jenkins)—The member for Kennedy, on indulgence.
—I came in late on the last speech and I wanted to get up and speak on it but the speaker had sat down. I ask your indulgence to speak on the MPI now.
—As I indicated, given the rhythm of the day, I had declared that the discussion had concluded.
—I was in the House at the time, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—But you were not quite in your place trying to get the call. I had been fairly lenient in seeing if anybody else was to arrive.
Mr Fitzgibbon interjecting—
—I thank the honourable member for Hunter. I understand that.
—I think you’d have liked what I’d have said.
—The chair, whilst in the chair, has no views on that matter.

subdebate.2.para: Message received from the Senate informing the House that Senator Carol Brown has been appointed a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the 16th report for 2005 of the committee relating to the redevelopment of Willis Island meteorological office, Coral Sea.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

talk.start.para: —by leave—On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the committee’s 16th report. The proposed work is intended to replace ageing and dysfunctional facilities on Willis Island to enable the Bureau of Meteorology to continue its important monitoring and research work. The estimated cost of the proposed works is $7 million. Most of the current facilities on the island were constructed in either 1950 or 1968 and are nearing the end of, or have already exceeded, their useful economic life.

speech.para: Specifically, the bureau has identified a need for redeveloping the facilities, based on substantial damage to the structure of existing facilities, with some areas no longer able to be made safe for operational use; health and safety hazards for station staff, visitors and maintenance personnel as a result of the presence of asbestos and ageing service infrastructure; the considerable cost of maintaining the existing facility in such a harsh and remote location; and the need to enhance the station’s desirability as a staff posting. In order to address these deficiencies, the bureau proposes to demolish and remove existing redundant buildings and to construct new accommodation, office and storage facilities and to upgrade utilities and services. The resulting facility will support a four-person deployment and allow for a six-monthly resupply and staff changeover period, during which the facilities will be required to accommodate a further 15 persons for about three days.

At the public hearing into the proposed work, the committee expressed concern that the bureau had contravened the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969 by undertaking documentation and design work prior to parliamentary approval of the project. While the committee accepts the bureau’s contention that some funds had to be spent to determine the viability of the project, it did not believe that the bureau was justified in proceeding to tender before referring the work to the committee. The bureau explained that this had been the result of a misunderstanding as to when the work should be referred. The chair observed that the act is very clear on this point and emphasised the problems caused by agencies failing to refer relevant works to the committee in a timely manner. In this instance, as a consequence of the delayed referral, the bureau will be unable to complete its proposed six-month construction schedule prior to the summer cyclone season, as originally hoped.

The committee explored the requirement for the ongoing retention of the Willis Island meteorological station and the alternative solutions were considered. The committee was assured that the bureau had considered both the automation of the station and a wet season only staffing option but had concluded that only the year-round, fully staffed observations and monitoring program would satisfy all reporting and research requirements. Moreover, the bureau anticipates that this level of function will be necessary for at least the next 20 to 30 years.

Having learnt that some of the buildings earmarked for demolition contain asbestos, the committee wished to ensure that the removal of any hazardous materials would be done safely. The bureau assured the committee that asbestos would be removed from the island in accordance with relevant legislation and expressed confidence that the tenders, including shipping costs, would cover the asbestos related costs in a worst-case scenario.

In response to questions regarding the environmental impact of the proposed work, the bureau stated that the Department of Environment and Heritage had determined that the work did not constitute a controlled action under the terms of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999. The bureau explained that the successful construction contractor would be required to prepare and implement an environmental management plan for the works.

Noting that the bureau had originally anticipated that the construction project would be completed before the summer cyclone season, the committee wished to know how a delay in the construction schedule would impact upon both the project costs and the bureau’s operations. The bureau explained that the magnitude of any delay would depend upon the severity of the coming wet season but anticipated that some excess costs could be absorbed by budgetary contingency provisions. The bureau assured the committee that the Willis Island radar system, which is pivotal in providing forewarning of cyclones approaching the North Queensland coast, will be operational before the cyclone season.

The committee undertook a close examination of the project costs and, given the remoteness of the work site, was especially interested in the costs associated with shipping and logistics. The committee also noted that the cost estimate included a number of as yet undetermined items. The committee recommended that the bureau supply it with cost details of these items when such information becomes available. Having given detailed consideration to the proposal, the committee recommends that the construction of facilities for the Bureau of Meteorology on Willis Island proceed at the estimated cost of $7 million. I would like to thank those who assisted the Public Works Committee with the public hearing and my committee colleagues. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I concur with the comments made by the member for Pearce with respect to the project on Willis Island. There is no doubt that there were some early concerns about the way in which the Bureau of Meteorology referred the matter—and these have been properly attended to in the comments made by the member for Pearce. It is important to note that this is a $7 million project and therefore attracts the provisions of the Public Works Act 1969. However, I think I represent the view of many members of the committee when I say that there has to be a review of the threshold amount of matters referred to the Public Works Committee.

speech.para: There is no doubt that we have a very heavy schedule. In fact, if you compare the work undertaken by this committee with that of many others, you will find that the number of public hearings and inquiries is great. This imposes certain strains upon the time and resources of members and, indeed, the secretariat. I raise that because the committee has asked the government to consider amending the Public Works Act to raise the threshold in order for us to look at works of significant expense—and that issue is under some consideration by government.

The government should also look at lease arrangements—these are not exactly bricks and mortar projects—worth tens and even hundreds of millions of dollars, which are not being properly examined by parliament. The government would do well to consider whether the threshold should be raised so as not to attract smaller projects. At the same time, so as to ensure that the Public Works Committee examines a greater proportion of Commonwealth expenditure, the government should look at allowing the committee to properly review lease arrangements, which have increased over the last 20 or so years, in terms of the way in which the Commonwealth decides to enter into lease arrangements with other parties to provide the services it requires. I support the comments made by the member for Pearce, but I wish to add to them by asking the government to properly consider the particular matters I have raised today.

motion.para: That the bill be referred to the Main Committee for further consideration.

subdebateinfo.title: Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation Committee

motion.para: That the following order of the day, committee and delegation reports, be referred to the Main Committee for debate: Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation—Report—Making it work—Motion to take note of document: Resumption of debate.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 17 March, on motion by Mr Ruddock:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —Although the Copyright Amendment (Film Directors’ Rights) Bill 2005 is a small bill, it carries a great deal of symbolic importance. With the passage of this bill, Australian law will provide economic intellectual property rights to film directors for the first time. This will recognise that directors are essential creative contributors to the film industry and that, as with other creators, their creativity should be rewarded through copyright law.

speech.para: Given the cultural and economic contribution that film directors make to Australia, Labor is pleased to support this bill. The bill includes directors of non-commissioned films in the definition of ‘maker’ of films for the purposes of section 98 of the Copyright Act. However, it then limits the effect of this change to the statutory scheme for the payment of royalties for the retransmission of free-to-air broadcasts. That is the scheme outlined in part VC of the Copyright Act. As a result, although it carries important symbolic value, it is a very limited change in practical terms.

In terms of the history of this issue, the practical modesty of the reform makes it remarkable that the government took such a long time to make good this commitment. The question of whether film directors should be included in the retransmission scheme first arose in 1999, when parliament was considering the digital agenda reforms which introduced the scheme. The House of Representatives Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, of which I was deputy chair, unanimously recommended that film directors should receive remuneration under the scheme. When the digital agenda bill was being debated in this House, Labor moved an amendment to give effect to that unanimous recommendation, but the government opposed it. We had planned to move the amendment again in the Senate, but the government announced at the last minute that it would conduct a special consultation process to consider the issue. In the interests of getting the rest of the digital agenda through, we accepted this compromise, expecting the government to make good its commitment. The then Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston, told the Senate:

quote.para: ... as a matter of priority in September the government will be calling for submissions on the issue of film directors’ copyright. It is hoped that any amendments arising from the review will be ready to be introduced by the end of this year.

speech.para: Unfortunately, that was in August 2000—over five years ago. The government have taken an astounding five years to produce this very limited but, nonetheless, important symbolic change. Given that they could have been guaranteed bipartisan support at any stage in those five years to get this change through, this delay seems to us a sign of nothing but pure incompetence.

Mind you, while it has taken the government five years to finally get around to this reform, the Liberal Party have been more than happy to promise it in both of the elections that we have had in that time. We have heard of the core and non-core promises, but this is an example of a third category of promises—the ‘when we can be bothered, if we remember to’ promise. The irony is that, after five years of allegedly consulting, the government did not seem to consult anybody much. The Screen Producers Association of Australia told the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee that they believed there had been a ‘serious failure on the government’s part to communicate and consult widely with the industry’ before introducing this bill. The Australian Writers Guild made a similar observation, saying that there has been a ‘complete lack of comprehensive industry consultation on the issue of director’s copyright’.

The first time any of the stakeholders got a chance to have real input was when Labor pushed for a Senate committee inquiry on the issue. So the consultation phase, promised to start in September 2000, never happened and the bill, promised before the end of 2000, did not see the light of day until 2005. This has been a case of quite extraordinary mismanagement.

Nonetheless, let us look at the proposed reform. While it has taken five long—and we say wasted—years, I am pleased that we are finally here debating this bill. As I have said, Labor will support the bill, as we believe that film directors should have their creative roles in the Australian film industry recognised through economic rights. By including directors of non-commissioned works in the retransmission scheme, the bill will give these directors an additional chip at the bargaining table. Copyright is assignable by contract, so a change like the one proposed really goes to the default position—the position where bargaining begins. In altering this default position, the bill recognises that directors do have a creative input into films. As with other creators, that input should be recognised through copyright law and through a system that makes sure that there are sufficient incentives to be creative.

There are many reasons that we should be concerned to provide the incentive structure to encourage and support creative directors. Along with others in the film industry, Australian directors over the last century have made a significant contribution to the development of our distinctive Australian culture. Through their work, they reflect our society, history and culture. They have also kept us entertained with Australian stories and, of course, Australia’s unique sense of humour.

Aside from these intangible benefits, the Australian film industry is an increasingly important export industry. As communications technology transmits higher quality video at faster speeds, Australian film increasingly competes in a global market. Indeed, one of the strongest rationales for including directors in the retransmission scheme is that it will help our directors receive reciprocal royalties from retransmissions of their work in other countries, which gives directors economic rights, principally in the large European market. This is a stream of export revenue which can be tapped to support our directors.

Although the internationalisation of the film industry is increasing in pace, the trend has been with us for some time and has already helped several Australian directors achieve international recognition. In what is far from a complete list, I think of people such as Gillian Armstrong, Peter Weir, George Miller and Baz Luhrmann or, more recently, John Polson and Cate Shortland.

I suspect that this bill will not do much to help those directors who have already landed on their feet. Their proven talent is no doubt their best bargaining chip. But it will help the next crop. It will also help the many less famous directors who make the documentaries, animations, miniseries, movies and other film products that are entertaining and educating us every day.

I know that it has been a concern among others in the film industry that the extension of economic rights to directors diminishes the recognition of other rights’ holders, like producers and writers. I do not believe that this is the case. Film, unlike some other creative pursuits, is inherently a collaborative art. It involves joint creative effort and the law should reflect that.

Labor acknowledges the concern raised by the Australian Writers Guild that screenwriters should also be considered owners of copyright in films for the purposes of the retransmission scheme. We support the recommendation of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee that the government consult with relevant stakeholders on this change. We hope that it will not take another five years to get that done.

The question has to be asked: could economic rights have gone further? The Australian Screen Directors Association, as I have said, would have liked this bill to go further. They would have liked some provision to include directors in future statutory royalty schemes. Labor believes that this is impractical at this stage, as we cannot make rules today that will govern schemes in the future—schemes that do not yet exist. I can give a commitment on behalf of Labor, however, that we will certainly consider the inclusion of film directors in any statutory scheme that is proposed in the future. One of the great benefits of the current bill is that it should mean that film directors are brought to the table whenever a new scheme is being considered.

The Australian Screen Directors Association also wanted to see film directors included in the educational copying and communication licensing scheme in part VA. They argue that it is inconsistent to recognise the creative contribution of directors in part VC but not in part VA. They also argue that it is discriminatory, as other creative contributors such as composers and writers are included in part VA of the scheme.

On their face, we find these arguments compelling. The film directors have raised a legitimate issue and it deserves to be explored, in consultation with other stakeholders. As far as Labor is concerned, this bill should not be considered as having closed the book on directors’ rights. Copyright law is a difficult area of policy, because we have to carefully balance the sometimes competing interests of directors, other creative collaborators like writers and producers, and of course consumers. Labor is committed to working with the film industry to pursue any improvements to copyright law that ensure that the incentives are right, the costs are fairly balanced, the export opportunities are maximised and that the public’s interest is properly taken into account.

Film directors are crucial contributors to Australia’s cultural and intellectual life. There is no doubt that their contribution to film is a creative one. For this reason, we believe that they are entitled to share the incentives that our system of copyright provides to creators. Although we would have preferred to see this change occur five years ago, we are pleased that the bill is before the House today, and we are pleased to provide Labor’s support.

talk.start.para: —The significance of the Copyright Amendment (Film Directors’ Rights) Bill 2005 is perhaps essentially a statement of principle, as a recognition in a small but nonetheless tangible way of the creative input of directors: those people who, in the midst of the scores of others involved in the making of a motion picture, have to provide the artistic leadership and the creative command that pull it all together to make the cinematic art. Section 22(4)(b) of the Copyright Act provides:

quote.para: … the maker of the cinematograph film is the person by whom the arrangements necessary for the making of the film were undertaken.

speech.para: That language is derived from the United Kingdom legislation which was the consequence of the recommendations of the Gregory committee in 1952. The committee observed that what this language had in mind was ‘the entrepreneur’—if the word is not too old-fashioned—‘under whose care the labours of many contributors are brought to a successful issue’. The entrepreneur, as artist, is an interesting concept, which is not extended to other forms of creative ownership. The patron who organises all the necessities of life for a painter, or a writer, does not by reason of those logistical efforts become the owner of the copyright in the works created. For films, the owner has always been taken, therefore, to be the producer, who typically pulls the whole enterprise together but, who, most importantly, marries the financial resources necessary for the film, together with the artistic leadership in the form of the director. Of course, a lot of directors are producers, too. The artistic temperament does not preclude great logistical and organisational skill, but the functions are nonetheless separate ones.

Section 86 describes the copyright in a movie as consisting, as one would expect, of essentially the right to copy that film or to cause it to be communicated to the public. In 2000 the parliament amended the Copyright Act to introduce part VC, which is designed to enable pay television operators to rebroadcast simultaneously free-to-air channels. This was an obvious and necessary reform which meant that subscribers to pay television services would be able to watch both the free and the pay channels through the one service. A statutory scheme was established whereby the retransmitting pay television operators would pay a fee—to be settled by the Copyright Tribunal—to the collecting society in the case of films, for screen rights. The effect of the bill therefore is to amend section 98 to provide that, where the film is not a commissioned film, the maker of the film—hitherto meaning the producer only—shall include a reference to each director of the film. The amendments, however, provide that, if a person becomes an owner of the copyright by reason of this director provision, it applies only ‘so far as the copyright consists of the right to include the film in a retransmission of a free-to-air broadcast’.

The term ‘retransmission’ is defined to mean a retransmission to which part VC applies, which is of course the part which applies to the retransmission of free-to-air channels on pay TV services. In some respects therefore, the declaration that the director is a co-owner of copyright in a film is, as the member for Gellibrand observed a moment ago, a symbolic one. Unlike the producer who has all of the section 86 rights of a copyright owner, the director declared to be an owner by this bill has no rights other than to receive a share of the retransmission fees if his film is, firstly, broadcast on a free-to-air channel and, secondly, retransmitted pursuant to part VC of the principal act by a pay TV operator.

The director has the right to transfer his or her interest under this legislation, and one would expect that in most cases the director’s rights would be the subject of a contract and that his or her participation in the copyright of the film—if any—would be determined by that contract. The Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, which considered this bill, was told by Mr Geoffrey Brown of the Screen Producers Association of Australia that only one or two per cent of Australian films were not commissioned ‘since directors waive most of their rights under the terms of their contractual arrangements with producers’. This commercial reality underlines again the essentially symbolic nature of the legislation. Reading the evidence given to the Senate committee, including that from the Attorney-General’s Department, one is struck by the consistent conclusion that the bill will have, in the Senate committee’s words, ‘a negligible impact for the current copyright arrangements for producers, because a director will never work without being in an employee relationship with a producer’.

The principal controversy attending the bill appears to have been the government’s decision not to confer on directors a similar share in the existing educational copying statutory licensing scheme in part VA of the principal act. Notwithstanding that the copyright ownership rights conferred on directors under the legislation are modest indeed, the screen producers expressed themselves as opposed to the bill. Mr Brown, to whom I have just referred, told the Senate committee that the bill introduces uncertainty to the investment climate in the industry. He said:

quote.para: Producers have to guarantee to their investors that the copyright in a cinematographic work is clear and unencumbered, that there is a clear chain of title, to create the confidence for investors to invest in the film. Once you start splintering that into copyright to individual creators ... you start to lose that confidence.

speech.para: Given the limited rights granted under this bill, Mr Brown’s criticism reads as unduly apocalyptic. A better argument, from his viewpoint, may be the contention that this would be the thin edge of the wedge and that further rights, especially statutory rights, could be granted. The bill, the producers would argue in that case, creates a precedent from which other legislative changes may follow. Dr Matthew Rimmer of the Australian National University, in his very scholarly submission to the Senate committee, observes—correctly in my opinion—that the answer to the thin edge of the wedge or floodgates argument put by Mr Brown is:

quote.para: ... that there should be clearer rules as to joint authorship in respect of a copyright work—not that we should deny the possibility of joint authorship altogether.

speech.para: I note, in the context of Dr Rimmer, that the member for Gellibrand, in her criticism of the government, seemed to make two critiques of the government’s preparation of this legislation or carriage of this legislation which were contradictory. On the one hand she said that the government had taken far too long to introduce it: after all, part VC had been introduced in 2000 so why had it taken five years to bring this bill into the House? On the other hand she said that the government had failed to consult and that one may then ask what had been happening over all those years. The reality is that the government was consulting. It is true that the producers and the Australian Writers Guild complained to the Senate committee about a lack of consultation—and the member for Gellibrand pointed that out. But she would have given the House a fairer appreciation of what had transpired before the Senate committee had she referred to the submissions from other parties before the committee, in particular that of Dr Rimmer whose contribution, as I said earlier, was a very scholarly one and an extremely valuable one. I will read what he said on this point in his submission. He said:

quote.para: ... the debate over film directors’ copyright has been an exhaustive process, with much special pleading by all sides. The various stakeholders have all had ample opportunities in the past six years in which to address this issue. There certainly has been a comprehensive consultation about film directors’ copyright.

speech.para: Dr Rimmer was not an interested stakeholder: he was not a producer, he was not a director, he was not a writer. With respect to the member for Gellibrand, I think it would have been fair of her to draw that objective appreciation to the attention of the House before she presented her highly critical assessment of the government’s carriage or preparation of this legislation.

The Writers Guild, predictably, opposed the bill unless similar rights could be given to writers. The Senate committee’s sole recommendation—other than that the Senate should pass the bill—was that writers be included as co-owners of copyright for the purpose of sharing part VC retransmission revenues. The writers’ case for inclusion in this bill appears to me a very strong one. After all, it was only in 2000 that the Copyright Amendment (Moral Rights) Billwas passed by this parliament. It granted to the authors of literary, dramatic, musical and artistic works and cinematographic films certain moral rights—essentially, the right to have their authorship acknowledged, or attributed in a reasonably prominent way, and the right to ensure that the work’s artistic integrity is maintained. For the purpose of the moral rights legislation, the author of a film is defined as the maker of the film, which is in turn defined as the principal director, principal producer and principal screenwriter of that film.

There was also some criticism of the bill because it allows directors to sign away their part VC rights—as undoubtedly almost all of them will do in accordance with their contracts with the producers. The notion of a nontransferable property right does not sit comfortably with our legal system and, certainly from our side of politics, it is difficult to see any reason why a person should not be able to deal freely with their own property. Given the global nature of the cinema industry, it is well for the House to consider whether this bill adds to international harmony or complexity.

The countries of the European Union have traditionally taken a different view of the ownership of the copyright in a film. Rather than the entrepreneur, the organiser, the producer, who pulls it all together being the owner of the copyright—which is the view taken by the common law countries, including the United Kingdom, the United States, Australia, Canada and New Zealand—the Europeans have given directors moral and economic ownership rights. This view of the director as auteur is distinctly different from our own, but it is gaining ground because of the influence of the European Union. In 1996 the United Kingdom’s laws, in order to comply with European laws, were changed to provide that the director and the producer are deemed to be joint authors and copyright owners of a film. An employed director’s rights vest in the producer, and a nonemployee director can, of course, contract to transfer his rights to the producer—and most do. The UK maintains a statutory scheme—not unlike our own scheme for rental rights—and the directors have a nontransferable right to remuneration from that scheme.

One submission to the Senate committee, by Kimberlee Wetherall, claimed that the bill creates a uniquely—and thus discordantly—Australian position, because, while we will recognise producers as owners of the copyright, as do the United Kingdom and the United States, we will add directors only for certain purposes. Further, she said, unlike the United States we will give directors moral rights—of course, we have given directors moral rights—but, again, unlike the United States, not confer a concept of co-authorship where the film is regarded as a joint work. The US position, as in so many other areas of law, is essentially unique, even idiosyncratic.

It is difficult to see how Australia can reconcile its law perfectly with that of any other country unless we were to copy that of another country. Of course, it used to be the case that our copyright laws were essentially a facsimile of the United Kingdom’s. The rest of the world has moved in so many different ways—and the differences are, in so many ways, very subtle—that it is hard to see how Australia can harmonise its laws with a copyright world that is becoming increasingly, often subtly, less harmonious.

On balance, I believe that the bill improves our position in a global context. It is better to give directors some recognition than to give them none. As the explanatory memorandum notes, the Australian Screen Directors Association has contended that it has had difficulty negotiating for recognition for Australian directors under authorship schemes in Europe due to the lack of reciprocal payments in Australia. A fair criticism of the bill would be that it is a gesture only—that directors will simply contract away their rights to the producers. That may be so—in which case the concerns of the producers ring rather hollow.

The critics of the bill may find, therefore, that this legislation will be an arrangement which, from their point of view, fails in theory but works perfectly well in practice. Time will tell. When the House returns to the subject matter of this bill, it would do well, in my view, to give very serious consideration to including, as the Senate committee recommended, writers as co-owners for the purposes of participating in the statutory scheme under part VC of the principal act. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —If the member for Wentworth was disappointed by the member for Gellibrand’s comments on the Copyright Amendment (Film Directors’ Rights) Bill 2005 then he will not be terribly happy with my comments either. My expectations of the government when it comes to this essential industry, our audiovisual industry, are very high. I expect the government to take a leadership role, above the sectional interests of the industry itself, and lead this industry into the vibrant future it deserves. The bill brings about some very minor changes. It is true that they may be symbolic, but they are associated with one of Australia’s most important industries and one of the fastest-growing markets in the world and they relate to one tiny aspect, very small amounts of money and very few directors under very narrow circumstances.

speech.para: Let us look at exactly what the bill does. Directors in Australia currently have no economic rights in a film; they have moral rights, but no economic rights. This bill gives directors copyright in the case of retransmission through free-to-air, but in very few cases—for example, it only applies to uncommissioned films and it is estimated that only one to two per cent of all films are uncommissioned. The vast majority are commissioned and will not be affected by this bill. It is about negligible amounts of money, for a very small number of people, in a scheme that has not yet been established, yet there has been considerable debate about it within the industry. It is extremely important to directors because it might be a precedent, it is extremely important to producers because it might be a precedent and it is extremely important to writers because they are not included in what might be a precedent. But each of those three groups has a different view. The directors hope it is a precedent, the producers hope it is not and the writers hope it might be. None of them is really concerned about the bill itself, because the financial impact will be quite negligible, but all are concerned about the possible precedents being established here.

All parties in the industry have had something to say. As I said before, as you would expect, the Australian audiovisual industry is well represented by these associations. They are all effective and all argue in the interests of their own constituents, as they should. The argument here, once again, is about how the pie should be cut up. We are arguing about the slices of pie and who gets what slice—or, more accurately, in this case we are arguing about the crumbs that fall off the slice of pie as it is passed from one person to another. This is essentially a bill about the crumbs—very minor stuff—and has been under discussion now for five years.

When the Copyright Amendment (Digital Agenda) Bill 2000 was passed, a scheme was introduced whereby subscription television providers could retransmit free-to-air broadcasts without infringing copyright on condition that royalties were paid to the copyright owners. That is quite a standard thing in other creative sectors. At the time, though, the Australian Screen Directors Association lobbied that film directors should be included as copyright owners in films for the purposes of the retransmission scheme. This was part of a broader ongoing campaign to have directors sharing in the copyrights of films. Currently the producers of films are the only default copyright owners. The government did not respond at the time, but they did promise to review the issue and present another bill later in 2000. The Copyright Amendment (Film Directors’ Rights) Bill 2005 is the result—five years later—and it is still unclear whether this is a precedent or whether it is a sop for directors who were promised something in 2000.

We are talking here about crumbs. We are arguing about slices of the pie when really we should be talking about the size of the pie. Whereas most of the industry associations within the film industry have to argue about the allocation of the pie slices, the government has the capacity to step above that and provide leadership in the industry and talk about how to make the pie bigger or even how to build a bigger bakery. The industry around the world is enormous and the potential for growth in the Australian industry is absolutely huge. In 1999 global trade in services accounted for 20 per cent of cross-border trade and 60 per cent of global output. In 1994 output from the information communications sector was valued at $US1.5 trillion, with media forming 21 per cent of that.

The industry has been growing at twice the US growth rate since 1977. It is a massive industry growing at a rapid rate. By all means let us talk about how producers, directors and writers divide up the pie, but let us talk, more importantly, about how we build a bigger, more vibrant industry. Let us talk about the barriers that stop our industry from growing quickly. Let us talk about the confusion between rules and regulations in different territories, complexities of coproduction, companies trying to operate in several tax regimes through several government funding models and under several copyright regimes, with private investors with their own needs and uncertainty in our own market in the interpretation of tax laws.

Underlying the difficulties that our film industry face is the international context in which films are made and distributed territory by territory, with many partners, other governments and private investors, each with complex rules, regulations and customs of their own. Our industry is drowning in complexity and production is falling. The deficit in the balance of trade for Australia in royalties arising from imports and exports of cinema films has continued to grow in the last 15 years. The value of exports of audiovisual products rose from $105 million in 1987-88 to $152 million in 2002-03. That is a 50 per cent increase over some 15 years. The deficit grew from negative $245 million to negative $528 million—that is an increase of 100 per cent in the same 15 years.

Meanwhile, Australia continued to go backwards. Imports of film, television and digital products whose IP ownership is offshore continues to outstrip exports. The longer this continues the more impoverished our industry will become. Australia’s production of its own films is well and truly in decline. In 2004 Australia produced 16 films—down from 28 in 1994. It is interesting to look at the range of countries that outproduced us quite significantly. The obvious countries are there: India, USA, Japan and China. India produced 946 films and China produced 212. Spain beat us with 133 films, Bangladesh with 90, South Korea with 82, Brazil with 81, Argentina with 78, Mexico with 54, the Philippines with 53, Turkey with 27, Pakistan with 25, Egypt with 25, Netherlands with 24, Taiwan with 24, Malaysia with 22, Greece with 22, Hungary with 21, Romania with 21, Poland with 17 and Indonesia with 17. Australia produced 16 films.

We are well down on the world production list. Australia is one of the great talents when it comes to film production. We have a highly creative population and we do excellent work. The domestic film share of the total national box office has been in decline in Australia. It was eight per cent in the year 2000 and only one per cent in 2004—significantly lower than many of our competitor countries. The average number of cinema admissions per capita in Australia is about average at 4.5. That is slightly up on the statistics for 1993, but the growth has been static, at best, since 1999.

Federal government appropriations have fallen. They were at their lowest in 1998-99, with the greatest variation in appropriations over the 11-year period attributed to the formation of the commercial television production fund, with the largest single increase—22 per cent—coming in 1995-96, the year in which the agency was established. The largest decrease—12 per cent—occurred in the year the fund was terminated, in 1998-99. Appropriations for the Australian Film Commission fell steadily from $68 million in 1991-92 to $49 million in 1996-97. They remained almost static at $48 million to $50 million between 1997 and 2002 and finally rose again in 2002-03 to $58 million—still $10 million short of the peak in 1991-92.

In the face of that, in the face of the potential and the reality for the Australian industry, let us talk about the audiovisual industry and how proposed changes to media ownership, for example, will impact on the development of our industry. We hear the government talk about changes to media ownership, but we rarely hear them talk about the effect that will have, positive or negative, on the development of our audiovisual production industry. Let us talk about changing technologies. Again, we hear the government talk about digital television—and there are many reviews into that at the moment—and shifts in consumer preferences through broadband and downloading through handheld devices, but how will these impact on the development of our industry? When those changes come to fruition will we have a stronger production industry? Will we be a stronger exporter or will we be an even greater net importer? Let us talk about market failure. Let us talk about the fact that in any creative industry there is a need for a very strong scene where mistakes are made, where people come together and break apart, where people try new ideas—many of which fail—and the extreme unlikelihood that any commercial company will invest in such a high-risk innovative product.

Let us talk about the ABC and how the role that the ABC had as a leading innovator and trainer of our audiovisual industry has now been lost, with the ABC producing very little drama and not playing a significant role even as we approach a change in form from analog to digital. Let us talk about all the issues that affect the rest of the country—skills, export, R&D and innovation. The film industry is in exactly the same boat, only in much rougher seas than most, and is still ignored. I rarely hear the government talk about the community, common stories and the role of the cultural sector in providing common views and stories for our population. Let us talk about vertical integration and convergence. Let us see the effect of transnational media corporations—big corporations that have swallowed production companies including large Hollywood studios—and the potential for anti-competitive behaviour when broadcasters and distribution media of all kinds become owners of production houses or when producers of content buy up the means of distribution.

Let us see the government address the effects of bilateral trade agreements, rather than multinational agreements, with exemptions negotiated on a case-by-case basis. This creates incredible uncertainty and is a nightmare for producers negotiating coproductions across international borders. Let us see the government acknowledge the difficulties experienced in gaining access to high-bandwidth telecommunications—the capacity needed to transfer and exchange the knowledge products of the industry—and the evidence that costs are much higher in Australia than they are in the rest of the world and that that is holding back our industry. Let us talk about the potential of that industry. Let us hear the government talk about the growing world market and the extraordinary talent that we have, how they will work to make sure that there are flow-on effects for our industry and that Australia’s creative product in the world benefits its image and its tourism industry. Let us hear the government talk about the intellectual property market globally and how our creative sector can become a major player in that world market. Let us hear something from this government.

In the past few weeks we have seen the government being driven by ideology on the sale of Telstra. We have seen them fixated on the path of privatisation to the extent that they do not know any more where that path is leading. We have seen a similar fixation on deregulating the labour market—so fixed on that belief, so focused on the path that they have not looked up to see where that path is going. When it comes to the audiovisual industry we do not see a path or a plan at all, let alone a horizon or a view of what the world might look like beyond that horizon. True, in recent years there have been some reports. There was a paper from the Prime Minister’s Science, Engineering and Innovation Council which had some excellent suggestions and quite a good analysis of the problems within the industry. We have had From reel to unreal: future opportunities for Australia’s film, animation, special effects and electronic games industries from the Standing Committee on Communications, Information Technology and the Arts; we have had the Gonski Review of Commonwealth Assistance to the Film Industry several years ago; and we have had some action with the promise to extend the Film Licensed Investment Company scheme immediately prior to the last election with some measures in the 2004 budget.

Nevertheless, it is my view that the government is not strongly supportive of this industry; that its work over the last few years has left this industry struggling with massive technological changes, massive changes in the financial structure of the industry and an extremely complex and convoluted international regulatory framework in which to operate. I urge the government to show leadership here, to engage the industry in the development of a real plan that will ensure a real future for this extremely important and highly skilled industry and to maximise the return to this country from the work of our creative talent. There are enormous potential benefits to Australia, both economic and cultural. We have had a five-year wait for this bill that deals with crumbs, but we really cannot wait another five years for this government to develop a real plan for this sector.

talk.start.para: —It is a pleasure to speak on the Copyright Amendment (Film Directors’ Rights) Bill 2005 because it recognises, for the first time, the right of directors to a share of the copyright in their films. The copyright protection of the directors’ creativity of entrepreneurial input will secure their economic and intellectual property. This bill will give directors a right to a share of royalties with producers when their films are shown on pay TV channels. Given the emergence of pay TV channels in our modern times, this has to be a very positive step.

speech.para: The bill delivers a commitment made by our government in the Strengthening Australian Arts policy for the 2004 election. It is the product of consultation with the main stakeholders. The bill builds on the government’s amendments to the Copyright Act 1968 in 2000, which gave directors moral rights in their films. The bill creates the opportunity for directors to claim royalties for use of their films under remuneration schemes in the European Union countries. European directors will now have reciprocal entitlements to remuneration in Australia.

In discussing this bill, it is worth reflecting more broadly on the film sector. The government recognises the importance of a viable local film and television industry for the many reasons just outlined by the member for Parramatta. The sector not only improves and makes a great contribution to our economy but is a very significant part of our cultural life. As a whole, the Australian film and television industry contributes some $2.1 billion annually to GDP and employs more than 25,000 people. I am aware, from a recent visit to China—I will talk about this in more detail shortly—that the Chinese industry use our postproduction facilities and have been doing so for some time. They are also very interested in our locations—the unique Australian landscape and the cities. The government is doing a lot to support the industry and to make sure that it continues to grow.

The film industry provides the creative opportunity to tell our stories in our way. The industry also fosters a very wide range of talents and skills—from directors to screenwriters, producers, actors, sound engineers, set designers and makers and camera operators. These are just a few of the different skills required of all those involved in producing a film. As I said, the government recognises the importance of the industry and provides a range of support to the sector to ensure its long-term sustainability. Without government intervention there would be few local voices on our screens.

In the 2004 election campaign, the government announced a film policy: ‘A World Class Australian Film Industry’. This package of measures was confirmed in the 2005-06 budget and is worth $88 million over four years. As a result, total direct funding for film in 2005-06 is at a high of almost $160 million. The package is a carefully balanced strategic intervention and takes a whole-of-industry approach. It will strengthen our film and television sector through a combination of increases in direct support to our film agencies and by making the film sector more attractive to private investors. It is important that we get the copyright laws right so that we protect the intellectual property of directors.

A focus of our film package is private investment. The Australian film industry needs a greater level of private sector support. Private investment is an important complement to direct funding by government. In Australia, film and television financing is usually a combination of investment from the marketplace, government funding and private investors.

The parliament recently enacted the Film Licensed Investment Company Act 2005, which extends the Film Licensed Investment Company scheme in accord with our election commitment. The extended FLIC scheme seeks to encourage the private sector investor back to film and television. On Friday, 12 August, Senator Rod Kemp, the Minister for the Arts and Sport—a very active minister who works very hard to promote the whole of the arts and sports portfolio; I know he has had a particular interest in film and done much to support that sector—called for applications from Australian companies for the new FLIC licence.

Under the FLIC scheme, in 2005 a company will be granted a licence to raise $10 million in concessional capital in both 2005-06 and 2006-07. This will inject up to $20 million in additional funds into the local sector, while investors in the FLIC scheme will benefit from a 100 per cent up-front tax deduction on shares purchased. The government will also soon be calling for submissions to a review of divisions 10B and 10BA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and has announced that it will amend the act with regard to the interaction of the foreign loss quarantining rules. Both of these measures were sought by the sector and were part of the consultation process.

The Australian government is working in other ways to stimulate our local film sector. To encourage and facilitate cooperative film-making, Australia and China have been negotiating a bilateral film co-production treaty. The member for Parramatta is right when she says that there has been immense growth of the film industry globally. I was in China with the minister at the time that the discussions on the bilateral film co-production treaty were going on. I am trying to recall the figures, but we met with the minister responsible for the film industry in China. She told us that China would be making in the order of 257 movies this year and would be opening around 160 or 170 digital cinemas across China. Their film industry is very vibrant, but we have to remember that China has a population of 1.3 billion people against Australia’s 20-odd million. So there is a slight difference.

I listened with interest to the member for Parramatta’s comments about the numbers of films being made. Success cannot always be simply linked to quantity. One of the great features of the Australian film industry is that we produce very high-quality film and television programs. That is recognised around the world. Many of our directors, actors, musicians—people writing music for screen—and many other people involved in the industry have been recognised and awarded. It is the quality of our films that is critical, and we need to maintain that high quality and high reputation within the sector. It is that high quality of work and that high reputation that bring in the other work that helps to sustain the whole industry—the post-production work, for example.

Australia and China have a history of working together. It is my privilege to have been, now for the second term of parliament, elected by my colleagues as the chair of the Australia-China Parliamentary Friendship Group. As such, I have had the great privilege of travelling to China fairly frequently. As I said, in July this year I had the benefit of being there with the Minister for the Arts and Sport, Senator Rod Kemp. He was very active in seeking a bilateral film cooperation treaty. We are hopeful that we will be able to agree on a text later this year.

As I said, our countries have a history of working together on internationally renowned film projects such as Hero and House of Flying Daggers. In both of these films we did some post-production work here in Australia, if my memory serves me correctly. The agreement between Australia and China represents a great opportunity for the Australian film industry to collaborate with Chinese film-makers and to access the film market of the world’s most populous nation.

There are tremendous opportunities for us, including promoting our own unique culture, telling our own stories in our own way and promoting the unique Australian landscape. The member for Parramatta mentioned the tourism aspect of film-making. A lot of people do not realise it, but when movies like Matrix, for example, are made in Sydney they are not made by an Australian company but they use Sydney as a set. That promotes Australia internationally. The unique Australian landscape is also of interest to the Chinese. They think it is pretty fascinating. There are lots of opportunities for us to highlight and promote the benefits of Australian talent, the Australian landscape and the Australian post-production services to overseas film-makers.

As I said, last month I was in China when Senator Kemp was there and when this treaty was discussed with Chinese officials. Both Australia and China are very enthusiastic about this treaty. I can assure the member for Parramatta that our minister—and he is a very good minister; he is very committed to the arts, very involved and very knowledgeable—was constantly talking about the brilliance of our Australian film industry and the brilliance of the talent that we have. He was taking every opportunity to promote the Australian film industry.

Australia and China are cooperating in other ways. On 10 September, the Australian Film Commission, together with the Australian embassy and the consulate-generals in China, will launch another series of Australian film festivals. There was a very successful Australian film festival last year. I want to take the opportunity to mention Sean Kelly, who is the cultural ambassador in China, working in the embassy in Beijing. A lot of the credit has to go to him and his department for the promotion and development of these very successful film festivals—of course, along with the Australian Film Commission and the Australian Ambassador to China, Dr Thomas.

During his visit, Senator Kemp was able to announce that the martial arts superstar Jackie Chan will be the international patron of the 2005 Australian film festival series. We know that Jackie Chan has had a long and very close association with Australia. I am sure that he will be an excellent patron and will again provide a great opportunity for us to promote the Australian film industry in the best possible way. Australia will present 10 leading Australian films from the past five years in festivals in Beijing in September—this month; in fact, it has happened—in Shanghai in November and in Guangzhou in December. Last year, audiences totalling nearly 10,000 people enjoyed another 10 top Australian films—as I said, in the first-ever Australian film festival held in China.

It has been a great promotion. Chinese people love good Aussie films. I had an opportunity to meet one of the Chinese leaders here a few months ago—I think last year. He was telling me about his grandchild, who enjoys Australian TV series. After his visit, I sent him a note to say how pleased I was to meet him and a copy of Bananas in Pyjamas for his four-year-old grandson. During a later visit to China, I had occasion to meet him. He said that his grandson thoroughly enjoys Bananas in Pyjamas, even though it is in English, and that it makes him laugh a lot.

As I said, Australian films are popular. The Chinese love Aussie films. Our minister is doing a fantastic job—as are our Australian film sector and the embassy—in promoting Australian films.
