It is very complex but very rewarding work—not monetarily, but rewarding in what he has been able to gain in extra experience and the fact that he loves the work. But he suffers from what a lot of other people in the industry suffer from: there is not enough remuneration, it is extremely casualised and there is no extra economic input. I doubt that storyboard artists will ever have that, but it is very similar to directors in terms of the creative input; they work together to create this content.

We have in the bill a very narrow focus with the government asking, ‘How do we get out of this problem?’ On the one hand, they have said, ‘We need to do something for directors, but we don’t want to upset the existing producers in the way they raise money to produce stuff. So we will create a new class of right, an economic right, but we will do it in such a way that it will be prescribed that only those free-to-air broadcasts, where previously a producer was paid, which are picked up by pay TV will have an economic right of which directors can be a part while having to share remuneration with producers.’

I hardly think this measure will re-energise the Australian film industry and I doubt whether the minister at the table does either. In his second reading speech he referred to the bill’s scope being made narrow and the fact that it was the right thing to do—and Labor members have had no demur in that regard. But it is also indicative of a fundamental problem: there has not been enough thought given to or enough work done on a key driver of the Australian economy.

I happen to know a little more about that because, in June last year, the report From reel to unreel: future opportunities for Australian films: animation, special effects and electronic games industries was brought down in this parliament. It was produced by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, on which I served as deputy chair throughout the last parliament. It was critically clear from those proceedings that the Australian film industry had entered a parlous period—to use a Goughism; it had gone into a trough. There were significant problems with creative input and funding for Australian films. There were further difficulties with greater power, particularly that of the United States. In addition, further problems had occurred in areas where we had had work previously, particularly in post-production. Right throughout production facilities on the Gold Coast—where there is the electorate of the member for Moncrieff, who also served on that committee—the cry arose from those industries that we needed to do a great deal more because things were rapidly changing within the film industry.

One of the key changes has occurred in post-production, where we had had a great deal of strength. Now, because the digital pipes running across the Pacific are much bigger, it is possible for post-production work to be done in Los Angeles and other areas of the United States; those who are putting up big money for these films are choosing to do that work there. So the capacity for people to get post-production work in Australia, in order to fill in between the bits and pieces of casualised work they can find, is being eroded by the march of technology and the capacity of broadband links, but it is also being eroded dramatically simply because there is a determination on the part of major producers in the United States to use their own people because they can now do so. That is one of the reasons we have difficulties.

But there is a further problem in that the engine of growth in terms of creativity in the Australian film industry seems to have died out. If George Miller is right, it is because there is a lack of self-belief in our own product. I think he is right to say that it is not the case that Australians are not bothering to turn up because they can go and look at the footy, because people are more interested in AFL or league or whatever else than they were a few years ago. We just have not put enough energy into producing product that is sufficiently compelling and that will sufficiently tell our stories in the way that we used to. I think a good part of that is the fact that the government just does not seem to get it about the Australian film, games and animation industry. They think they can run on their own. Like many other industries in the past, they need the government behind them. They need the government talking up the industry. They need the government supporting and helping to re-energise the industry. They need an active and innovative government that is willing to go in and put in the effort to support the games industry, which is almost as big now as our film industry in terms of its economic output and its capacity to work within the world market.

So, while I support it, this bill is tragically minor in its approach and tragically minor in its effect. But it is indicative of the fact that the government has a very narrow range of view in regard to one of our biggest and boldest industries—not just one by which we project ourselves to the world but also one where we have earned a great deal of money in the past and where we should earn a great deal of money in the future.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I thank honourable members from all sides who have participated in the debate. But, in relation to the comments we have just heard from the member for Blaxland, I might say that he suggested that much of what he had to say was sourced from somebody’s contribution that he had read. I thought his contribution was well informed and reflected his own interest from not only his family linkages but also his experience on the relevant parliamentary committee. I commend him for being a lot less political than some of his colleagues and very much more informed. I hope I have not damned him with faint praise.

speech.para: The member for Gellibrand has contributed, as has the member for Parramatta, the member for Fraser—the member for Watson had a one-minute intervention—the member for Kingsford Smith and the member for Gorton. If you read their contributions, you will know what I mean. My colleagues the members for Wentworth, Pearce, Fisher and Moncrieff were obviously very much more supportive, as you might expect.

The Copyright Amendment (Film Directors’ Rights) Bill 2005 is relatively simple. It delivers on a commitment made by the government in its strengthening arts policy at the last election. It delivers that commitment in a way that seeks to balance interests—and there are interests that need to be balanced. The producers may feel that those rights are an incursion on their rights; directors may feel that the rights proposed do not go far enough. The reality is that the government has to seek to strike a balance and, as ever, those issues are difficult.

The Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee and the government consulted and heard from key stakeholders and interests. The government and the Senate committee believe the bill strikes the right balance and for the first time will recognise directors as having a share in the copyright of their films. It will give directors a right to share in royalties to be payable by subscription television broadcasters for retransmitting free-to-air broadcast of films. However, as accepted by the committee, the bill will not affect the existing revenue streams on which producers so heavily rely in order to seek investment in the Australian film industry. I might say that it is interesting in the context of this debate how much emphasis was put by some on the need for investment in the Australian film industry.

The bill furthers the government’s aim to recognise and encourage the creative contribution of our many fine Australian directors. At the same time it avoids the potential for adverse effect on investment in Australia’s important film industry and on existing revenue sources that are so vital. I would also like to note that the government is of course proud to be able to move Australian law into line with that of many other countries in the world.

I observed that there were some criticisms. Some suggested there was delay. The member for Gellibrand did this, but the member for Wentworth correctly pointed out that there was a contradiction. While we were on the one hand accused of unreasonable delay, we were also accused of not having consulted enough. If you read some of the submissions to the Senate committee, the consultation was commented on by a number of the contributors. Dr Rimmer said to the Senate committee that the consultation was comprehensive and lengthy because stakeholders could not agree.

It is important to understand the context in which these changes are being addressed. They are not being addressed in isolation. The fact is that there have been many significant changes in Australian copyright law in the last four years or so. There have been major changes around the implementation of the American free trade agreement. There has been parallel importation legislation for software and computer games. I note that there have been other areas in which we have been engaged in undertaking comprehensive reviews. They include the fair use provisions and how they might be implemented to bring us more closely into line with what is happening in the United States; the technological protection measures; and the resale royalty issue, which I have been examining and on which I will have some statements to make shortly.

As members will know from dealing with me over a period of time, I am outcome driven and I want to see these issues moved on, and moved on effectively, but in a way which includes consultation. In relation to some of these issues, I would like to think that, rather than playing the man or woman, we would hear some positive contributions about what is being achieved in areas like this where it is said there is in fact no substantial difference between us. In that context, I thank the members who have contributed but I do not necessarily thank them for the personalised comments where they have been made.

Some other issues were raised. The member for Parramatta raised some issues, which I will write to her about to clarify. But in this matter the government believe that the amendments proposed in the bill honour our commitment in a way which fairly balances stakeholder interests. This legislation represents a milestone in giving recognition to the important creative contribution of directors, without disturbing existing practices for securing investment in the Australian film industry—something which a large number of members have commented on during the course of this debate. Again, I thank all those who have contributed and look forward to the bill receiving a speedy passage.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 7 September, on motion by Mr Abbott:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —Throughout 2004 the inflationary effect of the safety net on specialist fees was apparent to everyone but apparently not to the minister for health. Health journalists reported on the way the safety net was providing obstetricians with an incentive to restructure their fees to shift in-hospital costs to out-of-hospital costs that were then eligible for the safety net rebate. Perhaps this was attractive to patients, but it led to Medicare rebates for obstetricians increasing by 62 per cent from the first quarter in 2004 for the same period in 2005. Obstetrics fees increased by 151.8 per cent in the period from March 2004 to March 2005.

speech.para: Health care inflation was the real story of the safety net. Out-of-pocket costs for patients for all services have increased by 9½ per cent over the six months to June of this year, with patients now forced to pay an average of $24.61 per medical visit compared to $21.02 last December. But in this legislation there are no solutions to address inflationary health costs, and no amount of savage pruning can avert the safety net’s inevitable demise.

Since its introduction, the safety net has proved to be popular with patients. That was no surprise to the government. After all, it was the centrepiece of their so-called ‘Strengthening Medicare’ campaign at the last election. Within the first three months of the safety net policy, the cumulative number of families and singles that had registered for the safety net had reached half a million, while the first signs of a cost blow-out began to emerge as actual expenditure outgrew the estimated expenditure by 40 per cent. That is quite a blow-out.

Through the work of Senate estimates committees, we know that the Minister for Health and Ageing was well aware of these cost blow-outs by mid-July 2004. By August 2004, when the election was called, the difference between estimated expenditure and actual costs had reached an astounding 70 per cent, but the silence prevailed. Again, Senate estimates hearings revealed that both the minister for health and the minister for finance were aware of this cost blow-out but failed to tell the Australian public prior to the election. Apparently, there is real protection for ministers in the Howard government when it comes to accountability but no protection for the Australian people.
Who can forget that infamous Four Corners interview last September in which the health minister—who will no doubt be remembered for this—was asked:

quote.para: Will this Government commit to keeping the Medicare-plus-safety-net as it is now in place after the election?

speech.para: Of course, the minister replied:

quote.para: Yes.

speech.para: When asked:
The minister replied emphatically:

quote.para: Cast-iron commitment. Absolutely.

speech.para: It is a bit like pants on fire, isn’t it? Seeking further clarification, the reporter asked:

quote.para: 80 per cent of out-of-pocket expenses rebatable over $300, over $700?

speech.para: The minister declared:

motion.para: That is an absolutely rock solid, iron-clad commitment.

speech.para: That is more political farce. But it was not just this interview in which the minister misled the Australian people. There were dozens of occasions of deceit. Four days prior to the Four Corners interview, the Treasurer had a go. He insisted that the parameters of the Medicare safety net ‘will not change’. Even the Prime Minister got in on the act during an interview with Ray Hadley on radio 2GB when he said:

quote.para: In fact, we have a better Medicare system now than our opponents are offering because we have this new beaut safety net. If you’re a cardholder or a family tax benefit recipient and your out of hospital out of pocket expenses go over $300 a year, you get 80 per cent of the excess back.

speech.para: It did not take long for this ‘new beaut safety net’ to unravel. In April 2005, the Prime Minister told ABC radio that if the current threshold levels were maintained, the cost of the safety net would be $1.65 billion over the next four years. The sad stories always emerge. This is almost four times the original projections. So the ‘new beaut safety net’ was indeed in a tangle and would have to be cut after all.

This government’s disregard for the truth and its obvious willingness to betray the trust of the Australian people is scandalous. Let us not forget that the Medicare safety net policy was sold to the Australian people quite literally as part of the Liberal Party’s $20 million advertising campaign—an advertising campaign, paid for by the Australian people, that perpetuated the government’s lies and deceit. It does not get much more scandalous than that, although we do see a lot of repeat offences occurring right now.

Labor opposed the safety net policy at the last election because of its potential to increase health inflation, and instead put forward a range of policies, such as the provision of free specialist services provided through clinics at public hospitals, to address the very real problem of high, cumulative, out-of-pocket health costs. To combat out-of-pocket expenses for GP services, Labor proposed a range of powerful incentives to get doctors bulk-billing again. In March 1996, under Labor, the bulk-billing rate in Newcastle was 83.2 per cent. After nine long years of the Howard government, it is now at 66.9 per cent after reaching its lowest point in December 2003. Under current management, Medicare continues to advantage the more wealthy areas in major cities, while regional and rural areas continue to miss out on the health dollar.

Minister Abbott does seem to be missing in action on many health issues. The crisis in the medical work force compounds the problems of health care delivery in regional and rural Australia. In my electorate, general practices continue to close and patients continue to wait far too long to see their GP. Recruitment of general practitioners to the existing model of health care is just not happening. The latest figures from the Hunter Urban Division of General Practice show that our region has an unacceptably high ratio of one full-time equivalent GP for every 1,485 people. Their survey has also found that almost half of the doctors in our region would not have become GPs if they had their time again, with the top reasons given being paperwork, bureaucracy and government demands.

The Hunter Urban Division of General Practice put forward a proposal to minimise the demands of red tape on GPs, but apparently it has not heard back from the government on this issue. This is disappointing, but not surprising, given that the health minister did not have any idea about what his own department would be submitting to the current Productivity Commission inquiry into the health work force. The Hunter Rural Division of General Practice has also been vocal on the growing GP shortage. This is something they believe could actually cripple rural towns and their hospitals. They are calling for more nurse practitioners and home-grown GPs, but reform, unfortunately, is not on the health minister’s agenda.

Of course, the Medicare safety net broken promise has been well publicised, because John Howard chose to announce it while his minister was overseas, and in a bizarre act of fake contrition Minister Abbott announced that he had considered quitting over the issue. I am sure there will be some in both state and federal politics on his side who will regret that he did not act on that. But the real losers from his mismanagement of the health portfolio are the people of Australia. Rather than tackle real reform of this difficult portfolio, the government has simply walked away from the challenge and put the burden back on individuals, who now have to fend for themselves.

Another example is the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme—a Labor designed scheme. Unfortunately, in the face of the ever-escalating cost of the PBS, the Howard government has only ever had one response: increase patient contributions. Following the latest increase of the co-payment in the first six months of 2005, the number of concessional scripts written grew by only one per cent. There is a real fear that this slowdown represents poorer, older Australians and chronically ill Australians, who are finding it increasingly difficult to afford their medicines due to the co-payment increase. In my own electorate, I am told of aged people halving their dosages to make their medications last longer. This is not much of a saving given the health risks such actions can lead to.

Minister Abbott has compounded this risk. In August this year, he actually invented a whole new category of medicines on the PBS to which a special patient contribution applies. What is so ‘special’ about this new patient contribution? It conveniently plugs the funding black hole created by another of Minister Abbott’s broken election promises—to make $1 billion in savings to the PBS through his failed 12.5 per cent price-cutting policy. It just never happened.

The minister favours the bludgeon over the scalpel when it comes to managing health care costs. He has failed to effectively manage the detail of the PBS budget, so he is hitting out at the chronically ill to make up for it. He is slugging the sufferers of lung cancer, epilepsy and depression to pay for his failure to negotiate proper pricing arrangements. The minister apparently no longer has the stomach to take on the big guys, so he is taking on the ones who cannot fight back. So, for example, lung cancer sufferers are paying a ‘special patient contribution’ of $460 for the medicine Alimta.

Cancer Council of New South Wales statistics show that Hunter residents are more likely to die of cancer than those in any other part of New South Wales; cancer death rates are higher than the New South Wales average. It is widely accepted that for most forms of cancer early detection is one of the key factors in increasing the chances of survival. Yet the people of the Hunter have no access to Medicare rebates for positron emission tomography—PET—scans. PET scans are effective in the early detection of head, neck, lung, bone, colorectal and bladder cancers. The scans are also extremely accurate in the staging of cancer—that is, determining how advanced a cancer is and therefore being able to determine the most appropriate treatment.

Next year about 5,000 residents of the Hunter and New England region are expected to be diagnosed with some form of cancer. Yet Medicare-rebated PET scans are only available at two hospitals in Sydney. This is despite Newcastle’s Mater Hospital already having a PET scanner installed and running. Indeed, the PET scanner was purchased and can now scan limited numbers of patients using money raised through local cancer and nuclear medicine specialist trust funds, local community support and the activities of various local organisations. Given the cancer rates for my region, the demand for this service far outstrips its capacity, and people have to go to Sydney. I again repeat that Labor in the last election made the offer of making sure that regions had access to Medicare-rebated PET scans. I call on the government, as has the state government and as has our local Newcastle City Council, to make sure that Medicare rebates are given to PET scans in the Hunter.

The Australian people are sick—they are sick of the Howard government slugging patients to patch up a health system that its unrealistic election promises continue to punch holes in. If Mr Abbott had any fight left in him at all, he would use his energies and he would take up the challenge. He would start with supporting Labor’s amendments to limit the damage from this flawed legislation and take on real health reform to benefit every Australian.

talk.start.para: —I would like to start my contribution on the Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005 with an observation after a period of approximately nine or 10 months in this House. Often in addressing legislation there is a very clear difference among the ministers of the government who are presenting the legislation. Sometimes I am faced with a minister who has a genuine interest in their policy area, a real commitment to understanding the challenges that the nation faces in that policy area, and who is putting forward legislation that they genuinely believe will make a positive difference. Sometimes on this side of the House we agree with that legislation, sometimes we do not. But in many of those cases, despite the fact that I might vehemently disagree with the solutions they are putting forward, I can respect the commitment and professionalism that goes into what they are trying to present. On the other hand, as is the case tonight, I feel quite honestly that the Minister for Health and Ageing has very little interest in his policy area. In fact, this minister demonstrates a level of arrogance about his policy area. Having made that comment and that distinction about the frontbench on the other side of the House, I will leave it up to the individual frontbench ministers of the government to decide which category they fall into. I only want to identify that I particularly feel that the minister who is presenting the bill to us tonight falls into the latter category.

speech.para: The minister consistently presents a very political and a very short-term view in the way that he handles his portfolio. It reminds me of a sporting team or a business team which, faced with a particularly strong opponent or problem, gets together and says: ‘Look, guys, we need somebody to go out there and to take a fall to take the other team out. It’s going to destroy your credibility. You’ll look like a complete idiot afterwards, but you’ll be doing it for team and we’ll all appreciate it.’ I think the minister for health is one of those who goes: ‘Yes, pick me. I’m up for that challenge. I’ll take one for the team.’ He does that in the hope that, when he comes back to the locker room, they will like him so much better. That is exactly what has happened on this occasion. This bill has clearly destroyed the credibility of the Minister for Health and Aging. After his ‘rock solid, ironclad guarantee’ no-one believes a word he says.

One of the most transparent tactics to use when you actually know little about your portfolio, have no commitment or interest to it and are merely filling that seat because that is what is available to you is that you believe that if you repeat a mantra often enough it will become truth. The reality is that mantras are powerful in politics, but only if there is some substance behind them. In this case, the minister for health’s repeated claims that this government is ‘the best friend that Medicare has ever had’ covers an absolute absence of solid commitment. In fact, what we have seen, particularly in the run-up to the election, where most of the current health policy that we are dealing with in legislation came from, is that little player from the team running out, saying whatever he has to, willingly and in the full knowledge that he will take a fall after the election in the hope that the team will be grateful. I suspect that they are less than grateful, to be honest, given the decreasing enthusiasm for his repeated mantra in the place of solid policy decisions and sound arguments on behalf of those positions.

This bill changes the thresholds which will apply on the Medicare safety net. It raises the threshold from $300 to $500 for low-income earners and increases the threshold from $700 to $1,000 for others. But it also changed the threshold of truth in election commitments. The minister was directly challenged on whether or not this very piece of legislation would ever appear in this House after the election. That is when he said it was a ‘rock solid, ironclad’ guarantee. He set his own benchmark. He set it high, and he failed it abysmally. It is a broken promise, and the minister should, at the very least, resign his portfolio.

The very least our constituents expect of each of us is the truth: fact not fiction. They do not mind a change in position or a change of mind, especially if they are convinced that those changes are the result of new information such as a financial blow-out. But what they expect is the truth, the old-fashioned ‘facing the music’. Instead, they were fed misleading information and one-liners by the minister and the Prime Minister in repeated interviews, doorstops and, indeed, massively publicly funded commercial television, radio and newspaper advertising. They were told that the Medicare safety net was safe. It was responsible. It was a rock solid, ironclad guarantee. It would not change. It would not be altered in any way, said both the minister and the Prime Minister. It was fully costed. It was funded in the budget, assured both the minister and the Prime Minister.

The $20 million advertising spree repeated those assurances, sometimes three or four times a night with viewing on commercial television. I have to say that I have constituents who complain about being harassed by advertisers on the telephone. Many of them expressed to me the feeling that this particular advertising campaign was very similar. It was a massive advertising campaign.

All the while, however, the government fully knew that their Medicare safety net was blowing out, that it was inflationary and putting considerable pressure on budget outlays. Did they tell anyone? Did they even hint that there might be problems? No. Why not? Because there was an election to be won. There was a public to try and dupe.

Labor, however, knew there was a problem. We knew the Medicare safety net policy was blowing out. We knew it was inflationary. We knew its weight could not be sustained in the budget forward estimates. We said so. We opposed the policy because we knew that it was irresponsible. We knew it was a bandaid for the health system of this country—indeed, we knew it was a bandaid for the electoral fortunes of the government at the election. For our trouble, of course, the government led a chorus of indignation. Those opposite said that we were running a scare campaign to frighten families and pensioners. We were, it was claimed, undermining Medicare. The government urged anyone who would listen to believe the television and radio ads.

But it all came crashing down in this house of cards after the election. The Prime Minister rushed out just prior to the budget to announce that Labor had in fact been right all along—although, if I recollect correctly, he did not actually put it in those terms. Out came the measure to increase the threshold and rein in the fiscal blow-out. The minister, of course, having taken his fall and having been made to look like a fool in his own portfolio area, was nowhere in sight, with no credibility and nothing to say on a major issue in his portfolio.

Many issues relating to the health portfolio have been on the political agenda this year. We recall that the Prime Minister—the Prime Minister, I would point out, not the clayton’s health minister, who obviously has no real interest in his policy area—established a task force inquiry into the health interface after the election. The report, while leaked in parts—and I do not believe there has been any pursuit of that leaking—has not been sighted. COAG is currently assessing health services through a committee and is scheduled to report by the end of this year. Several of the state premiers have been making comment on potential changes to health arrangements. All the while, the minister has said nothing and done nothing constructive, his only contribution being to put up private health insurance premiums—the tick that he is quite happy to provide every year—and to withdraw medicines from the PBS.

When the minister was appointed to counter the very effective campaign of highlighting this government’s dismal performance on bulk-billing and hospitals by my colleague the shadow minister for health, the minister was a veritable ferris wheel of ideas and proposals. He even proposed a takeover of funding and administering hospitals by the Commonwealth. The minister has no credibility on health matters, which has been proven time and time again. He should do the decent thing and resign the portfolio, but the minister will stay to tough it out, because ruthless arrogance abides in these sorts of decisions in the government today. It is the same extreme and ruthless arrogance that promotes an industrial relations agenda with no need to explain why it is truly necessary for Australia’s future.

The government considers that its part in explaining anything can be done by a quick television, radio and newspaper ad, no price too large—$20 million for industrial relations, $20 million for Medicare. We are more than happy to outspend Coca-Cola on advertising in this nation. Since it came to office in 1996, this government has spent nearly $1 billion on advertising alone, not only more than Coca-Cola but more than Toyota or indeed McDonald’s. John Howard has become an adman with absolutely no peer.

But the health minister cannot dodge the statement he made on a doorstop on 16 September last year. He said: ‘I absolutely guarantee that the safety net, as the government has put it into operation, will continue. I absolutely guarantee that. This government does not believe in cutting health spending. The MBS is not a budget limited, bureaucratically controlled program.’ Perhaps it should have been. This language is as unequivocal as you can get. A statement was made to the press, laden with words like ‘absolutely’, ‘guarantee’ and ‘we do not believe in cutting health spending’. What precisely does this bill do? It cuts health spending and reduces access. I am sure the Treasurer was probably one of those egging on the minister to go out and take the fall for the team. The Department of the Treasury, and Finance, have made it clear that the MBS is indeed budget limited and bureaucratically controlled. This is the point of this bill.

The minister has been forced to eat his own words—to squirm through his broken promises and his misleading of Australians before the election. The minister has not told us precisely when he knew that the Medicare safety net was in trouble. He should come clean in this debate. He should try to regain some credibility as the Minister for Health and Ageing. It is clear from information Labor obtained through Senate estimates—a process that the government, with its control of the Senate, now wants to tame—that the department knew that the Medicare safety net was in strife in mid-July 2004. Bear in mind that this policy was adopted by the government only in March of that year.

The pattern of blow-out in expenditure continued throughout the caretaker period, which began on 29 August 2004. It is absolutely inconceivable that the minister was not aware that the Medicare safety net policy was a financial albatross, which this side of the House had predicted. Indeed, not only was the policy flawed but data which the minister released on 16 September 2004 indicated that the rebates paid under the Medicare safety net policy were heavily skewed in favour of high-income electorates. The rebate figures released by the minister revealed that poorer electorates received very little benefit from this safety net. In my electorate, for example, the safety net rebate for September was $144,037. In the electorate of my colleague the member for Throsby the rebate was just $74,117. Compare this with Bradfield, $911,828; Wentworth, $822,545; or indeed the minister’s own electorate, which received $634,791. Even the cheapest of the government ministers’ electorates received five times that of an electorate such as mine. Bennelong, the electorate of the Prime Minister, scored payments of $419,895.

The Medicare safety net policy is a fiasco. The minister will not release an update of the statistics that he published last September to enable me to provide this House with an updated position—although I doubt very much that he would have hesitated to release those figures if the situation had changed and a more equitable share of that Medicare safety net money had been spread across all areas. The threshold increases—in other words, the cut to Medicare accessibility that this bill will implement—exclude one million people, or ‘claiming units’ in the sterile language of the bureaucray, from eligibility for the safety net. I believe that Australians have a right to know how the excluded one million ‘claiming units’ will be apportioned. The minister should provide details during the course of this debate, as he should have done prior to the election.

The other minister who should bear some responsibility for this fiasco is the Minister for Finance and Administration, who sits in the other place. Clearly, he was the team player who said, ‘No, I won’t go out and take that fall; I’m sure my colleague’s much more appropriately placed to do so.’ Several weeks ago, on the ABC Lateline program, my colleague the honourable member for Melbourne called the minister a soft target and a cheque writer for this government’s policy incompetence. The minister’s weak rejoinder was to ask Maxine McKew if it was comedy hour. The time line of the safety net fiasco, which Labor had to tease out during Senate estimates, confirms that the ministers for health and finance, joined by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister, could take this show on the comedy festival tour circuit.

It would be a comedy hour if the issues were not so serious. The cover-up, denial and outright misleading of the electorate are hallmarks of this government’s policies and they are the strategies of a health minister with no commitment to better health outcomes for Australians. The absolute hollowness of the so-called Charter of Budget Honesty has been revealed. The charter, enshrined in the statute books, is a joke. Apart from using the Senate estimates process, Labor had its initial scepticism of the safety net policy confirmed by the charter process. The massive blow-out in the budget’s forward estimates was confirmed only when Labor sought Treasury’s and Finance’s costings of our pledge to abolish the government’s program.

The unfairness of the Charter of Budget Honesty has been raised in this place by my colleague the honourable member for Fraser, and I consider that his concerns are well founded. The honourable member for Lalor outlined in a speech in Queensland the operation of the Congressional Budget Office in the United States. I strongly believe that all members should seriously consider the establishment of such an office in the Australian parliament.

Health care is fundamental to Australia’s wellbeing. Labor governments, from Chifley to Keating, have recognised that the nation’s health care is vital to so many other policy areas—to name just two: the labour market and the productivity growth of the nation. A healthy people with access to medicines, doctors and hospitals has been the principle of Australian health care for the Labor Party. It is why the PBS was established, why Medibank was founded and why Medicare was created. Labor built the health care system to cater for people regardless of income. I do not want to see a return to the days when Australian families put off seeing the doctor, until they could stand the pain of sickness no more, because they did not have the cash in their wallet—or, indeed, because they had such a large outstanding debt that the debt collectors were after them. I do not want to see a return to the days when the choices of a mother were to pay the mortgage, to put food on the table or to visit the local GP.

There is a very good book entitled The politics of Medicare: who gets what, when and how by Gwendolyn Gray. It was published by the University of New South Wales Press. Anyone interested in the complexity of the Australian health care system should read it. I am sure that that the author would be happy to put out an abridged version with cartoons for the minister. The books says:

quote.para: For over 50 years, Australian health care policy has oscillated backwards and forwards between systems of private and public health insurance. Each time a Labor government has introduced a public scheme, an incoming coalition government has dismantled it. Radical change of this magnitude is unique: nowhere in the OECD have major programs been introduced and terminated with every change of national government.

talk.start.para: —It is fair to say that the Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005 is just another example of the incompetence and arrogance of the Howard government. It is a bald statement of the Howard government’s contempt for the Australian voting public. As my colleague the shadow minister for health, Julia Gillard, has said in this place previously, from the time this bill was first legislated it was abundantly clear to every health expert that the design flaw in the safety net was that it was going to be inflationary and it was therefore inevitable that the costs would blow out. History has proven us right.

speech.para: This was a problem lost only on Minister Tony Abbott and the Howard government generally. There is a collective responsibility for the Howard government to front up to the fact that, without a doubt, it has misled the Australian voting public with respect to its proposed Medicare safety net. Certainly the government knew from a Health Insurance Commission audit in 2004 that the scheme, budgeted at $440 million over four years, was going to blow out to around $1.2 billion. The government had knowledge of those figures, yet the Australian public are asked by the health minister, the finance minister, the cabinet and the Howard government collectively to believe that they knew nothing about it and therefore were not required to take the Australian voting public into their confidence with respect to this proposed blow-out. This is incompetence and arrogance in the extreme.

Alternatively, perhaps we should seriously think about whether or not the Howard government did understand the implications but were prepared to deliberately mislead the Australian public for the sake of political expediency. That is the real question that we have to consider in this debate. Perhaps they really knew the figures and sought to go out of their way not to make them fully known to the Australian public. This is borne out by the history of the Howard government’s announcements on the Medicare safety net. I remind the House that the safety net was rushed through this place to give the government an advertising platform on health in the lead-up to the 2004 election, just 12 months ago.

We all know that the Howard government had their eyes firmly set on their own re-election and firmly off any suggestion that elections are about truth and honesty in government. The Minister for Health and Ageing, Mr Abbott, and the Prime Minister and their associates repeatedly guaranteed the voting public, the Australian community, that the safety net would stay in the form that it was in prior to the election. That was a bald, black-and-white undertaking given by the minister for health and the Prime Minister to the Australian community. They very clearly stated on numerous occasions that the $300 and $700 thresholds would proceed, not the $500 and $1,000 thresholds now proposed by this bill before the House.

The minister for health, Tony Abbott, likes to promote himself in the eyes of the coalition government and the Australian public as a knock-around bloke who likes to keep his word. He likes to shake hands and enter into ironclad guarantees with people who he gives his word to. I want to remind the House of what the minister for health infamously said. He said:

motion.para: That is an absolutely rock solid, iron-clad commitment.

speech.para: He went on to say that the $300 and $700 thresholds would stay. He did not say anything about raising them to $500 and $1,000 respectively. What worries me is that this is not the first, nor will it be the last, occasion that that type of commitment has been given by the Howard government, especially during the course of an election campaign.

By way of further example, I can think of another serious problem confronting the Australian public where similar ‘ironclad guarantees’ were given by a senior government minister during the course of the 2004 election campaign. I move from the ‘ironclad guarantee’ of the Medicare safety net given by the minister for health, Tony Abbott, to a similar ‘ironclad guarantee’ given by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Ian Campbell, with respect to the proposed location of a low-level nuclear waste disposal unit.

I want to take the House to the transcript of a radio interview concerning a nuclear waste dump on Thursday, 30 September 2004 on Darwin radio. It raises similar images to the minister for health’s ‘ironclad guarantees’ on the Medicare safety net during the campaign and reinforces why the Australian community should no longer trust the Howard government. We have heard before about core and non-core promises and honesty and integrity in government. So let us go to another example of what they did during the election campaign and what has occurred since the election. We note that, since the election, all of a sudden this nuclear waste dump should be located at one of potentially three areas in the Northern Territory. This is what Senator Campbell said on Darwin radio about a nuclear waste dump:

quote.para: Well what we have said quite clearly and unequivocally many months ago is that the Commonwealth is not pursuing any options anywhere on the mainland—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I fail to see the direct relevance to the Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005.
(Mr Wilkie)—I have been listening very carefully to the member for Batman and he is drawing a comparison on a matter of honesty. I am sure that he will get to the point shortly.

—It is also related to the fact that, in terms of health care and the Medicare safety net, the waste from nuclear medicine is the type of waste that will be stored in the low-level dump proposed by the Howard government for the Northern Territory. It is clearly related to the bill before the House this evening. On his undertaking to the people of the Northern Territory, Senator Campbell went on to say:

quote.para: So we can be quite categorical about that cause. The Northern Territory is on the mainland. And can we also say that our preferred option and the only options that we are pursuing are on the offshore islands.

speech.para: He then went on to say that this:

quote.para: … is interesting given the nature of the debate before the house this evening. “We had decided to be very open and honest about where we want to pursue a waste dump.”

speech.para: Senator Campbell was building up his capacity to give that undertaking to the Australian public about a nuclear waste dump. It reminds me of Minister Abbott’s statement when he said that it was an absolutely ‘rock-solid, ironclad commitment’ with respect to the Medicare safety net. This is how Senator Campbell builds himself up as a person of integrity and standing. I quote:

quote.para: I—

speech.para: Minister Campbell—

quote.para: can rule things in and out and that’s why I’m on the program doing that. He’s—

speech.para: Mr Tollner—

quote.para: asked me to come on the program and make a definitive statement and I’ve made that.

speech.para: He then went on to suggest that, alternatively, the Labor Party was running a scare campaign about the Howard government’s real intentions about the new low-level dump and the proposal to locate it in the Northern Territory. I simply use that by way of example to reinforce that, be it on the Medicare safety net—the bill before the House this evening—or, alternatively, where a nuclear waste dump is to be located in Australia, the Howard government is a serial offender when it comes to misleading the Australian electorate. There are numerous examples of this government saying one thing during the course of an election campaign—giving ‘ironclad guarantees’—and doing another thing after the election. In essence, the government cons the Australian public into believing one thing—the so-called core promise—and then does another thing after the election: the Prime Minister’s famously coined phrase, the ‘non-core promise’. This issue is at the crux of the proposals before the House this evening.

I suggest that the safety net is therefore very unattractive, because it is not what the Australian public voted for at the last election. It is a serious decision by the Howard government to break an election promise, and I therefore reject the statement by the Minister for Health and Ageing in his second reading speech where he says:

quote.para: Increasing the Medicare safety net thresholds has been a tough decision.

speech.para: It was not a tough decision. The minister for health basically said, ‘I got away with it. We won the election and I got away with it, and to hell with the Australian public. If they were silly enough to believe me, that’s their stupidity and I’m the winner.’ That is the type of conduct we have to consider when we look at how the Howard government conducts itself with respect to serious public policy issues in Australia. I believe it was either Howard government incompetence or Howard government lies, and I encourage the Australian public to seriously consider that question.

The minister for health, Mr Abbott, and the Howard government have never been interested in the real problem. The real problem is the growing out-of-pocket expenses of Australians when they need to see a specialist or take a diagnostic technological opportunity. As it has done in many other areas, including child care and health, the Howard government has structured a program that encourages the providers of services to increase their fees, a program that means that those who are supposed to benefit are short-changed yet again. Not only are consumers facing higher costs as providers raise their prices in response to the safety net provision, but the changes proposed to lift the thresholds now mean that the most disadvantaged in our community will suffer yet again. For the wealthy in our community, such as a minister of the Crown—the minister for health, Mr Abbott—an extra $200 or $500 is not hard to find. For those types of people, it will guarantee that their health care needs and those of their families, their children and their parents are met, because they can afford it. But, for middle-income Australians and the poorer members of our community, another $200 or $500 before higher rebates kick in will not be easy to find. That effectively means that, unfortunately for the health of this nation, a sizeable section of the Australian community is potentially going to place its health outcomes at serious risk. In the long term, that is going to cost the Australian public more because of the potential deterioration in the health of Australians.

As all the available statistical information proves, the least wealthy in our community face poorer health outcomes than the wealthiest in the Australian community. There is real pressure on these people at the moment, and this potential change in the safety net will only make it more difficult for these people to try to attend to the essentials of life. Lower income households spend just $22 a week on health, whilst the wealthiest households spend about $77 a week on health. This means that there are people in our community who are simply going to go without treatment because they cannot pay for health care. This is on top of all the other pressures that we are experiencing as a community at the moment.

I will just refer in passing to the spiralling costs of fuel. To be truthful, there is little we can do at this point because of international pressures, but we have people now at the lower income levels who have to make decisions about whether to fill the tank every week or every second week, whether to put food on the table for their children, whether they can afford a school excursion or whether they can afford a pair of runners necessary for the kids to put shoes on their feet. They are the hard decisions that Australian battlers have to make at this point in time. They have to make choices about whether to spend a dollar on food for the table or whether to use the money to fill the tank. On top of that, they are now going to be in serious difficulties with respect to their health care and that of their families.

Rather than making it harder for them, I think we as a community ought to be trying to help these people to maintain their health and, where possible, improve their health care. The truth is that many of these people will not be able to meet the increase in costs associated with the proposed changes to the Medicare safety net. That means, beyond any doubt, that under the Howard government universal health care has disappeared. It fulfils the long-term ambition of the Prime Minister to always develop a two-tiered system—one system for the most wealthy and one system for the least wealthy. In essence, more than ever those with less just have to go without.

But that is not new; it is the philosophy of the Howard government right across the board. It is about accepting a growing divide in the Australian community between the haves and the have-nots. One million people who otherwise would have qualified for the safety net will no longer qualify under the higher thresholds. That is a sizeable section of the Australian community—one million people. They are the people already doing it the toughest. They are likely to be from middle Australia or the poorest parts of our community. The safety net is highly skewed towards the wealthiest electorates and away from the poorest electorates in Australia. Some of the poorer electorates, I might say, are represented by coalition members, especially in regional communities. They ought to seriously think about the impact of the changes to the Medicare safety net before the House.

The proposed increase will exacerbate the situation. In particular, as I have stated, people in rural and regional Australia will suffer. For them, access to specialist services and diagnostic care often involves taking time off from work, at additional cost, or taking time away from their families to travel to the services, with additional costs. That is in addition to all the proposed additional costs which are going to be put in place by the bill before the House. It is in stark contrast to the proposals by the opposition for a decent, attainable, universal health care system. We should remember that, during the last election campaign, Labor proposed the provision of specialist outpatient clinics and access to diagnostic technologies in public hospitals—a huge proposal. People who need specialist care or diagnostic services would have been able to access them with no gaps and no out-of-pocket expenses.

The Labor proposal entails a system which does not send price signals to service providers to take a slice of the pie from the safety net. This system focuses on the real problems of the less well off in our community, such as their inability to pay out-of-pocket expenses for health care services that they and their families need. Labor is for a universal health care system, not health care and health outcomes based on whether or not you can afford to pay for them. That is the crux of the debate.

Labor does not support this bill. It condemns the government’s two-tiered approach to Medicare and health outcomes. I totally reject the statement made by the Minister for Health and Ageing at the beginning of his second reading speech to the bill, where he said:

quote.para: The Howard government is committed to protecting and strengthening Medicare and delivering high quality, affordable health care to all Australians.

speech.para: The bill does the exact opposite. As an alternative, I say on behalf of the opposition that Labor in government would deliver a fairer, more equitable Medicare system which would strive for good health outcomes for all Australians irrespective of their level of wealth and which would provide access to health care services on the basis of need, not the capacity to pay for health care services or to buy health outcomes.

I will finish on this point: given the example of this Medicare safety net bill and a range of other examples over the last 9½ years, the Australian public has to seriously think about whether it will take the Howard government’s word seriously yet again. The government says one thing during election campaigns and does another thing after elections. From as early as I can remember, I was taught that if you give your word you keep it. No-one can believe the minister for health, Tony Abbott, when he says yet again to the Australian public, ‘I propose an ironclad guarantee.’ I suggest that when he says that in the future he will be proposing a deliberate lie. He will go out of his way to mislead the voting public and con them with one thing before the election and then walk away from the undertaking after the election. The opposition is correct to raise these issues, because this is a debate not just about the Medicare safety net; it is a debate about honesty and integrity in government and whether you can trust the Howard government yet again.

talk.start.para: —The Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005 attempts to modify the extended Medicare safety net, which came into effect on 12 March 2004. Under this so-called safety net, Medicare meets 80 per cent of out-of-pocket expenses for professional services provided out of hospital once an annual threshold is reached—all a little complex for the average family. The annual threshold is currently $300, as indexed, for concession card holders and families in receipt of the family tax benefit part A; and $700, as indexed, for all other persons. Indexation is applied annually to the thresholds as per section 10A of the Health Insurance Act 1973. In accordance with the legislation, the thresholds were indexed on 1 January 2005 at $306.90 for the lower threshold and at $716.10 for the higher threshold.

speech.para: Safety net thresholds have been increased because the government have suddenly realised this is costing them more. The thresholds will be increased to $500 for concessional individuals and families in receipt of FTBA and to $1,000 for all other individuals and families. As the thresholds are to be set at $500 and $1,000 for 2006, indexation will not be applied to these amounts for 2006, but will be applied from 1 January 2007 and will be indexed annually thereafter, as prescribed in section 10A of the act.

This legislation is not acceptable in its current form and is a broken promise from the election. The Minister for Health and Ageing sold the Australian people a big lie. This government should be criticised for the decision to increase the amount people must pay for health care before the Commonwealth’s Medicare safety net catches them so soon after the election, where it was a foundation of the Liberal Party health policy. But they deserve far more censure for adopting this safety net in the first place. It was Medicare fool’s gold, bad politics and worse economics. It was exactly the sort of expensive tripe the health minister has been bribing the electorate with since the wobbles at the start of 2001—costly policies, poorly targeted, that are politically difficult for him now to claw back.

We had a universal Medicare system where everybody had access to health care whatever their circumstances. Those who could paid a levy through their income tax, and those who could not could access all the essential services free of charge. That was a Labor reality and it worked well. People could take out private health insurance if they wanted to for elective care but, if they could not afford it, they could still get proper care. There were no second-class citizens under Labor.

Hospitals could also get access to proper funding, were not fighting with private hospitals for private insurance money and were funded to do the emergency job that they are equipped to do. Even private hospitals refer patients when they cannot deal with them. What have we got with this situation? A huge load on the federal government’s budget that they have decided they cannot afford. A recent article by Leeder and Boxhall published on New Matilda puts it more clearly. It says:

quote.para: Health accounts for a substantial and growing proportion of the government’s total budget and of national expenditure - in 1991-92, according to the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare health costs amounted to 8.1% of GDP and 9.5% by 2002-03. The Departments of Treasury and Finance undertook a detailed costing analysis of the safety net policy prior to the election. The department identified the likely cost blow-out. When quizzed after the election about this assessment, Abbott pleaded ignorance, claiming that departmental officials had not told him about it before the election. This is reminiscent of other missing intelligence concerning the ‘children overboard’ scandal, when the Prime Minister claimed that he (like Mr Abbott in the next election) was never informed that the children had not been thrown overboard.

Yet, the safety net policy design faults should have been obvious to Mr Abbott’s staff, even if Treasury had kept the unworkability of the safety net to themselves. Perhaps Mr Abbott himself might have guessed that it would not work. Because the safety net is an uncapped subsidy for the cost of medical treatment, it was inevitable that Medicare items would expand to include services previously not covered (like a lot of fringe services for women undergoing IVF) and that medical fees would also rise. These flaws in the policy should have rung alarm bells for the government for two reasons: first, an understanding of them is basic economics, and second, the precedent of what happened with the private health insurance rebate.

speech.para: I am not an expert on things medical or economic, but I believe that the flaws that these people are pointing out are very serious and that the government is just flicking them off as though the health of some 500,000 Australian people does not matter. Where have we seen this recently? Perhaps with the Prime Minister’s best friend, George Dubya, flicking off those unfortunates trying to survive in New Orleans.

Following the estimates investigation after the budget this year, it was plain that the government must have known the problems. Our shadow minister Julia Gillard pointed out in an Age commentary on 28 May 2005:

quote.para: The inconsistencies that have been revealed in Senate estimates have revealed the Howard Government’s true agenda on the Medicare safety net. The Howard Government never intended to keep it.
The Medicare safety net was a cruel hoax and Senator Minchin clearly played his part.

speech.para: And the health minister still did not know there was going to be a blow-out? Even Senator Harradine picked up that this legislation was a pig in a poke. He said:

quote.para: In negotiations with the Government it was clear it was not willing to put in the required money to provide some guarantee of reviving Medicare bulk-billing rates. So the only way to offer some protection for people against high out-of-pocket, non-hospital medical costs was to have a safety net.

A safety net is necessary because medical costs are increasing, but the insurance coverage offered to patients through Medicare is not keeping up. The increasing gap between the Medical Benefits Schedule and what doctors charge is hurting Australians.

... as bulk billing becomes less available, fees become more common. The safety net is about giving low-income families real cash relief because they face real fees ... Now those families face an extra $200 before any relief.

speech.para: The doctors themselves are not impressed with the changes, as can be gathered from an article in New Doctor in 2001. This article points out that a health scheme based on public funding is ‘best at cost containment, equity and efficiency’. It says:

quote.para: The Federal Government continues to express support for Medicare. However, some of its actions suggest it is slowly moving away from the Medicare system as it was originally conceived.

Instead of putting extra resources into solving real problems of the public health system, the Government has put these into private health insurance—despite its demonstrated inefficiencies and poor value. The provision of massive subsidies totalling some $2.5 billion per annum to private health insurance contradicts the international evidence about the best way to fund health services.

International experience demonstrates health systems which rely predominantly on public funding and public provision of services are generally best at cost containment, equity and efficiency. While Australia has a mixed system the Federal Government appears bent on shifting us closer to a publicly funded private provision model. International evidence proves that reliance on private health insurance cannot achieve universal access and equity.

speech.para: These arguments reflect that many people have assessed this new Medicare and found it wanting. With these proposed changes, we have a scheme that is costing the government more than it needs to. The government is continuing to prop up the private insurance companies and is now making pay those who can least afford to and those who now rely on the government’s safety net. I can see many families just not going to the doctor because they cannot afford those first payments. If they have to see a specialist and the dollars mount up for them, it is going to be less and less likely that people on fixed incomes will take this up.

This costs the government in the long run. But it is a way this federal government transfers costs to the state. Hospitals have to pick up these cases when they become critical. People who do not go to the doctor when they are ill and who end up critical are picked up by the state public health systems. We are not like America, and I do not want to see us copy these American ways, where you have to pay up front to see a doctor and you can be admitted to hospital only if you have the cash in your hand. This is what the federal government wants—everybody to pay.

It has been bad enough with the Telstra debate in this lower house. Few people could actually comment on the legislation in detail as it was not introduced into the parliament until late in yesterday’s sitting. Parliament must be allowed to debate these issues properly and to scrutinise legislation. This bill is yet another example of sloppy and rushed workmanship. The government is hoping to solve a problem that it has created by knocking off all the good points of Medicare.

I am not happy with this legislation. It once again waters down the whole purpose of Medicare and sets the agenda for getting rid of Medicare altogether. I am very worried and very disappointed that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health and Ageing have broken their promises again. This minister is not on the case of health; he has failed. He has shown that he cannot win arguments in his cabinet—or that he never wanted to. There are ironclad guarantees and millions of dollars spent on advertising. This was a political exercise by this government that the Australian people should remember. They lied to the Australian people and this bill shows that they have.

talk.start.para: (Mr Wilkie)—The member for Lyons should know that the word ‘lie’ should not be used in speeches and will withdraw the remark.
—I thought, with respect, that ‘lie’ was okay as long it was not appointed to any individual. I am talking generally.
—It will be withdrawn in this case.

—I will, of course, withdraw. As always, as the founder of Medicare, Labor will make good health policy, protect Medicare and have good health outcomes for all Australians, as we have done in the past.

—Before I call the member for Blaxland, I would like to acknowledge the presence in the public gallery of members of various Lions clubs from throughout the Canberra region who have been meeting with the Lions Club of the Australian Parliament. It is good to see you here.

—There are lies, damned lies and statistics. It would not matter which measurement from those three that you chose, the Minister for Health and Ageing would be found wanting. In all my time here I have never seen anything so ephemeral as what we see before us today, statistically put line by line in this flimsy bill, the Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005—except the outcomes for the people who have been conned by the minister for health and by the Prime Minister; less so by the Treasurer, because he did not involve himself in this as much as the others. People have been conned for more than a year, from November 2003, when this was first mooted.

speech.para: When the government first looked at bringing in a Medicare safety net it was a ‘magnificent idea’ from the minister for health—someone on the way up, someone charging towards the future leadership of the party. It was some bright idea from a former practising journalist that would grab the attention not only of the media but also of the public at large. What a ‘beaut little idea’, in the words of the Prime Minister—a beaut little thing to have to fix the out-of-pocket expenses of people who had to spend extraordinary amounts in the medical area. Once people reached a certain level of expenditure it would refund 80 per cent of those out-of-pocket expenses. So if someone went to a GP and the GP did not charge the prescribed fee but charged $100, or if they went to an obstetrician and the obstetrician, as a guiding specialist, charged $10,000, both the $100 and the $10,000 could be taken into account as out-of-pocket expenses.

Everyone in this country knows that specialists are more expensive than GPs. I think that by now, since March 2004 when the original bill was before parliament, there is not a person in the parliament or in the community at large who does not know that—apart from the minister for health. The penny does not seem to have dropped yet for the minister for health, who has attempted to defend himself month after month, week after week, in tragic incident after tragic incident in relation to the core of this bill. Even the minister for health should have known, given the advice that the people in his department gave him before this bill first came in.

When the government were first looking at this they were told that for health care card holders, pensioners and concessionaries there needed to be a level of about $500 before people could claim out-of-pocket expenses and a level of about $1,000 before people who were non health care card holders and non-concessional people could claim out-of-pocket expenses. But, politics being the way that it is, with compromise ruling so much, in order to buy off the votes of some senators and to do a deal with them, they came up with a different set of figures: $300 for people who were concessional and $700 for people who were not. The secretary of the department, the other advisers in the department of health, the people in the ministerial office and the very minister himself knew what was advised, but they also knew and were party to those lower figures.

When they signed up to that we were told that there would not be any blow-out, that this was a great new thing to give to Australians—a terrific thing; you could fix their out-of-pocket expenses. It was just like all of the rest of Medicare—the Medicare benefits scheme and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme—because it is all demand driven and, if people took it up, that would be okay because that would just show how successful it was.

I do not think I have seen any example in the time I have been here, since 15 June 1996, to match the effrontery of what has happened in this area or the boneheadedness of the minister in initially denying and then denying time and time again that there was a blow-out in costs. That was matched only by the Prime Minister in election mode from March until October 2004 and by the fact that what is being changed here has its very genesis in the design of this bill. It is structurally flawed. It is structurally boneheaded.

It is a bright idea to go and buy off the electorate and say, ‘We understand you’ve got lots of out-of-pocket expenses; we understand how much a specialist costs; we understand that they’ve got no price signals out there, except for the other people in the market.’ Anyone who has any experience with some groups of specialists allied to the AMA, particularly those hip specialists under one surgeon who for years was a formative influence on the Liberal Party, knows that the price signals simply were not out there to hold some of those back, in the most effective trade unions in the country, the medical associations of specialists, which regulate the number of people who can actually be in their speciality and then regulate the fees. They may do a great job but they are not dumb. The minister might be but the specialists are not.
What we have in this flimsy bill is very small but very telling for the majority of Australians. Most of it deals with subsection 8(1A) of the Health Insurance Act 1973. Section 1 of the bill states:

quote.para: Omit “$300”, substitute “$500”.

speech.para: That is how brutal this is. Section 2—we are almost halfway through the bill—states:

quote.para: Omit “$700”, substitute “$1,000”.

speech.para: Section 3 states:

quote.para: Omit “$300”, substitute “$500”.

speech.para: And, just for a bit of variation, section 4 amends subsection 10A(1) of the act to omit ‘2005’ and make it ‘2007’.

With this flimsiest of bills presented to this parliament there is an impact on all those people who were conned by the minister for health and the Prime Minister prior to the last election. People believed that they would be able to claim 80 per cent of out-of-pocket expenses. And they believed, they were told, that it would not actually cost that much. But if you look at the work done by Angela Pratt in the Parliamentary Library there is an interesting set of figures and an interesting time line in terms of how much things cost. There are also some interesting statements around when this bill was introduced.

Don’t you just love the Prime Minister? This was to come into force in March 2004 and there was a nice run-up from that date to the election. At multiple times and in multiple places—like over a little cuppa at the Colac Otways Performing Arts and Cultural Centre—the Prime Minister was asked what he thought about the government’s great new scheme. He said, in part:

quote.para: So what that does is to provide a peace of mind, a security against unexpectedly large medical expenses ...

speech.para: It is what you would expect him to say—‘You can be very relaxed and comfortable about this. This is something that we’ve got for you.’ A little later, on 12 May last year, he said:

quote.para: Now, that new safety net is funded in the budget, although it was announced several months ago but it is funded in the budget.’

speech.para: In July 2004, after some criticism that it was not sustainable because of its design—the fact that there were no price signals and no caps at all on this—at the Solomon Community Hall morning tea in the Kalymnian hall, the Prime Minister says:

quote.para: ... most recently through the introduction of the Medicare safety net, which is daily looking after more and more Australian families. They are some of our goals, not only for the next three years but, indeed, for the next ten.

speech.para: What a forward-looking, visionary Prime Minister who looks to his next 10 years in office bringing this sort of thing to the Australian people. He crowned that on 28 August 2004 by saying:

quote.para: As the months go by the 220,000 Australians that have already benefited from the safety net will grow, and grow, and grow.

speech.para: And the price to the Commonwealth, I would add, will grow like topsy—because since November 2003 that is exactly what has happened. But to give him his due, the Prime Minister twice again, once before the election, reiterated just what a terrific thing this was and effectively what he thought of the minister for health for coming up with this bright idea. In a radio interview with Ray Hadley on 2GB, he said:

quote.para: In fact, we have a better Medicare system now than our opponents are offering because we have this new beaut safety net. If you’re a cardholder or a family tax benefit recipient and your ... out of pocket expenses go over $300 a year, you get 80 per cent of the excess back ...

speech.para: And didn’t he think that was wonderful to campaign on for the October election. But just before the election some concern was voiced dramatically. The Prime Minister, just after the election of course, came to a bit of a different view. What had been argued for a year all of a sudden was a bit different. He talked about the increase in numbers from a quarter of a million to many more. In fact, it had gone up into the 400,000s and then the 600,000s—600,465, I think. Within a few months of it coming in, we had 650,000 Australians claiming. But on 8 October 2004 at a press conference in Sydney, he was asked about the safety net in a sort of roundabout way, ‘Isn’t it true that it is costing more money and something will have to be done about it? Are you going to keep it? The Prime Minister replied:

quote.para: Well I commit to keeping it in place but I also commit to taking whatever action is needed if there is clear evidence that anybody’s trying to exploit it.

speech.para: Those who were trying to exploit this were the minister for health, the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the rest of the government. They were the ones exploiting a system that they had introduced. They were the ones who had tried to convince Australians that they should take it up in droves—and so they did. The Prime Minister continued:

quote.para: But bear in mind that Medicare is a demand driven policy, there is no cap on the availability of Medicare services, it’s one of the fundamentals.

speech.para: There is also another fundamental of Medicare: there are price caps, there are regulations and there are regulatory mechanisms to take care of the price pressures so that it does not explode as this has done. What is the key difference, as pointed out by Angela Pratt in the Bills Digest and others who have commented on this? The key difference is that, when you go to the extra charges over and above the scheduled Medicare fees—we know that many GPs out there do not charge the scheduled Medicare fees; we know that specialists certainly do not charge them—there are no regulatory, price or capping mechanisms to keep this in control.

This is a policy that is completely out of control. We have seen not only an escalation in the number of people but also an escalation in the cost. We also know—and this is completely evident, if you look at who benefits from this most—that it is weighted towards Liberal electorates. It is weighted towards electorates where there is a higher per capita income. It is weighted against electorates like mine. Indeed, in the electorate of the member for Bradfield, the safety net rebate paid as at September 2004 was $911,828, with an average of $1,759 for those people who claimed. If you go to the next page of the document, you see that in the electorate of Blaxland 212,186 people claimed, their claims averaging $839. You can run through every Labor and National Party electorate—because National Party electorates are usually, with ours, the least well-off electorates—and you will find the same kinds of figures repeated again and again. This is a policy that gives to those who have and to those who choose to have higher expenditure and to run that higher expenditure in a particular period of time.

In the past our tax system has generally taken care of this.
