Labor condemned this proposal when it came in—this bright idea from the minister for health—and we pointed out that it was more important to reinvigorate bulk-billing Australia wide. The other day, the minister for health—extremely ungraciously and very clumsily—tried to make a point not only about me but also about another member and the fact that we had high bulk-billing rates in our electorates. Yes, we do—and, yes, I said it was under threat from this government.

One of the reasons it is under threat is the dopey idea that the minister for health came up with that you should bring in this Medicare safety net, which imperils the good governance of the rest of health policy in Australia. The dimensions of that are pointed out in the parliamentary digest on a time line that the Parliamentary Library has provided. Even with the original figuring that was given in November 2003, when the proposal first surfaced, when the government thought the levels should be $500 and $1,000—those contained in this flimsy here before the government did its deal with the senators—what was the expected cost of this in the first four years of its operation? It was $266.3 million. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will not be surprised—and no-one else in Australia will be surprised now—that, by March 2004, as a result of the new thresholds, the government expected the cost to be $440 million.

Yet some few months later, just prior to the election, that was denied by the health minister, denied by the Prime Minister and denied by the Treasurer. So what was the cost? The cost came from a reputable source. Ken Henry is not only a good economist but a good servant of the public. As Secretary of the Treasury, he released the following in September 2004:

quote.para: Treasury figures show the cost of the Safety Net as $142 million higher than the approximately $120 million originally forecast for the 2004-05 financial year. Subsequently, the cost over four years (2004-05 to 2007-08) was estimated to have blown out to approximately $1.05 billion.

speech.para: That is a pretty big blow-out. That was before the election and that was from Treasury. They have tried hard, but they have never been completely accurate in their determinations of what the cost would be. And I tell you what: it has escalated somewhat.

In April 2005, fully a year and a month after this bill was introduced into the House and brought into action, the Prime Minister—having earlier had a go at the member for Hotham, saying that the idea that the cost would be $1 billion was completely ludicrous—confirmed that, if the current threshold levels were maintained, the cost of the safety net would be $1.4 billion over the period to 30 June 2008. And guess what? Up to 30 June 2009, the cost will be $1.65 billion—that is, 400 per cent more; four times the projected cost at the lower levels because the lower levels had expanded by four. Accordingly, the government announced that it would move to increase the safety net thresholds.

We have here the government’s determination that they will go back up to those thresholds. But what has been pointed out, not only in the advice given by the Parliamentary Library in their digest but by commentators on health Australia wide, is that this bill addresses threshold levels. Maybe it will work for a few months or even six months; the government may be able to constrain the cost of this. But this will not fix the structural faults that are inherent in this bill. The reason this measure was so appealing to the people who have used it in extraordinary numbers—650,000 in just a few months—is that there is no cap. There is no regulation. There is no pull-back, apart from these levels, and there is no reason whatsoever to rein this in. This is dumb policy which prejudices the Commonwealth’s control of health funding in Australia.

The minister for health has put himself in a position where he has no way out. Prior to the election, he told us that there was no way at all that the $300 and the $700 would ever be changed. Ticky Fullerton gave him a series of questions and his answer on whether these thresholds would be changed was:

motion.para: That is an absolutely rock solid, iron-clad commitment.

speech.para: The Treasurer even jumped in and said:

quote.para: The parameters of the Medicare safety net will not change.

speech.para: This tells you a little about this health minister. I will finish with a quote from him—it is a beaut:

quote.para: The MBS is not a budget-limited bureaucratically controlled program; it’s a demand driven patient-initiated program. That’s the way the MBS has always been and that’s the way it will always continue under this government and that’s one of the reasons why medical services in the community have been much more effective and much more efficient than some other aspects of the overall health system.

speech.para: If you believe that, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, you will believe anything. This is really silly. As I said at the start, we have lies, damned lies and statistics. The statistics involved in looking at this problem say that this has betrayed the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth’s demand for structure in the health system. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005 is to amend the Health Insurance Act to increase the annual thresholds above which benefits under the extended Medicare safety net are payable. The thresholds will increase from $306.90 to $500 for concession card holders and other low-income families and from $716.10 to $1,000 for all other families and individuals from 1 January next year. That is the summary of the bill, according to the Bills Digest. But we know what this bill really signifies.

speech.para: We know this bill is a reflection of the government’s failure to concern themselves with ordinary battling families; we understand that. We know this bill is also a reflection of the government’s failure to understand the economic consequences of their own promises; we understand that. We also know that, once the government did understand the consequences of their promises, they did not tell the public. They did not tell the Australian public the consequences of the government promising a particular safety net before the election until after the election.

There are all sorts of words people could use to describe that behaviour but there is no need because the Australian public are not foolish. When someone comes to them and says, ‘I promise that I’ll do this. I’ll personally make an absolutely ironclad commitment to undertake the following,’ and then waits until after the general election to say, ‘Look, hold on a second here. We looked at the figures and we can’t deliver this,’ then the Australian community know exactly what has gone on. They know exactly what the minister for health has done by not coming clean before the election.

While we are in possession of those facts, one of the reasons that led us to conclude that the minister, the government and this Prime Minister have no regard for the Australian people who need decent health services is that they were aware of the cost blow-outs prior to the election but failed to indicate that publicly. This is very reminiscent of the Telstra fiasco, the Telstra scandal, where matters have been brought to the attention of the executive government and they have held them back—not sharing them with mum and dad shareholders—despite the reality that those facts in the possession of the government could possibly have adverse consequences for ordinary families—families that were encouraged by this government to buy the shares in the first place.

The situation with the Medicare safety net is comparable to the Telstra scandal that has beset this government. The Minister for Health and Ageing was well aware that the promise that he undertook to make to Australian users of health services was not sustainable in the least. I know that earlier members commented on some of these facts. I would like to draw the attention of the House to a number of the calculations that were made by the department from the time of the promise to the post election reversal of that promise.

In November 2003, the safety net as originally proposed—I remind the House that is with $500 and $1,000 thresholds—was expected to cost $266.3 million in the first four years of its operation—just over a quarter of a billion dollars was calculated as the cost by the department. In less than four months the department revised the four-year cost of the safety net as a result of the reduced thresholds negotiated, as we all recall, in the Senate and estimated the cost to be $440 million, an amount that was still sustainable. Treasury figures in September 2004 showed the cost of the safety net as $142 million higher than the approximately $120 million originally forecast for the financial year 2004-05. Subsequently, the cost over four years was estimated to have blown out by $1.05 billion.

These facts were in the possession of the government prior to the election. I suppose we cannot blame the minister for health entirely and that we have to assume that, when you are making such a huge public policy decision as the government was making, it would involve the finance ministers and the Prime Minister. We now know as a result of the embarrassing backflip by the Minister for Health and Ageing that the government confirmed in that month that the cost of the safety net, if the current threshold levels were maintained, would be $1.4 billion over the period to 30 June 2008 and $1.65 billion to 30 June 2009. Accordingly, the government announced that it would move to increase the safety net thresholds.

I have put it as plainly as I can. People say that a lot of politicking goes on in this place. I do not have to use any hyperbole to explain the behaviour of the minister and the executive government. Ordinary Australian families will understand that. Families who are not able to apply for the safety net now because they do not meet the threshold know exactly what this government has done to them. The awful truth is that it is going to affect the lower income earners more than the higher income earners—again. We see not only the failure by this government to economically determine the costs of their health policy decision but, when they look to correct their fundamental error—an error that was not revealed to the public before the election—that they choose to hurt people who can afford it least. The government choose to hurt families who can afford it least.

It is not surprising that earlier speakers talked about the inequity that we have in this current system whereby, because of the safety net, members from wealthier constituencies are likely to receive a larger piece of the pie. This is because of the way in which some families are able to expend on health care as compared to others. It is quite clear, in particular, that many seats held by government members in metropolitan capital cities and some other areas will receive a higher proportion of the safety net as a result of the proposed changes to the threshold. This will compound the inequity in the current system. It is most disappointing that there have been no government members willing to raise concerns about this matter. Whilst I have already said the majority of the government members may see their seat being favoured in this distorted backflip policy, the fact is that there are also government members holding seats, particularly in country Australia, which in terms of socioeconomic factors are more akin to the city areas that do not have a great deal of wealth. Those particular seats will also suffer.

I would have expected, for example, the forthright and outspoken member for Indi—who, by the way, notwithstanding the boasts of the Minister for Health and Ageing, still has a seat that has less than 50 per cent bulk-billing and has a socioeconomic dimension that would mean that these changes will not benefit her seat—to have come to this place and have said: ‘Hold on a second. This is not right for the constituents of Indi.’ I am not sure how often the member for Indi actually visits her seat. She does speak her mind, I am told; I read about it in the paper all the time. I would have thought that she would have had the decency and the integrity to consider remarking on the adverse consequences for her constituents.

There are other country seats that will not benefit as a result of these changes. I think it is incumbent on members to come in and explain why they would support a bill that is going to hurt the people who voted for them to come here and represent them. If I can put it another way, it is incumbent on those members to explain why they will not speak out when the government is choosing to hurt those constituents who are from low-socioeconomic families, who have difficulty in making ends meet and who therefore would hope that their federal member in this place would at least raise concerns. But we have not heard from them. In fact, in the long list of speakers on this bill, I do not know if any government members have spoken at all.

We are talking about a fundamental public policy. We are talking about the Medicare safety net. I do not know what the government members have to be embarrassed about. If they truly supported the Minister for Health and Ageing, they would show their support for him—and indeed the finance minister and the Prime Minister—by coming in here and defending the government’s position with respect to this bill. But there has not been one government member—certainly not one today and I do not know whether there has been one at all—speaking on this bill and defending the actions of the government. There has not been one government member defending the government backflip in telling the Australian public one thing before the election and another after the election—explaining that and defending why that happened.

This bill shows either the government lacking integrity when it comes to being honest with the Australian people in terms of public policy or a lack of economic credibility, because the blow-out in cost of this policy was so astronomical that the Treasurer had to rein in the Minister for Health and Ageing, to embarrass him, as did the Prime Minister, and explain to him that his promise was not in any way sustainable. It really did show a lack of economic credibility by the government. Either that or it understood the consequences—exactly understood that it could not sustain the policy—but chose not to tell anybody until people cast their vote in the 2004 ballot. Which one would the government wish me to choose: that it is economically incapable of calculating a very important public policy like the Medicare safety net or that it deliberately chose to say one thing before the election and wait until after the election to say another? Either way this government is damned by its own behaviour. Either it is incompetent or it has misled the public. It has been loose with the truth. It has not been honest in explaining what could occur, given the open-ended nature of the policy.

We are getting sick of the walking cliche—the Minister for Health and Ageing—coming in here and answering about 50 questions with the same answer. It really is getting a little tiring. If he only has one sentence in the box, why don’t we just get a dummy in here and pull the string? Because we know that the government are not the best friend that Medicare has ever had. If the government could get away with destroying Medicare, they would do it. We know what the Prime Minister’s longstanding position is and what he would love to do to Medicare. We know that position is shared by the Minister for Health and Ageing and, indeed, by many other frontbenchers and the majority of the government. We really do not need to hear any more cliches from the Minister for Health and Ageing; we need to see him focused on his job. We need to see him not worrying about the internal workings of the New South Wales Liberal Party, not making off remarks about former leaders of the New South Wales Liberal Party but focusing on his job and delivering decent health services to this country.

talk.start.para: —It is a pleasure for me to have this opportunity to talk about the Health Insurance Amendment (Medicare Safety-nets) Bill 2005. The safety net came into effect in March 2004. This bill proposes two amendments which will put into place changes to the thresholds for the Medicare safety net and which the government wants to have come into effect on 1 January 2006. For the sake of explaining the mechanics of the safety net, I refer to a note done by Angela Pratt from the Parliamentary Library:

quote.para: Under the Medicare Safety Net, patients are reimbursed for 80 per cent of their out-of-pocket costs (that is, the cost over and above the relevant Medicare rebate) for medical treatment received in a non-hospital setting, once a certain threshold is reached in a calendar year. This includes out-of-pocket costs for things like GP and specialist consultations, and diagnostic tests such as X-rays and pathology exams.

speech.para: I read that very specifically because it is important that we all understand exactly what is being changed here. The government set the original thresholds for the safety net after quite a deal of argy-bargy, if I may say so, with minor party senators. They set the thresholds for access to the safety net at $300 for concession card holders and family tax benefit B recipients and $700 for all other people. We opposed the policy at the time, on the grounds that we believed it would prove to be inequitable and it would have an inflationary effect on health prices. Of course, we were criticised and told that we were wrong and that we had got it all completely skew-whiff—that in fact this was the best thing the government could ever think of for Medicare. We disputed that at the time and we still do.

In 2004, in the lead-up to the election and during the campaign, extensive government advertising across all forms of media from around March to June, and adding to the previous minister’s A Fairer Medicare package, cost around $20 million. In other words, about $20 million of taxpayers’ money was spent out there trying to convince people that this idea of the safety net with threshold levels of $300 and $700 respectively was really worth the consideration of the community.

Serious concerns emerged after this came into place. It was evident within three months of the safety net being in place that higher numbers of families and single people were registering. I believe the government’s estimate was that about 450,000 people would register in one year, yet in the first few months alone almost 650,000 people qualified. This meant that Treasury figures released during the election campaign in September last year showed more than a doubling of the approximate $120 million originally forecast for the year 2004-05 in costs. Therefore the total cost over the out years would have reached over $1 billion, more than double the original projections.

It has to be said that it was not just us on this side of this House who were alarmed; there were journalists and other commentators involved in health issues, professional organisations and people writing commentary who were all saying the same thing as us, all singing from the same song sheet—that is, of course, that the costs were going to be very difficult to contain. However, the minister and other senior ministers through the whole of the election campaign period continued to deny that we had a problem on our hands.

There was all this pressure on the system, against the background that the minister had bargained the original bill into reality. At the risk of repeating what has been said many times in this place—but I must—it was during that election campaign that the minister gave that famous and now sadly infamous rock solid, ironclad guarantee that the thresholds would be maintained at those original levels that he had bargained into reality in the first place. Despite all the evidence, despite everybody saying it was just not mathematically financially possible, he said nothing would change. He gave that wonderful guarantee to the community of this country. They wonder why sometimes people get a little bit cynical, to put it kindly, about undertakings given by this government. Here is yet another example where an undertaking—in fact, more than an undertaking: a rock solid guarantee, an ironclad thing—was given, and yet it was just disposed of at the flick of a wrist.

From that point during the election campaign we fast-forward to April this year. The government then released figures showing a further increase in those projected safety net costs. The Prime Minister went on ABC radio saying that if those current thresholds were maintained the cost of the safety net would be $1.65 billion over the four years to June 2009. This was almost four times the original projections. This government, the Treasurer and all these people are supposed to be in charge of this economy. Everybody was saying this could not be done. Everybody was saying this could not be maintained. We had an ironclad guarantee from the minister. Yet, in April this year, the Prime Minister said, ‘I’m terribly sorry, but we think we got it wrong; it’s a little bit too expensive.’ So the government says after all of this that it must now change these thresholds to the safety net at the lower level from $300 to $500 and at the higher level from $700 to $1,000. To say those families and single people out there were misled is an understatement. It was more than misleading; it was a dramatically misleading action by this government.

How many people do we think might be affected as a result of this change? According to the department at Senate estimates in June, if current thresholds were maintained, in 2006 we would have 2.5 million people qualifying. Under these increased levels, approximately 1.5 million people are expected to qualify. What is the difference? One million people out there who have been told by this government in the past that they would have access to this financial assistance with their medical costs will now not receive it.

I represent an electorate here that in statistical terms is relatively well off. We still have ordinary families on ordinary incomes in that electorate. There are people who find it really hard even to find a doctor in some parts of my electorate. Why isn’t all the government effort going into making more GPs available? Why isn’t the government effort going into ensuring that people can actually find a doctor and see them when they need to, especially when they have families and young children in tow, and they really need to be able to do that and afford to do it? Instead, we have a government that stands up and basically just misleads the community, tells them whatever it wants and does whatever it can in a campaign leading up to an election to ensure in some way that it gets those extra votes.

After the election, it is another ball game altogether. After the election, the government said that we were wrong. But no way were we wrong. We knew all along that these costs were going to blow out, and so did a lot of other people. I believe many senior members of this government knew that as well, and they did nothing about it until after the campaign, after the election, after winning the majority in both houses. Then they think they can just do what they want.

The people in my community and, I believe, in the communities around Australia are waking up to this. They are no longer going to be willing to be taken for granted on issues as important as this. This is fundamental to the economic wellbeing of families around Australia. I am sorry to think that I have been witness to such a deceit by this government of Australian families and the Australian people.
Debate interupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being almost 9.00 pm, I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday the last elements of the Israeli army left their posts around the settlements in Gaza. The Israeli army remains in control of all border areas. Gaza is now a Palestinian ghetto—a prison for its 1½ million people. All flows of people and goods must pass through Israeli border controls, which has resulted in the World Bank’s reporting that unemployment and poverty will rise in Gaza. As the world watched the tearful removal of illegal Jewish settlers from Gaza, its attention was turned away from other forced removals. While 8,000 illegal Israeli settlers will be compensated by as much as $A500,000 each, there was no compensation—not one cent—for the 23,000 Palestinians in Gaza whose homes were bulldozed by the Israeli army.

speech.para: Illegal settlements to the east of Jerusalem will be expanded by up to 15,000 people, in defiance of President George Bush’s road map for peace. The ever expanding wall now cuts the occupied West Bank in half and, in parts, will be 25 kilometres inside the green line which defines the occupied West Bank. Palestinians have been cut off from their work, their fields and families without any compensation. While there was world attention on the tearful settlers, there were few tears for the 680 Palestinian children shot dead by the Israeli army in the past five years. If the 1½ million Palestinians in Gaza have anything to celebrate, it will be the return of the 25 per cent of their land that a mere 8,000 settlers illegally occupied; however, the Israelis can celebrate their relief from the cost of $500 million a year to watch over those illegal settlers.

Israel’s attempt to colonise Gaza has failed. It was hoped that, by circling its settlement wagons, the cavalry would keep the natives on their reservation. But it was too costly. Now Israel will rule Gaza like a walled ghetto, a giant penal colony, a concentration camp. Israel controls all air, sea and land borders. The same is happening in the West Bank as the illegal wall cuts it into small, walled ghettos and completely cuts off the Palestinian state from its heart in East Jerusalem.

Physically, Palestine exists only as a few ink blots on a map but, in spirit, Palestine possesses a strength to be reckoned with. In the year 2000 I visited the Jabalaya refugee camp in Gaza, where over 100 people were killed by the Israeli army a year ago. Eighty thousand people live in one square kilometre. The schools have two shifts a day to cope with the number of children. I spoke to a father of seven children and his pregnant wife in their clean and tidy three-room home. He was a third-generation refugee. His grandparents had fled Israel in 1948. When I asked him why he had so many children, he smiled and said, ‘We are fighting them in the bedroom.’ If you look at the booming Palestinian population, his strategy is clear.

The Palestinian people have resisted the ethnic cleansing that the colonising Israeli settlers had hoped for. Israel will rule an empire where the Arab population outnumbers the Jewish population. Israel will be neither a democratic nor a Jewish state. That is what the member for Wentworth was referring to last week when he recalled Moshe Dayan’s 1967 warning: ‘You want the dowry but you do not want to marry the bride.’

The Gaza disengagement, which is accompanied by the expansion of settlements, should be seen as another tactical step by Israel—a way to freeze the peace process and to claim East Jerusalem. It is a strategy which flouts international law. As Israel’s Deputy Prime Minister has said, the strategy is to maximise the number of Jews and to minimise the number of Palestinians—something my friend in Jabalaya is doing his best to fight. We are witnessing the ethnic cleansing of East Jerusalem, the heart and soul of the Palestinian nation. The world must not allow this to happen.

talk.start.para: —It is no secret that, as proud Australians, we are all saddened by the loss of the Ashes last night, but we congratulate England on their victory. We all face challenges in life—some we conquer; some we lose. We all know that Kim Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, went to a lot of trouble shifting to Sydney to be closer to the political action but, sadly, it did not restore his status as patron of the Newcastle Knights. His demise from that role is a very sad and sorry tale, one that perhaps should be revealed only behind the closed doors of the party room and then in jest at the official briefing.

speech.para: It is fortunate for Mr Beazley that, when he was rolled by Latham for the leadership, he was dropped as the patron of the Knights. He was rolled for the job by Michael Costa, who is now known as ‘the minister for wooden spoons’. It is fortunate; otherwise we naturally would have blamed Kim for the Knights’ poor season and the wooden spoon. Or would we?

Everyone will understand that I only mention this story in humour and jest, but it is a story that I do not think the Leader of the Opposition can weasel out of—or, should I say, wriggle out of. But I will not say that, because it conjures up a vision. I say this in the same humorous way that Kim described the Prime Minister in the privacy of the caucus room. ‘Wriggle’ conjures up a vision that I do not think even Mr Beazley’s most ardent supporters would want to spend much time visualising, so I say ‘weasel’ rather than ‘wriggle’.

talk.start.para: —Order! The member for Paterson will refer to the Leader of the Opposition by his title.

—I refer to differing versions of an event today—the real doorstop transcript, and the Leader of the Opposition’s airbrushed version of events. It started in the Labor caucus today, where the Leader of the Opposition laid blame for the loss of the Ashes squarely at the Prime Minister’s feet. To quote AAP:

quote.para: “You can have your rugby tests, you can have international soccer, but this is what matters and there has been a frittering away of the spirit and he (Mr Beazley) holds that weasel (Mr Howard) responsible for it” a spokeswoman quoted the Labor leader as saying.

speech.para: Read: Julia Gillard, member for Lalor, leadership aspirant and official briefer for the Labor caucus. The Leader of the Opposition was not helped today by Senator Stephen Conroy in an interview with Jason Morrison on 2GB. I will recount this for the benefit of members present.

quote.para: Morrison: ... did you hear him say that about Mr Howard today?

Conroy: I was in the party room and I can say to you I am a little surprised at the reporting. It was very much tongue in cheek and my understanding is that ... Julia Gillard gave a briefing to the gallery where she went through a lot of Kim’s comments so in terms of I’m not aware if people rushed out and told people but my understanding was Julia Gillard gave a report to the assembled.

Morrison: I think that how it worked out is that Julia Gillard was asked questions about it because already some pretty senior and well known identities of the ALP had already run upstairs and told everybody to make sure you found out about it.

speech.para: Whilst Mr Beazley may dismiss this as the work of someone else, at the doorstop it was all his own work. When questioned on why he called the PM a weasel and why he chose that particular description, his transcript is different to the full version. It was unfortunate for him that Alison Carabine on 4BC Drive with John Miller played the full grab:

quote.para: Kim Beazley: Look I was speaking in jest. I don’t believe that the Prime Minister is responsible for us having lost the Ashes— not completely.

speech.para: And now for the airbrushed part:

quote.para: Journalist: Do you believe he’s a weasel?
Kim Beazley: Thanks very much. Good on you. See you later.
Carabine: So he was only joking, but when he was given the opportunity then to withdraw that description, he declined to do so.

speech.para: It would appear that, in regaining the Labor leadership, Beazley inherited Latham’s air brush for selectively cleaning up press transcripts to suit. Latham left it on the desk for Kim—a useful tool, no doubt.
Going back to the beginning of this supposedly humorous tale told in jest, it is best summed up by 2UE’s Steve Price. Today he said:

quote.para: Kim Beazley’s got to be kidding doesn’t he?

Reports out of Canberra have him blaming John Howard for the Ashes loss and calling him ‘a Little Weasel’. Now that shows what sort of party room solidarity Kim Beazley had—the moment he made those comments they were leaked , they were out to the rest of the media straight away.
Now name calling is pretty pathetic when you get to that level of federal politics and do we really want the alternative PM using such language? As for the Ashes jibe ... it was just stupid.

Kim Beazley plays right into John Howard’s hands with this sort of stuff, the electorate doesn’t like it and while many might disagree with John Howard’s policies and the direction he’s taking the country in, we don’t like the highest office in the land and the highest officer in the land being called a ‘weasel’.
That’s the sort of stuff Paul Keating used to go on with and look what happened to him.

speech.para: I am sure that this was just a tale told in jest, but, if it is a joke, who is it on?

talk.start.para: —It is all dust and ashes in the mouth—that is all I can say about the previous contribution. Sixty years ago, people in this country had war foisted upon them. We were part of the British Empire and had not signed up to the Balfour Declaration of 1931 or the Statute of Westminster, so when Britain declared war on 3 September 1939 we were necessarily at war.

speech.para: Earlier this year, we celebrated the 60th anniversary of Victory in Europe Day. Just recently, we celebrated the 60th anniversary of the Victory in the Pacific—or, as it is known to most people of my mother’s age group, Victory over Japan. We did what we do too few times in this House and we celebrated it. There is an ongoing debate in the Main Committee with regard to VP Day, but in our national life we have not celebrated enough those who experienced the depths of the Depression and all the difficulties that it created for their lives and who, coming out of that, went into the greatest and most total war that this planet has ever seen.

I am grateful to the government for providing funds for each electorate to commemorate it—$10,000 for each electorate, including Blaxland. I am grateful to the member for Banks, Daryl Melham MP, who ensured that $2,500 of his $10,000 was combined with what was available to Blaxland. I am also grateful for the work done by volunteers at the Australian Aviation Museum at Bankstown, under the leadership of Barry Thompson and with help from the Bankstown District Sports Club and the Bankstown City Council, to make our celebration on 21 August—a week after the main events of 14 and 15 August—something very important and central to everyone in the city of Bankstown.

Bankstown Airport is at the geographical heart of the city of Sydney and it is at the historical heart of Australia’s participation in the war in the Pacific. It was established as a military airport and had the distinction of being, at one and the same time, a naval base for the British, an Australian aviation base and a facility for the Americans. Our people who fought in the air were trained at Bankstown Airport in the surrounding fields of Villawood and Chullora. Armaments factories supplied their planes and the armaments for our ships and soldiers on all the various fronts, not only in the Pacific but elsewhere. It was in that war period that Bankstown established itself as an industrial area.

Black Charlies Hill overlooks the city of Bankstown—it was then a municipality—and, to the west, Bankstown Airport. Underneath that hill, in a bunker, was the command centre for the war in the Pacific. All naval shipping in the Pacific was controlled from that area, as well as air movements in Bankstown and elsewhere. It was one of General MacArthur’s prime command posts and it served throughout the war. Dr McNally, who was one of the recipients of a medal that day, had served in the Pacific war from a young age, breaking the Japanese kanji code and sending back intelligence information to our soldiers at the front. After the war, Dr McNally served under Black Charlies Hill in that defence establishment doing intelligence work.

Also at the function were people like Bert Collins, who served in West Papua New Guinea, now Irian Jaya. He and others fought—as they are fighting now—to try and get recognition for their service. He was one of 6,000 Australian soldiers faced with a Japanese force of 193,000. They expected the Japanese force to bear down and obliterate them. He survived malaria, infestation, dengue fever and the ravages of a long time in that climate, with ulceration and so on. He showed the proud spirit of the people of Bankstown and the strong desire of Australians to defend themselves and their people. I salute the courage of all those Australians who received medallions on the day or who will shortly be receiving medallions, people who with might and main fought their way to victory in the Pacific. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Tonight I rise to speak about welfare in contemporary Western democracy, particularly relating to Australia and to Indigenous issues. I quote from a report presented to parliament last year on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. In giving evidence to the committee in Adelaide on 23 September 2003, Reverend William Edwards said:

quote.para: At that time—

speech.para: and he refers to the fifties and sixties of the 20th century—

quote.para: Commonwealth finance was unavailable for Aboriginal work. The Presbyterian Board of Missions provided staff salaries—which were fairly low—and occasional extra funding for development work, such as fencing, well sinking et cetera. They also provided a budget in 1958 of $9,600 for general running expenses.

speech.para: He went on to say that the South Australian government provided additional funds, that the craft room brought in some income and that there were various employment opportunities. He continues:

quote.para: Older couples were employed as shepherds. Women were employed as school and clinic assistants and in staff houses and in the craft room. During these years Ernabella—

speech.para: in the north of South Australia—

quote.para: was a place of relative peace and purpose.

speech.para: This was before Commonwealth finance was available for Aboriginal work. He also said:

quote.para: All children attended school regularly and the clinic provided good or adequate medical services. There were few social problems.

speech.para: That set the scene for something like 40 years ago. I will move on to an editorial from the Australian, dated 12 August 2005, which said:

quote.para: If there is anyone out there who still thinks our long history of regarding Aborigines principally as candidates for welfare has achieved anything, they should study the photograph on the front page of The Australian yesterday—

speech.para: that is, 11 August—

quote.para: It showed a young man ... sniffing petrol from a can stuck down the front of his shirt.

... The Australian drew national attention to petrol-sniffing in 2001, as much as $12 million has been allocated to combat sniffing in the Anangu Pitjantjara region of far north South Australia alone. None of it appears to have done a lot of good. Take that as a microcosm of the state of indigenous policy generally. Aborigines die 20 years earlier than other Australians, are 15 times more likely to be in jail and 10 times more likely to be murdered.

speech.para: It further says:

quote.para: And, as Warren Mundine, a member of the National Indigenous Council and incoming national president of the ALP, has pointed out, it means releasing Aborigines from the socialist dreaming of the chattering classes and giving them individual, rather than collective, property rights over the land and houses they occupy.

speech.para: Another editorial which appeared in the Australian on 27 May 2004 said:

quote.para: ... In his sorry day speech at the Sydney Opera House last night, former prime minister Malcolm Fraser persisted with an older way of speaking about Aboriginal disadvantage in which the root cause is white racism. We need to become far more compassionate, he said. It would be hard to argue with that, but easy to argue about just what it means. For example, what is the properly compassionate response to the riot on the Block in Redfern in February that caused $1 million worth of property damage and injured 40 police? ... NSW parliamentary inquiry into it, we have heard racism, especially among police, trotted out as the spark that lit the inferno. The riot had many causes, heroin not least of them, and suggestions that only racism was responsible get us nowhere—

speech.para: It was put that:

quote.para: ... the solution is to decriminalise heroin and set up an injecting room at Redfern—beggars all belief. The real solution is something like the opposite: zero tolerance, and an urban version of the grog bans pioneered by Cape York leader Noel Pearson in far north Queensland.

speech.para: I will conclude by quoting the incoming national president of the Labor Party, Warren Mundine, a man for whom I have immense respect and regard, along with his wife; they are great leaders in this country. This immediate past weekend Mr Mundine said that a group of Indigenous leaders wished ‘to preserve us’—Aboriginal people—‘as museum pieces as well and keep us locked in poverty and socially dysfunctional communities’. He made the point that it keeps those who are running these things at the moment in a job. Clearly Mr Warren Mundine is going to set a new course in this area. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last week I attended the annual award night for the Granville District Soccer Football Association—a gala event attended by over 400 people—and I had the pleasure of watching one of my clubs, the Wenty Waratahs, win the prestigious Club of the Year award. The waratahs have been an active club for the past 50 years and provide sporting teams of various ages. During the last season, there were 633 players with the club, making up 23 junior teams, 12 senior teams and 11 Rooball teams.

speech.para: In a tremendous, all-round effort, the club had eight grand final teams, and six were victorious. I had been present at the presentation of medals for one of those teams the previous Saturday and was pleased to hear the comments by their opponents that it was a delight to compete against a team that just played soccer—a clear reference to the fair play of the Wenty Waratah teams. I should point out that winning the Club of the Year award is not just about winning games. The scoring system also recognises fair play. Clubs are penalised for yellow cards—I will not mention which club received over 1,000 yellow cards during the season; let us just say that it was not Wenty Waratahs. They won the award because of the quality of their coaching, consistent wins by the broad range of their teams and fair play.

Unless you are directly involved in soccer you might miss what an extraordinary thing it is that our local soccer competitions happen on the scale that they do. There are thousands of clubs around the country, held together and flourishing, decade after decade on the dedication of small groups of people. Some are parents, some are ex-players, some are just soccer enthusiasts and many are soccer fanatics. There is one person in the Granville district who walks around wearing an alarming soccer ball covered tie—and all those in Granville district know who I am talking about. All these people give their time out of commitment to the game and to their club.

In the Granville District Soccer Football Association, there are currently 10,735 registered players. Of those, 9,500 are male and about 1,200 are female. The numbers are up from last year and continue to grow. Attend the weekend games and you will see the world come together in our local parks. There are young boys and girls, and men and women, many whose families have lived locally for decades and others who have come to Australia from all over the world and brought their love of soccer with them. The sport is a great leveller in our community. It is a game that is known and loved around the world. It is an activity shared by those born and bred here and those new to our shores. Each team carries the characteristics of its local community. If you want to see just how successful our multicultural society is, just hang out at the local oval in my neck of the woods and see some kids kick around a ball.

Today I most want to acknowledge the volunteers who make all things possible when it comes to weekend sport: the people who hassle local councils to support them with the provision of ovals; the people who raise the funds and give their time to keep those sporting fields up to scratch; the people who each month organise and manage hundreds of games and many more training sessions; and the people who raise the money, work in the canteens, coach, umpire, clean up and wash the jerseys. It is remarkable that people give so much to their clubs. It is even more remarkable that, in the case of Granville and District Soccer Football Association, people have been doing it for over 100 years.

The Granville and District Soccer Football Association is recognised as the oldest football association in the Southern Hemisphere. It celebrated its 100th birthday in 2002. The original club, the Granville Soccer Club, was formed back in 1882 by a group of Scottish steelworkers from the Clyde Steelworks, together with English and Welsh migrants. It became known officially as the Granville Soccer Club and initially games were played at Brunton’s paddock, which is currently the site of the Granville Returned and Services League club.

The football association was formed in 1902, incorporating a number of clubs, with its boundaries encompassing approximately 35 per cent of the current Sydney metropolitan area, stretching from Gladesville in the east to the Nepean River in the west. It was not until the 1950s that population growth started to shrink its boundaries. Now it represents over 30 clubs, including those in my electorate: Dundas United, Ermington United, Hills Brumbies, North Rocks, Parramatta City, Parramatta Eagles, Pendle Hill, St Joseph’s Rydalmere, Toongabbie, Winston Hills and, of course, the club of the year, the Wenty Waratahs.

I congratulate all the players this season, but I particularly wish to thank all the people who made the games happen and the clubs flourish. I know that, for most of the volunteers who keep the faith, the sport—soccer—is the point of their efforts, but local sport and soccer in particular play an essential role in our community beyond the sport itself in bringing people together and networking children and adults across cultural and economic divides. We would be a much poorer community without the Granville and Districts Soccer Football Association and its team of dedicated volunteers.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak about telecommunications services in my electorate of Bass. I also wish to correct the record after incorrect statements were made in the Senate today. I seek leave to table an election advertisement published in the Examiner in October 2004.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —As a candidate for election last year, I promised to be honest, to work hard and to give my best. I promised to stand up to governments of any colour if my community needed me to. I promised to be myself, a person who believes in the value of Christian values. I know that I am not perfect and I know that I cannot possibly solve all the world’s problems. But is it reasonable to be lectured by a lazy Labor senator who would not know how to stand up for a local community if it bit him on the bum, who willingly misleads the Australian Senate and who deliberately misquotes his opponents?

speech.para: During the election campaign, I worked closely with local people because I wanted to understand what the local issues were and how I could help with them. One issue was phone services in Nunamara, a small town on the Tasman Highway just to the east of Launceston. The local network itself was in need of ongoing maintenance. I am pleased to see that Telstra listened to our concerns and last week announced a million dollar upgrade of the network for early 2006. It is the right thing to do. It will be appreciated by the local community and, I believe, further demonstrates how federal government regulation has left Telstra little room but to make the needed investment.

Importantly, though, it is impossible to get mobile phone reception in this area. I became concerned about this and decided to do something about it. This is not just an issue for the townspeople of Nunamara; perhaps more importantly it is an issue for the 8,000 or so residents of the north-east who commute to Launceston on this road. For a substantial section of the journey, mobile phones are unusable. To address this I promised to lobby for funding for a CDMA tower. Those are my exact words from the advertisement that I have just tabled. It is a promise I have kept and I will keep working. I think it is worth pointing out that no other candidate offered any such assurance of assistance whatsoever.

I have persistently pushed the matter of improving services in Nunamara: I have spoken in the House; I have raised the matter in my party room within the hearing of my colleagues, including ministers and the Prime Minister; I have written to and spoken with Senator Helen Coonan about how the government can assist Telstra to improve mobile phone services at Nunamara; and I have held discussions, even with Telstra, since October.

This brings me to Senator Kerry O’Brien’s remarks in the Senate today, where he reported his own—wrong—version of events in order to try to mischievously suggest that I have not kept a commitment. He said that I guaranteed funding to deliver the mobile tower, as if the coalition had accepted to pay for it as part of our election promise costings. He further claimed that after my win I promised delivery of this fanciful commitment within 100 days. That is absolutely wrong, and the senator knows it. Some people would say that Senator O’Brien is a barefaced liar—

talk.start.para: —Order! The member will withdraw that comment.
—Mr Speaker, I said that some people would say that.
—The member for Bass will withdraw that comment!

—I do withdraw. In my view the $3.1 billion package to address shortcomings and to future proof telecommunications gives us a realistic chance to get this project up. The taxpayer should not have to stump up the full cost; Telstra should contribute too—after all, they will benefit. They will gain a new asset and it will benefit their customers, which will deliver them more income. That is what I will continue to push for, and I know that if we do get a result it will be because I have taken this issue to the government and Telstra in a constructive way.

speech.para: For what it is worth, hardly anyone in Tasmania even knows who this senator is. I think that his whinging in the Senate today is partly motivated by hatred of the Liberal Party and partly by guilt because he knows that, as a supporter of the Latham forestry policy, he sold out the very same community that he has been using today in an attempt to attack me. Now I find that he has even promised to vote against the very funding package—Connect Australia—which could make this upgrade possible. In closing I would say that Senator Kerry O’Brien should be ashamed of himself for misleading the parliament and for his grubby attempts to diminish my reputation as a member who works hard and does his best for the people of Bass.

talk.start.para: —During the winter recess I received an anti-whaling petition from grade 2 and 3 students at Findon Primary School in Mill Park. The petition is not in the proper form for presentation to the parliament. When I visited the school two weeks ago I undertook to table the petition on their behalf. I congratulate Thu Thao and Vivian for organising the petition and thank them and their fellow students for their interest in conservation. I seek leave to table the document.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 9.30 pm, the debate is interrupted.

debate.para: M r A bbott to present a bill for an act to amend the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, and for related purposes. (National Health Amendment (Budget Measures—Pharmaceutical Benefits Safety Net) Bill 2005)
M r A bbott to present a bill for an act to amend the National Health Act 1953, and for other purposes. (National Health Amendment (Immunisation Program) Bill 2005)
M r A bbott to present a bill for an act to amend legislation relating to health, and for related purposes. (Health Legislation Amendment Bill 2005)
M r A bbottto present a bill for an act to amend the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989, and for related purposes. (Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2005)

M r R uddock to present a bill for an act to amend various Acts relating to law and justice, and for related purposes. (Law and Justice Legislation Amendment (Video Link Evidence and Other Measures) Bill 2005)

M r R uddock to present a bill for an act to amend the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979, and for other purposes. (Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005)
D r N elson to present a bill for an act to amend legislation relating to higher education, and for related purposes. (Higher Education Legislation Amendment (2005 Measures No. 4) Bill 2005)
D r N elson to present a bill for and act to amend the Education Services for Overseas Students Act 2000, and for related purposes. (Education Services for Overseas Students Amendment Bill 2005)
M r M acfarlane to present a bill for an act to encourage more efficient use of energy by large energy using businesses, and for related purposes. (Energy Efficiency Opportunities Bill 2005)
D r S tone to move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Proposed office replacement of the Bureau of Meteorology at Willis Island, Coral Sea, Qld.
D r S tone to move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Proposed fitout of new leased premises for Australian Customs Service at 1010 LaTrobe Street, Docklands, Melbourne, Vic.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: Did the Department or any agency under the Minister’s portfolio engage the services of a media training company in 2004; if so, how many individuals (by agency/department) received media training.
Did the Minister personally receive any media training.
What was the cost of the media training.
What was the name and postal address of each company engaged to provide media training.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Yes.

item.label: (a)
item.para: 822 individuals in Defence received some form of media training from companies in 2004.
No.
The cost of media training delivered within Defence can be divided into two categories:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 25 May 2005:

item.para: What sum was provided in 2004 to (a) government and (b) non-government schools in the postcode area (i) 2167, (ii) 2168, (iii) 2170, (iv) 2171, (v) 2174, (vi) 2178, (vii) 2179, (viii) 2560, (ix) 2564, (x) 2565, and (xi) 2566.
What was the (a) location of, (b) expenditure on and (c) purpose of each grant in 2004.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Total Australian Government funding for government schools is not reported at the level of detail requested. Australian Government General Recurrent Grants for government schools are provided to the government education authority in each State or Territory, on the basis of total enrolments. The State or Territory determines where the grants are used. Payments to individual schools are not recorded.

The Department of Education, Science and Training only provides postcode detail for General Recurrent Grants and Establishment Grants to non-government schools, and Capital Grants, Flagpole funding and funding for the Boys’ Education Lighthouse Schools (BELS) project and values Education Study to both government and non‑government schools.

No Capital Grants funding was provided to government schools in the electoral division of Werriwa and identified postcode areas in 2004. Grants totalling $5,887.17 under the Flagpole funding initiative, were provided to government schools in the identified postcode areas for 2004.

BELS funding is provided to a nominated ‘lighthouse’ school in a “cluster” of schools, both government and non-government, in a defined region. The Lighthouse School within the cluster at the postcode of 2560 in the electoral division of Macarthur, Airds High School (a government school), received BELS funding amounting to $19,318.20 in 2004 on behalf of other schools (government and non-government) in the cluster.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Total Australian Government funding for non-government schools cannot be reported at the level of detail requested. General Recurrent Grants funding totalling $81,089,891.90 and capital grants totalling $2,285,474.00 were provided to non‑government schools in the identified postcodes for 2004. No Establishment Grants, Flagpole funding, funding for the BELS project or the values Education Study were provided to non-government schools in the identified postcodes in 2004.

(2) (a) and (b) Details on the expenditure and location for the identified postcodes for 2004 are as follows: Funding to government schools for 2004 for flagpoles is in Table 1 at Attachment A; and funding for the BELS project is in Table 2, Attachment A. General Recurrent funding to non-government schools is in Table 3 at Attachment A and Capital Grants funding for non-government schools is in Table 4 at Attachment A.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The purpose of Flagpole funding is to assist schools with their civics and citizenship education activities, and promoting values education in Australian schools.

The purpose of Australian Government General Recurrent Grants is to help schools with the recurrent cost of school education so that they can offer students education directed towards the achievement of the Australian Government’s priorities for schooling.

The purpose of Capital grants is to provide supplementary funding to improve educational outcomes by assisting in the provision of school facilities. The Australian Government Capital Grants are supplementary to funds provided by state and territory school authorities and are used to provide and improve capital infrastructure, ensure attention to refurbishing and upgrading capital infrastructure for existing students while making provision for needs arising from new demographic and enrolment trends.

The purpose of the Boys’ Education Lighthouse Schools Project is to enhance teaching and learning in the education of boys in Australian schools by establishing effective teaching and learning practices in “clusters” of schools.

subdebateinfo.title: United Nations Relief and Works Agency

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 9 August 2005:

item.para: Can he confirm that Australia will be providing $6.2 million to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine (UNRWA), consisting of $4.2 million core funding and $2 million to support UNRWA’s 2005 Appeal.

Is he aware that (a) the head of UNRWA, Mr Peter Hansen, has acknowledged that there are Hamas members on the payroll of UNRWA and does not see the need to address this problem, (b) in September 2003, an Israeli military court convicted three UNRWA employees for acts of terrorism, (c) a public Israeli government report in 2002 stated that UNRWA schools are used for storing ammunition for terrorists, UNRWA vehicles have been used for transporting terrorists to attacks, and that UNRWA ambulances have been used for transporting ammunition between terror cells, (d) UNRWA schools are used by Islamic Jihad and Hamas as forums for distributing propaganda, an activity which has been supported by the Hamas-dominated UNRWA teachers’ union, (e) UNRWA continues to manifest through its agencies an ideological commitment to the unconditional return of all Palestinian refugees to residence within the borders of pre-1967 Israel, in direct contradiction of the ongoing peace process and that this is done through de-legitimisation of Israel in UNRWA schools and UNRWA support of programs to perpetuate this viewpoint amongst the residents of its camps, and (f) UNRWA camp residents have claimed that black marketeering and corruption have seen many vital aid supplies directed away from the residents who need them most.
Can he confirm that Hamas and Islamic Jihad remain classified as terrorist organisations by overwhelming vote of both houses of the Australian Parliament.

Is he aware that the United States, as a response to proven UNRWA support of arming and training terrorist groups, has introduced statutory regulations requiring the General Accounting Office to ensure that funding to UNRWA does not flow through to such groups.

Has he implemented mechanisms to ensure that Australian funding is not used in support of arming and training terrorist groups; if so, what are they; if not, how does he propose to ensure that the funding is directed towards legitimate aid-related activities.
Has he placed any conditions on the manner in which the aid money is to be spent by UNRWA.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: In financial year 2004/2005 Australia provided $6.2 million to UNRWA, comprising $4.2 million in core funding and $2.0 million to support UNRWA’s 2005 Emergency Appeal.

(2) (a) I am aware of the statement made by the then UNRWA Commissioner-General, Peter Hansen. My Department raised this matter with UNRWA. Mr Hansen clarified that he was referring to likely Hamas sympathisers, but that this did not in any way mean UNRWA supported terrorism or employed terrorists. UNRWA has maintained that it expects its staff to adhere to strict codes of conduct, including non-involvement in political activities and being impartial servants of the UN. A fuller response to this issue from UNRWA can be found on its Internet website (www.unrwa.org).

item.label: (a)
item.para: I am aware of the statement made by the then UNRWA Commissioner-General, Peter Hansen. My Department raised this matter with UNRWA. Mr Hansen clarified that he was referring to likely Hamas sympathisers, but that this did not in any way mean UNRWA supported terrorism or employed terrorists. UNRWA has maintained that it expects its staff to adhere to strict codes of conduct, including non-involvement in political activities and being impartial servants of the UN. A fuller response to this issue from UNRWA can be found on its Internet website (www.unrwa.org).

item.label: (b)
item.para: Yes, I’m aware of the convictions. In November 2003, the then Commissioner-General, Peter Hansen, issued a written statement regarding the matter.

item.label: (c)
item.para: I am aware that Israel has raised concerns about these sorts of issues. There has been dialogue between the relevant parties and efforts made to overcome these concerns.

item.label: (d)
item.para: I am aware of the accusations and again my understanding is that there have been discussions between Israeli authorities, the Palestinian Authority and UNRWA on these issues.

item.label: (e)
item.para: I am aware of the allegations. In my meeting in January 2004 with Mr Hansen I raised the issue of incitement in UNRWA school textbooks. Mr Hansen advised that in accordance with a longstanding agreement with UNESCO, the UN was obliged to use host government textbooks. Mr Hansen also noted that independent scholars had reviewed the Palestinian textbooks. The UNRWA website (www.unrwa.org) also seeks to respond to these issues. My Department continues to pay attention to this matter.

item.label: (f)
item.para: While we have not seen reporting that would confirm these allegations, the Government is deeply concerned by the debilitating effect corruption has had on the economic prospects of the Palestinian people. Australia is working alongside other international donors to help combat corruption.

Hamas’ Izz al-Din al-Qassam Brigades and Palestinian Islamic Jihad (PIJ) were recently specified under the Criminal Code Regulations 2005 as terrorist organisations for the purposes of section 102.1 of the Criminal Code Act 1995 (the Criminal Code). These Regulations took effect from 5 June 2005. These organisations were re-listed as terrorist organisations under the Criminal Code as the Attorney-General continued to be satisfied that HAMAS’ and PIJ are organisations directly or indirectly engaged in preparing, planning, assisting in or fostering the doing of a terrorist act (whether or not the act has occurred or will occur).
I am aware of the United States regulations requiring the General Accounting Office to ensure UNRWA funding does not flow to terrorist groups. I note the U.S. is continuing to fund UNRWA.

Yes. Australia has formal agreements in place with multilaterals (including UNRWA) that require those institutions to ensure funds are expended in a manner consistent with UN Security Council Resolution 1373 (2001) and related Australian laws.

Yes. AusAID’s formal agreements with UNRWA address aid effectiveness by directing Australia’s contribution to specific purposes and requiring accountability through appropriate financial and reporting mechanisms. The agreements also specify compliance with relevant counter-terrorism legislation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 9 August 2005:

item.para: Can he explain the process for the establishment of a low-level nuclear waste dump for Australian low-level nuclear waste including (a) when the process was commenced, (b) what is its current status, (c) what steps are yet to be completed, and (d) what is the estimated timeline for completing the process including the estimated timing of a final decision on the location of a dump.
What is the precise nature of the material or materials to be stored in the dump.
Has there been an audit or any other type of review conducted to determine the sites where low-level nuclear waste is currently stored around Australia.
How many sites for the storage of low-level nuclear waste material are there in Australia and where is each site located.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The process for establishing the Commonwealth Radioactive Waste Management Facility (‘the Facility’) is:
- field studies will be conducted at three Defence properties in the Northern Territory (as announced on 15 July 2005) to determine their suitability or otherwise to host the Facility;

- after evaluation of the sites, a decision will be made on a preferred site that will be referred to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage for assessment under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999;

- should the Minister for Environment and Heritage approve construction of the Facility at the preferred site, licences to site, construct and operate the Facility will need to be sought from the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA).
The Commonwealth Radioactive Waste Management Facility will manage low and intermediate level radioactive waste generated by Australian Government departments, agencies and statutory authorities.
Low level radioactive waste includes:
- contaminated laboratory equipment, such as protective clothing, paper, rubber gloves, plastic and glassware;
- lightly contaminated soil arising from previous CSIRO research into mineral extraction that had been transported to Woomera by the former Government in 1995; and
- low activity disused radioactive sources (for example smoke detectors and exit signs).
Intermediate level radioactive waste includes:
- residues from overseas reprocessing of Australian spent research reactor fuel;
- waste arising from the production of radiopharmaceuticals by ANSTO; and
- higher activity disused radioactive sources arising from industry, medicine and research.

Information on State and Territory radioactive waste management arrangements was provided to the Commonwealth through the former Commonwealth/State/Territory Radioactive Waste Consultative Committee. Information on national radioactive waste holdings obtained through this process is summarised in DEST’s radioactive waste website http://www.radioactivewaste.gov.au .

ARPANSA has recently asked State and Territory Governments to provide up to date inventories of radioactive waste holdings in accordance with Australia’s obligations under the international Joint Convention on the Safety of Spent Fuel Management and on the Safety of Radioactive Waste Management. ARPANSA will shortly commence an audit into radioactive waste held by Australian Government departments, agencies and statutory authorities.

It is estimated that low level radioactive waste is stored at over 100 locations around Australia in government stores and in universities, hospitals and in factories. In addition, low level radioactive waste is disposed of at the Government of Western Australia’s Mt Walton East Integrated Waste Management Facility. The Queensland Government operates a purpose-built radioactive waste store at Esk.

The Australian Government stores radioactive waste at Woomera in South Australia and the Lucas Heights Science and Technology Centre in Sydney. Radioactive waste is also stored at Department of Defence facilities in or near Melbourne, Ipswich, Wodonga, Adelaide, Newcastle, Darwin, Sydney and Nowra; at CSIRO facilities in Canberra, Sydney, Adelaide, Mt Gambier, Brisbane and Melbourne; and at the Australian National University.
Questions regarding the location of radioactive waste that is under state or territory control should be directed to the relevant agency in each jurisdiction.
